Notes will be guaranteed on a senior unsecured basis by Parent and each of Parent’s existing and future wholly owned domestic restricted subsidiaries that are
guarantors under the New Term Loan Credit Agreement (as defined herein) (the “Subsidiary Guarantors” and, together with Parent, the “Guarantors”) and
(ii) the Secured Notes will be guaranteed on a senior secured basis by each of the Guarantors. To the extent lenders under the New Term Loan Credit
Agreement release any Guarantor from its obligations, subject to certain exceptions, such Guarantor will also be released from its obligations under the Notes.

Description of the Secured Notes—Secured Note Guarantees.”

- Security and Ranking: If this offering closes prior to the consummation of the Acquisition and the Reorganization, the Notes will initially be obligations
solely of the Issuer, secured by a first-priority security interest in the applicable escrow account and all deposits and investments therein. From and after
satisfaction of the Escrow Release Conditions and immediately following the consummation of the Acquisition and the Reorganization (or on the Issue Date
immediately following the Acquisition and Reorganization if the Acquisition and Reorganization close concurrently with this offering), the Unsecured Notes
and the related guarantees will be general, senior unsecured obligations of the Issuer and the Guarantors, and will rank senior in right of payment to all of the
Issuer’s and the Guarantors’ subordinated indebtedness and equally in right of payment with all of the Issuer’s and the Guarantors’ senior indebtedness,
without giving effect to collateral arrangements. The Unsecured Notes and the related guarantees will be effectively subordinated to any of the Issuer’s and
the Guarantors’ secured indebtedness, including the New Credit Facilities and the Secured Notes offered hereby, to the extent of the value of the assets
securing such indebtedness, and will be structurally subordinated to the liabilities of Parent’s subsidiaries that are not Subsidiary Guarantors. From and after
satisfaction of the Escrow Release Conditions and immediately following the Acquisition and the Reorganization (or on the Issue Date immediately following
the Acquisition and the Reorganization if the Acquisition and the Reorganization close concurrently with this offering), the Secured Notes and the related
guarantees will be general, senior secured obligations of the Issuer and the Guarantors, secured on a first-priority basis by security interests in the Fixed Asset
Collateral (as defined herein) and on a second-priority basis in the Current Asset Collateral (as defined herein), in each case, subject to certain limitations and
permitted liens. The Secured Notes and the related guarantees will rank senior in right of payment to all of the Issuer’s and the Guarantors’ subordinated
indebtedness and be effectively senior to all of the Issuer’s and the Guarantors’ unsecured indebtedness, including the Unsecured Notes offered hereby, and
indebtedness secured by liens junior to the liens securing the Secured Notes, including, in the case of the Fixed Asset Collateral, the New ABL Revolving
Credit Facility (as defined herein), in each case, to the extent of the value of the assets securing the Secured Notes. The Secured Notes and the related
guarantees will rank equally in right of payment with all of the Issuer’s and the Guarantors’ senior indebtedness, without giving effect to collateral
arrangements, and equal to all of the Issuer’s and the Guarantors’ senior indebtedness secured on the same priority basis as the Secured Notes, including the
New Term Loan Credit Agreement. The Secured Notes and the related guarantees will be effectively subordinated to any of the Issuer’s and the Guarantors’
indebtedness that is secured by assets that do not constitute collateral for the Secured Notes to the extent of the value of such assets, and indebtedness that is
secured by a senior-priority lien, including our New ABL Revolving Credit Facility to the extent of the value of the Current Asset Collateral, and will be
structurally subordinated to the liabilities of Parent’s subsidiaries that are not Subsidiary Guarantors.

**USE OF NON-GAAP FINANCIAL MEASURES**

To supplement our financial information presented in accordance with U.S. GAAP, we use the following
non-GAAP financial measures to clarify and enhance an understanding of past performance: EBITDA, Adjusted
EBITDA, Pro Forma Combined EBITDA, Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Combined Adjusted
EBITDA (After Synergies), Segment profit, Adjusted net operating cash flows, and Adjusted net investing cash
flows. We believe that the presentation of these financial measures enhances an investor’s understanding of our
financial performance. We further believe that these financial measures are useful financial metrics to assess our
operating performance from period-to-period by excluding certain items that we believe are not representative of our
core business. We use certain of these financial measures for business planning purposes and in measuring our
performance relative to that of our competitors. We utilize Segment profit as the primary measure of our segment
specific performance. The following terms have the following meanings:

  - “Adjusted EBITDA” means EBITDA further adjusted to give effect to (i) for Solenis, the impact of realized
and unrealized foreign exchange gains/losses, severance payments associated with restructuring, non-cash
expense for equity compensation plans, financing expenses, non-service costs for pensions and other nonoperational items, fees paid to Solenis’ current shareholders and merger related costs, integration, other
non-recurring items, incentive compensation above 1.0x of the applicable target, one-time income related
to the clawback of bonuses realized in 2021, non-cash gains on an asset disposal and pre-acquisition
EBITDA for the acquisitions by Solenis of Chemsystems Pulp and Paper business, Poliquimicos, S.A. de
C.V. and MFG Chemicals and, in prior periods, adjustments related to the JV and, (ii) for Sigura, the
impact of non-operating income/expense, including Sigura’s gain on the sale of Surface Water in October
2020, fees paid to Platinum, one-time consulting and transaction costs related to the separation from its
previous owners, as well as other non-recurring and unusual costs, one-time consulting and other costs
related to implementation of operational improvement plans, severance payments associated with
restructuring, unrealized foreign exchange gains/losses, the disposal of a fixed asset and the divestiture of
its Surface Water segment and Argentina business.

  - “Adjusted net operating cash flows” and “Adjusted net investing cash flows” means, for Solenis, reported
net cash (used in) provided by operating activities and net cash provided by (used in) investing activities,
each adjusted for the effects of cash subsequently received as part of our Existing Accounts Receivable
Financing (as defined below).

  - “EBITDA” means net income (loss) before interest expense, income taxes, depreciation and amortization
(including amortization of pre-publication investment cash costs).

  - “Pro Forma Combined EBITDA” means EBITDA further adjusted to give effect to the Transactions.

  - “Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA” means Adjusted EBITDA further adjusted to give effect to the
Transactions.

  - “Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA (After Synergies)” means Pro Forma Combined Adjusted
EBITDA further adjusted to give effect to the unaudited pro forma combined impact for certain estimated
run-rate annual cost synergies from actions expected to be taken within 18 months of the closing of the
Transactions. See “Risk Factors—Risks Related to the Acquisition and Reorganization—We may not
achieve some or all of the expected benefits from the items reflected in the adjustments included in
Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA and Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA
(After Synergies).”

  - “Segment profit” means, for Solenis, EBITDA adjusted for (i) non-operating income or expense, (ii) the
impact of certain non-cash, non-recurring or other items that are included in net (loss) and EBITDA that we
do not consider indicative of our ongoing operating performance and (iii) certain unusual or non-recurring
items impacting results in a particular period.

vii


-----

We believe the EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Combined EBITDA, Pro Forma Combined
Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA (After Synergies), Segment profit, Adjusted net
operating cash flows, and Adjusted net investing cash flows measures are commonly used by investors to evaluate
our performance and that of our competitors. However, our use of the terms EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA, Pro
Forma Combined EBITDA, Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA
(After Synergies), Segment profit, Adjusted net operating cash flows, and Adjusted net investing cash flows may
vary from that of other competitors in our industry. These financial measures should not be considered alternatives
to income before income taxes, net (loss), or any other performance measures derived in accordance with U.S.
GAAP as measures of operating performance. See “Summary—Unaudited Pro Forma Condensed Consolidated
Financial Information” and “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of
Operations of Solenis—Non-GAAP Financial Metrics—Reconciliation of Net (Loss) to EBITDA and Segment
Profit.”

With respect to Adjusted net operating cash flows and Adjusted net investing cash flows, Accounting
Standards Update (“ASU”) 2016-15 requires us to evaluate the transfer of title of receivables sold under our Existing
Accounts Receivable Financing against cash received on previously-sold receivables in exchange for the transfer of
title. Since there is a dichotomy between when we legally transfer title of receivables to ING Luxembourg S.A. or
MUFG Bank, Ltd under the current receivables purchasing agreements and when the cash received on previouslysold receivables, receivables are deemed transferred in exchange for a beneficial interest in the collection of that
receivable. This is considered a non-cash investing activity. Furthermore, ultimate receipts of cash, when settled
with ING Luxembourg or MUFG Bank, Ltd., are considered cash flows from investing activities, as the receipt is
considered a return of capital on the beneficial interest.

We believe that this may cause net cash (used in) provided by operating activities and net cash provided by
(used in) investing activities to be potentially misleading to investors. While Solenis does not retain legal ownership
of the receivables sold, the nature, timing, and extent of cash flows have not materially changed as a result of the
agreement. We use these non-GAAP metrics to assess our own liquidity.

The adjustments reflected in our Pro Forma Combined EBITDA, Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA
and Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA (After Synergies) have not been prepared with a view towards
complying with Article 11 of Regulation S-X. Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA (After Synergies) is
intended to provide additional information on a more comparable basis than would be if provided without such
adjustments because they account for initiatives related to back office, sales and support staff optimization,
warehouse and temporary labor efficiency and technology, among others.

The non-GAAP measures noted above are the primary indicators that we use internally to conduct and
measure our business and evaluate the performance of our consolidated operations. We believe these non-GAAP
financial measures are useful because they provide meaningful comparisons to prior periods. These non-GAAP
financial measures are used in addition to and in conjunction with results presented in accordance with
GAAP. These non-GAAP financial measures reflect an additional way of viewing aspects of our operations that,
when viewed with our GAAP results and the accompanying reconciliations to corresponding GAAP financial
measures, provide a more complete understanding of factors and trends affecting our business. A material limitation
associated with these non-GAAP measures as compared to the GAAP measures is that they may not be comparable
to other companies with similarly titled measures that present related measures differently. The non-GAAP
measures should be considered as a supplement to, and not as a substitute for or superior to, the corresponding
measures calculated in accordance with GAAP.

The Indentures governing the Notes and the New Credit Agreements include definitions of EBITDA-based
metrics that are different from the definition of EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Combined EBITDA, Pro
Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA and Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA (After Synergies) used herein.
EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Combined EBITDA, Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA and Pro
Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA (After Synergies) should be considered in addition to, not as a substitute for, or
superior to, measures of financial performance prepared in accordance with GAAP. You are encouraged to evaluate
each adjustment and the reasons we consider them appropriate for supplemental analysis. In evaluating EBITDA,
Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Combined EBITDA, Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA and Pro Forma
Combined Adjusted EBITDA (After Synergies), you should be aware that in the future we may incur expenses

viii


-----

similar to the adjustments in this presentation. Our presentation of EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma
Combined EBITDA, Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA and Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA (After
Synergies) should not be construed as an inference that our future results will be unaffected by unusual or nonrecurring items.

The non-GAAP metrics do not necessarily indicate whether cash flow will be sufficient or available to
meet our cash requirements and may not be indicative of our historical operating results, nor are such measures
meant to be predictive of our future results. Our non-GAAP metrics have limitations as analytical tools, and you
should not consider them in isolation. Some of these limitations are:

  - they do not reflect our cash expenditures or future requirements for capital expenditures or contractual
commitments;

  - they do not reflect changes in, or cash requirements for, our working capital needs;

  - they do not reflect the significant interest expense, or the cash requirements necessary, to service interest or
principal payments on our debts;

  - although depreciation and amortization are non-cash charges, the assets being depreciated and amortized
will often need to be replaced in the future and EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Combined
EBITDA, Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA and Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA (After
Synergies) do not reflect any cash requirements that would be required for such replacements;

  - some of the exceptional items that we eliminate in calculating EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma
Combined EBITDA, Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA and Pro Forma Combined Adjusted
EBITDA (After Synergies) reflect cash payments that were made, or will be made in the future; and

  - other companies in our industry may calculate EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Combined
EBITDA, Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA (After
Synergies), Segment profit, Adjusted net operating cash flows, or Adjusted net investing cash flows
differently than we do, limiting their usefulness as comparative measures.

We compensate for these limitations by using EBITDA, Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Combined
EBITDA, Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA (After Synergies),
Segment profit, Adjusted net operating cash flows, and Adjusted net investing cash flows along with other
comparative tools, together with U.S. GAAP measurements, to assist in the evaluation of operating performance.
Such U.S. GAAP measurements include income before income taxes, and net (loss) amongst other performance
metrics. In evaluating these financial measures, one should be aware that in the future we may incur expenses
similar to those eliminated in this presentation. Our presentation of such measures should not be construed as an
inference that our future results will be unaffected by unusual or non-recurring items.

We may incur expenses similar to the adjustments noted herein to calculate Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma
Combined Adjusted EBITDA and Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA (After Synergies). However, the
magnitude of such adjustments for the periods noted below is not necessarily indicative of the magnitude of such
adjustments in future periods.

See “Summary—Summary Historical Financial and Pro Forma Financial Data” for a reconciliation of these
measures to our directly comparable GAAP measures.

Because the leverage ratios presented in this offering memorandum are based, in part, on Adjusted
EBITDA, Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA and Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA (After Synergies),
these measures are similarly impacted by the limitations referenced above and also should not be considered in
isolation or as a substitute for GAAP measures.

**BASIS OF PRESENTATION**

The consolidated financial statements of Solenis UK International as of and for each of the years ended
September 30, 2020, 2019 and 2018 have been prepared in accordance U.S. GAAP, and include the financial
statements of Solenis UK International and its wholly owned subsidiaries.

The consolidated and combined financial statements of Innovative Water Care Global Corporation, doing
business as Sigura, as of and for the years ended December 31, 2020 and December 31, 2019 have also been
prepared in accordance with U.S. GAAP, and include the financial statements of Innovative Water Care Global
Corporation and its wholly owned subsidiaries.

Historically, the combined and consolidated financial statements of the Solenis business were presented at
the level of Solenis International, L.P., a Dutch limited partnership. In January 2019, in conjunction with the
acquisition of BASF SE’s paper and water chemicals business, the ownership interests in Solenis International
L.L.C. (formerly a limited partnership known as Solenis International L.P.) transferred to Solenis UK International,
and the business’s combined and consolidated financial statements for the year ended September 30, 2019 partially
restated the consolidated statement of operations, the consolidated balance sheet and the consolidated statement of
cash flows as of and for the years ended September 30, 2018 and 2017 to reflect the change in reporting entity for
comparability purposes.

It is not anticipated that either Solenis UK International or Solenis UK Holdings Ltd will be acquired as
part of the Acquisition. Neither Solenis UK International nor Solenis UK Holdings Ltd have any business operations
or assets, other than certain cash and cash equivalents, intercompany loan balances and investments in the ownership
interests of the Sellers. All such intercompany balances and transactions will be eliminated as part of the
rationalization prior to the consummation of the Acquisition and Reorganization. See “Unaudited Pro Forma
Condensed Combined Financial Information—Note 3(c).”

Due to the impact of the acquisition by Platinum and certain of its affiliates of Sigura on February 28, 2019,
Sigura’s consolidated and combined financial statements and certain note presentations for the year ended December
31, 2019, are presented in two distinct periods to indicate the application of a different basis of accounting between
the periods presented: (1) the period up to and including the acquisition date (January 1, 2019 through February 28,
2019, labeled Predecessor) and (2) the period after that date (March 1, 2019 through December 31, 2019, labeled
Successor).

The consolidated statement of operations of Solenis for the fiscal years ended September 30, 2020, 2019
and 2018, and the consolidated balance sheet data as of September 30, 2020 and 2019 have been derived from the
audited consolidated financial statements and related notes of Solenis UK International for the year ended
September 30, 2020, included elsewhere in this offering memorandum. This offering memorandum also includes
the unaudited interim consolidated financial information of Solenis for the nine months ended June 30, 2021, which
has been derived from the unaudited consolidated financial statements of Solenis UK International.

The consolidated statement of operations of Sigura for the fiscal year ended December 31, 2020, and the
consolidated balance sheet data as of December 31, 2020 have been derived from the audited consolidated financial
statements and related notes of Innovative Water Care Global Corporation as of and for the year ended December
31, 2020, included elsewhere in this offering memorandum (and which comprise the consolidated balance sheets as
of December 31, 2020 and 2019, and the related consolidated and combined statements of comprehensive loss,
stockholders’ invested equity (deficit) and cash flows for the year ended December 31, 2020, consolidated for the
period from March 1, 2019 to December 31, 2019 (Successor) and combined for the period from January 1, 2019 to
February 28, 2019 (Predecessor), and the related notes to the consolidated and combined financial statements). This
offering memorandum also includes the unaudited interim consolidated financial information of Sigura for the six
months ended June 30, 2021 and June 30, 2020, which has been derived from the unaudited consolidated financial
statements of Innovative Water Care Global Corporation as of and for the six months ended June 30, 2021.

Financial data of Solenis for the twelve months ended June 30, 2021 has been derived by subtracting data
from our unaudited consolidated financial statements for the nine months ended June 30, 2020 from our audited

**Company Overview**

**_Solenis_**

Founded in 1907 and headquartered in Wilmington, Delaware, Solenis is a leading manufacturer and
distributor of specialty chemicals and solutions for consumer and industrial water intensive industries, including the
pulp, packaging paper and board, tissue and towel, oil and gas, petroleum refining, chemical processing, mining,
biorefining, power and municipal markets. Our product portfolio includes a broad array of water treatment
chemistries, process aids, functional additives as well as state-of-the-art monitoring and control systems. These
technologies are used by customers to improve operational efficiencies, enhance product quality, protect plant assets
and minimize environmental impact.

Solenis has 41 manufacturing facilities strategically located near customers in approximately 19 countries
around the globe to ensure seamless supply continuity and employs a team of more than 5,200 professionals
(including 1,600 field representatives with deep industry knowledge) in 120 countries across five continents. Solenis
has nine labs consisting of R&D centers and Customer Applications Laboratories spanning every region it serves,
aimed at making water work more effectively and more sustainably for its more than 11,000 customers. Key brands
include Zetag™, Kymene™, Hercobond™, Spectrum™, Praestol™, PerForm™ and Percol™.

For the twelve months ended June 30, 2021, Solenis generated Net sales and Adjusted EBITDA of $2.86
billion and $485 million, respectively, reflecting an Adjusted EBITDA margin of 17%. See “—Summary Historical
Financial and Pro Forma Financial Data.”

**_Sigura_**

Headquartered in Alpharetta, Georgia, Sigura (Innovative Water Care Global Corporation, doing business
as Sigura) is a leading supplier of sanitizers and other water treatment solutions featuring top consumer brands in
residential and commercial pool and industrial water care markets. Water care products and value-added services are
offered for residential and commercial pools and spas in consumer channels such as Mass Retail, Professional
Dealer and Commercial, and for Industrial and Municipal Water addressing drinking water, process water,
wastewater, irrigation, surface water and industrial applications. It features top consumer brands in the pool care
market and strong positions in high-growth Industrial & Municipal water markets. Key brands include HTH®,
Poolife®, GLB®, Leisure Time®, Sirona Spa Care®, HTH Spa®, and more.

Sigura maintains six production facilities throughout North America, South America, Europe and South
Africa, with approximately 1,000 employees globally, located in all major regions. Sigura has three manufacturing
facilities that primarily produce calcium hypoclorite (“cal-hypo”) for water treatment and three packaging plants that
produce finished products for sale to customers.

1

**Combined Company Overview**

We believe that the combination of Solenis and Sigura will create a global market leader across all water
intensive industries. We believe that we will be well-positioned to benefit from growing Environmental, Social and
Governance (“ESG”) and macroeconomic mega trends, including around customer sustainability goals and focus
points, such as: water recycle and energy and raw material management, consumer focus on hygiene, environmental
legislation globally, increased levels of shipping and packaging, among others. Together, we will offer a diverse,
comprehensive portfolio of solutions and services, which will limit any obsolescence risk as no product or solution
represents a material part of our business. Our cutting edge technology is at the forefront of the digitization of the
water treatment industry and we have a strong pipeline of new and innovative products that drive significant value
for our customers. We will operate across a diverse set of growing end markets and our broad geographic reach
allows us to meet the needs of our customers globally. Our footprint spans six continents, with both laboratories and
production facilities across North America, LatAm, EMEA, and APAC, where we serve all major developed
markets and are closely integrated with our customers throughout the world. Through our global presence and
differentiated service offering in growing markets, we believe we will be an industry leader in all of our segments.

**Industry Overview**

**_Specialty Chemicals – Consumer_**

The consumer market is comprised of water treatment chemicals and solutions for pulp and paper specific
process applications (e.g., strength additives and sizing agents across wet-end/dry-end of paper process). Based on a
report by a third party expert advisor completed in June 2021, the global consumer market was estimated to be
approximately $8 billion in 2020.

The Packaging market is one of the key market segments within the consumer market that can be broken
into consumer packaging and food packaging. Based on the same report, the consumer packaging market was
estimated to be $2.7 billion in 2020 and is expected to grow at a 3.4% CAGR for the ten-year period 2020 to 2030,
which we believe will be driven primarily from the growth of e-commerce and megatrends in pharmaceuticals and
cosmetics and beauty. Approximately 18% of our pro forma Net sales for the twelve months ended June 30, 2021
was generated from the consumer packaging market. Based on the same report, the food packaging market was
estimated to be $1.8 billion in 2020 and is expected to grow at a 1.9% CAGR for the ten-year period 2020 to 2030,
driven by increased demand for ecofriendly packaging and changing lifestyles centering on more take-away and
individually packed food. We believe the shift away from plastic and the growth in the barrier coating market, which
is not included in the market size estimate, may drive additional growth in food packaging over this period.
Approximately 10% of our pro forma Net sales for the twelve months ended June 30, 2021 was generated from the
food packaging market.

The Graphic & Specialty Paper market has been adversely impacted by the continued substitution of
printed material with electronic media. Reduced use of commercial office spaces in Europe and North America as a
result of COVID-19 is also a negative factor for the sector outlook. The Graphic & Specialty Paper market, based on
the same report, was estimated to be $1.9 billion in 2020 and is expected to decline at a 1.9% CAGR for the ten-year
from 2020 to 2030. However, we have limited exposure to newsprint, which accounts for less than 2% of Consumer
Solutions sales, and we are shifting our focus to higher margin products to offset the expected volume decline in this
market. Approximately 11% of our pro forma Net sales for the twelve months ended June 30, 2021 was generated
from the Graphic & Specialty Paper market.

The Tissue & Towel market is benefiting from strong demographic/socioeconomic trends and increasing
hygiene standards, especially in developing markets. However, stagnating population growth in some mature
markets, and cost-cutting in the public sector and private company spending is expected to limit global market

9


-----

growth. The Tissue & Towel market, based on the same report, was estimated to be $1.2 billion in 2020 and is
expected to grow at a 2.6% CAGR for the ten-year period 2020 to 2030. Approximately 10% of our pro forma Net
sales for the twelve months ended June 30, 2021 was generated from the Tissue & Towel market.

**_Specialty Chemicals — Industrial_**

The industrial market supplies water treatment chemicals and solutions for heavy and light industries and
municipalities (e.g., cooling tower, boiler, influent/effluent, process water). Broadly speaking, the industrial market
consists of core water treatment which includes end markets such as pulp, mining and oil and gas, and wastewater,
which includes end markets such as municipal and industrial wastewater markets.

Based on the same report, the global industrial market was estimated to be approximately $23 billion in
2020 and is expected to grow at a 4.0% CAGR for the five-year period 2020 to 2025. The municipal market is
expected to grow at a 4.3% CAGR for the five-year period from 2020 to 2025, based on the same report, as demand
continues to increase from higher per capita usage of water, population growth and increasing regulatory demands.
The core water treatment market growth is expected to be driven by increasing sustainability and environmental
policies, growing regulatory demands and global industrial growth. This growth is expected to be highest in the food
and beverage market (5.5% CAGR for the five year period from 2020 to 2025, based on the same report) and the
refining and petrochemicals market (4.0% CAGR for the five-year period from 2020 to 2025, based on the same
report).

**_Pool_**

The aftermarket for the residential pool industry is comprised of three main segments: (1) Chemicals, (2)
Equipment, Parts, and Accessories and (3) Services. Our main focus is on the Chemicals segment which is the
largest and most stable component of aftermarket pool spend.

Pool chemicals sales are tied to: (1) the pool installed base and (2) total gallons of treatable water, and not
new builds. The U.S pool installed base has displayed long-term stability as it has consistently grown for decades,
including all years through the housing-led recession and during the COVID-19 pandemic period, which is
providing current tailwinds for the business. However, new builds account for less than 4% of the installed base
annually, meaning that new build rates are unlikely to materially impact our long-term performance.

The Pool Solutions segment also benefits from a stable aftermarket spend that mirrors the steady dynamic
of the installed base. Our chemical-based products result in 100% aftermarket exposure, which reduces our exposure
to cyclical industry trends such as housing starts. Pool chemical use is entirely non-discretionary in that it is a
requirement for owning and using a pool. Pool owners who have already made the significant upfront investment of
constructing a pool, estimated to cost $40,000 to $100,000, will continue to purchase pool chemicals, at the de
minimis annual expense of only $300 to $400 in order to maintain their pools.

Based on data contained in the Pkdata US Residential Swimming Pool Market Report (2020), the market
for chemicals for U.S. residential pools was estimated to be $2.6 billion in 2020. While according to the same
Pkdata report, the market is expected to grow at a 3+% CAGR in the five-year period 2020 – 2025, we believe our
Pool Solutions segment will grow in excess of that as we expand our customer base and increase market share with
new dealer relationships and e-commerce channel.

Many customers are starting to embrace digital technology / data analytics to help track performance and
starting to partner with suppliers with strong R&D capabilities to develop innovative solutions to drive efficiency

_Industrial Solutions_

The global industrial water chemicals market is fragmented, with the top seven players, of which we are
one, covering only approximately 30% of the market, based on a report by a third party expert advisor completed in
June 2021. This is due to the required application-specific expertise and track-record of performance. Hence, by
region and by end-user market, three to five players may have disproportionately high share. We believe we have an
outsized share of the global pulp and paper market, which is one of our larger markets within the Industrial
Solutions segment.

We believe we offer the lowest per unit cost for comparable chemicals compared to our industry peers and
believe that the competitive pricing is our greatest strength in the Industrial Solutions segment. Additionally, we
offer an array of innovative solutions and comprehensive product lines both in core water treatment and wastewater
segment. Notable competitors include Ecolab / Nalco, Suez, ChemTreat, Kurita, Kemira and SNF. Ecolab which
acquired Nalco in 2011 is the largest water treatment player followed by Suez.

Similar to the consumer market, technology and R&D are becoming increasingly important beyond the
chemical product itself as customers are moving towards advanced analytics to optimize the volume of chemical
treatment, driving select industry participants to increasingly focus on equipment / engineering solutions as opposed
to chemical solutions.

_Pool Solutions_

We believe we are the only true global player in the Pool Solutions segment with leading market positions
in North America, South America, and EMEA. Our primary competitor in this segment is KIK Custom Products,
which provides various pool chemical solutions, with a focus on North America. Other smaller competitors also
compete in this market, with varying breadth and geographical focus, including Hasa Pool, Jandy, Lo-chlor and
Jack’s Magic.

We believe we are the world’s largest producer of cal-hypo, a primary chemical used in water treatment
and sanitation. All three of our cal-hypo facilities are co-located with chlor-alkali producers meaning that raw
materials (chlorine and caustic soda) are delivered into our production plants via a direct pipeline. We believe this is
a major competitive advantage and barrier to entry in the Pool Solutions segment as we believe it would not be
economical for our competitors to open a new cal-hypo facility that is not co-located with a supply of raw materials.

**_Sustainability and Environmental and Social Governance_**

We drive sustainability by reducing water and energy use and raw materials waste while improving
operational productivity. Increased focus on sustainability and ESG is a key trend across both Consumer Solutions
and Industrial Solutions segments and is driving demand as our customers aim to reduce water and energy
consumption, optimize raw materials spend and reduce waste emission. These objectives require increased chemical
use which is driving increased demand for our business.

At the micro level, we provide solutions to customers with specific sustainability goals. For example, our
offering of PFAS-free oil and grease resistant technology has been selected by major brand owners as a replacement
in food service bowls. We also made a series of recommendation to a petroleum company which resulted in a
reduction of 162 million gallons of water per year and approximately $45,000 of savings per year on energy and
chemicals. Our management is dedicated to, and focused on, building and marketing our strong ESG reputation,
shifting to green products and providing value-added services to help our customers achieve their sustainability
targets.

Focus on solving customers’ environmental and sustainability challenges has led to notable results for
Solenis. In the twelve months ended September 30, 2020, (1) 84% of innovation projects in the pipeline had
sustainability / circularity focus, (2) 84% of Net sales was driven by projects that support customers’ sustainability
goals, (3) 12% of innovation programs focused on Carbon footprint projects, (4) CO2 emission was reduced by 16%

We are also focused on long term sustainability goals for our business that include: (1) over 50% of raw

every commercial person focusing on reduction in energy, water and raw materials as well as improved productivity
and (7) water consumption to be reduced by 5% from the twelve months ended September 30, 2018 by 2030.

**Summary of Operational Improvements and Synergies Initiatives**

We, along with Platinum, have identified synergies resulting from the combination of Sigura and Solenis.
We expect to achieve an estimated $40 million in annual cost synergies from actions taken within 18 months of the
closing of the Transactions. The synergies are expected to be realized through consolidation of support and sales
functions, materials sourcing and facility consolidation.

  - Approximately $33 million of cost synergies are expected to be achieved through Sigura’s back office
consolidation into Solenis, as well as consolidation of the Sigura industrial sales organization.

  - Approximately $3 million of cost synergies relate to leveraging Solenis’ infrastructure and resources to
better drive Sigura’s direct materials sourcing through spend scaling.

  - Approximately $4 million of cost synergies are attributable to warehouse and distribution center
optimization as well as the consolidation of Sigura’s Alpharetta facility.

To achieve the identified synergies, we expect to incur approximately $28 million of one-time costs. The
majority of these one-time costs are related to implementation support with the balance related to severance and
other integration costs to ensure business continuity.

Additionally, we, along with Platinum, have identified operational improvements at the existing Solenis
business, resulting from plans from management that are currently underway. We expect to achieve an estimated
$72 million in annual cost savings based on actions implemented over the first four years from the closing of the
Transactions. The cost savings are expected to be realized through raw material sourcing capabilities at Solenis,
pricing and mix optimization, shared service and indirect spend optimization, and 4-wall improvement on
controllable costs at existing facilities.

  - Approximately $31 million of cost savings are expected to be achieved through improvement in sourcing
capabilities at Solenis.

  - Approximately $20 million of cost savings relate to driving pricing adherence to above floor pricing and
our ability to shift margin mix away from lower margin business.

  - Approximately $14 million of cost savings are attributable to expanding the scope of share service
organization (India and Poland) while driving savings in indirect spend categories.

  - Approximately $8 million relate to focus on reducing controllable costs at plants and facilities.

To achieve the identified synergies, we expect to incur approximately $25 million of one-time costs. The
majority of these one-time costs are related to implementation support and other costs to ensure business continuity.

**Competitive Strengths**

_Leading Provider in Growing Water Intensive Industrial, Consumer & Pool Markets_

We believe the size of our total addressable market is $39 billion and that the market is relatively
fragmented, with the top six players holding only approximately 40% market share, presenting an opportunity for us
to capture share. Our combined platform will create a scaled leader across all water intensive industries. Based on a
report by a third party expert advisor completed in June 2021, we believe that we have that we have the #1 market
position in the Consumer Solutions segment and are one of the top market players in the highly fragmented
Industrial Solutions segment. Additionally, we believe we are one of two top players in the U.S. pool and spa
chemicals market.

We serve a variety of growing diverse water-intensive end markets, including consumer chemicals
(estimated by a third party expert advisor to grow at 1.8% CAGR for the ten-year period 2020 to 2030), industrial
chemical (estimated by a third party expert advisor to grow at 4.0% CAGR for the five-year period 2020 to 2025),
and pool and spa (estimated by the Pkdata US Residential Swimming Pool Market Report (2020) at 3%+ CAGR).
We have a comprehensive portfolio of solutions including Biocides, Antifoams, Raw and Waste Water treatments,
and Deposit Control, among others for our customers to address their needs in these growing end markets.

_Global Leader with Diverse Sticky Customer Base_

We have a large geographical footprint that enables us to provide global service to our customers. We are
present on six continents, with both laboratories and production facilities, across North America, LatAm, EMEA,
and APAC, where we serve all major developed markets. At Solenis, we have more than 5,200 employees with a
substantial presence across the North America, LatAm, EMEA, and APAC regions. At Sigura, we have a global
footprint in all key pool and water care regions, with approximately 1,000 employees globally across operations and
retail channels. Our strategic global footprint allows us to efficiently and effectively serve customers around the
world by providing consistent products and service.

Our service and technical abilities are mission critical to our customers. Typically our trained value-add
employees, scientists, and service engineers are embedded at customers’ sites, creating strong and long-term
relationships. We represent a lower overall percentage of our customers’ cost base and have been able to achieve
significant value add documented savings for our customers. We are highly engrained in our customers’ workflow,
and it is often difficult, expensive, and potentially disruptive for customers to switch to a competitor. As a result,
more than 95% of Solenis’ Net sales is recurring. Sigura’s Net sales are 90%+ driven by established, branded
products that carry strong customer recognition and loyalty and unique potential in their geographic end markets.
Further, our customer concentration is low with the top five customers representing approximately 13% of pro forma
combined company sales and the top customer represents approximately 4% of Net sales.

_Differentiated Business Model with Best in Class Service, Chemistry, and Technology_

We believe our suite of comprehensive products and services unlocks customer value as a result of our
industry leading employees and innovative technology offerings. Our solutions represent a small portion of our
customers’ overall end costs and provide a significant return on investment. Our differentiated service model, with
over 1,500 of our sales and service engineers on site with our customers, leads to highly recurring, non-discretionary
spending on our products and services, and with our solutions and value propositions including industry leading

We offer innovative chemistries to address customers’ operational and sustainability challenges while our

_Attractive Financial Profile with Strong Top Line Growth, Expanding Margins, and Robust Free Cash Flow_
_Generation_

Our global business has shown strong topline growth, with over 95% of Solenis’ Net sales being recurring

_Long Tenured, Industry leading Management Team with Strong Track Record_

We have an experienced management team with long tenures in the industry and experience in the sector.
Following consummation of the Transactions, the combined company will be led by John E. Panichella, who has
been CEO of Solenis since its inception in 2014, following the initial carve-out from Ashland. Through organic

specialty chemicals for water-intensive industries. Prior to leading Solenis, John served as President of Ashland
Water Technologies, SVP of Ashland, Group Operating Officer of Ashland Specialty Ingredients and Ashland
Water Technologies, and President of Ashland Aqualon Functional ingredients. Surrounding John is a deep bench

(and who will be CFO of the combined Solenis company following the Transactions), Andreas Tuerk, present and
continuing President of the Consumer Solutions business, Edward Connors, present and continuing President of the
Industrial Solutions business, and Robert Baird, current CEO of Sigura (and who will be President of the Pool
Solutions business following the Transactions). Solenis’ experienced team will drive long-term stability of the
combined business and support future growth.

customers to a more profitable mix, driving margin growth. The combination creates unique, value accretive
synergy opportunities, with line of sight on approximately $40 million of cost synergies (resulting from actions
taken within 18 months of the closing of the Transactions) and an additional approximately $72 million of
operational improvement opportunities within the combined Solenis company (based on further actions
implemented over the first four years from the closing of the Transactions). Our new partnership with Diversey will
allow Solenis access to a greater portion of the attractive Food & Beverage market.

We are also well positioned to continue to grow through acquisitions via multiple M&A avenues. We have
a proven track record as an M&A platform, with 11 transactions completed since 2014, including the transformative

**Historical Business Segmentation**

**_Solenis_**

Since the joint venture arrangement with BASF in January 2019, Solenis’ business has principally
consisted of three operating segments: Pulp & Paper, Industrial Water, and Reverse Supply Agreements.

**_Pulp & Paper. The Pulp & Paper (“P&P”) business manufactures and sells a broad array of process_**
chemistry for the pulp and paper industry including deposit and scale control agents, defoamers, biocides, retention
aids and crepe and release additives. These products are designed to deliver benefits such as enhanced operational
efficiencies, system cleanliness and superior performance in a wide variety of manufacturing operations globally.

In addition, the P&P business offers functional chemistry for packaging, tissue and towel, and printing and
writing producers that impart specific properties such as wet or dry strength, colorants, surface size, liquid holdout
and printing ability to the final paper or board. Products and technologies include internal and surface sizing agents
and wet and dry strength additives.

**_Industrial Water. The Industrial Water (“IWT”) business offers specialized chemicals for the utility water_**
treatment market including influent water, boiler water, cooling water and effluent water treatments. Products
include scale and corrosion inhibitors, coagulants and flocculants, biocides, defoamers, anti-scaling for desalination,
membrane treatments and sludge dewatering. In addition, the IWT business offers process additives such as frothers
and collection aids, dust control additives, sterilization treatments, corn oil extraction and scale and corrosion
inhibitors for mining and mineral processing, food processing, oil refining, chemicals processing and general
manufacturing markets.

**_Reverse Supply Agreements. As part of the joint venture with BASF in January 2019, Solenis agreed to_**
provide certain finished goods to BASF, consistent with BASF’s historical cost and pricing structure, intended to
allow BASF to uninterruptedly sustain its retained businesses. These arrangements and related activities comprise
the Reverse Supply Agreements (“RSA”) segment of Solenis. As part of the resegmentation described below, RSA
will become part of the go-forward Industrial Solutions segment.

Solenis also provides automated equipment, including performance-based feed and control systems,
proprietary monitoring devices and remote system surveillance. The utility products, services and equipment
offerings are designed to protect plant assets and optimize energy, water and operational costs at customers’
facilities. As part of the resegmentation described below, equipment destined for packaging mills will become part
of the go-forward Consumer Solutions segment. Equipment provided by refineries will form part of the go-forward
Industrial Solutions segment.

18


-----

**_Sigura_**

Beginning with the quarter ended March 31, 2021, and following the divestiture of its Surface Water
business in October 2020, Sigura moved its commercial pools segment from the previous Industrial, Commercial,
Municipal & Surface Water segment (now known as Industrial & Municipal Water segment) to be consolidated with
residential pool segment under a newly named Pools Solutions segment. Additionally Sigura has a third Other
segment for other operations.

**_Pools._** Sigura’s pool business offers the sale of sanitizers and other treatment chemicals for pools, spas and
water parks. For the twelve months ended June 30, 2021, Sigura’s Pool segment had Net sales of $540 million, of
which 71% was generated in North America, 22% in EMEA and 7% in Latin America.

    - **_Recreational Water. Sigura’s recreational pool and spa care portfolio brings clean, healthy water to_**
households worldwide with a variety of shock, sanitizers, oxidizers, algaecides and balancers. Sigura’s
trusted brands ensure clean and healthy water for its customers’ and consumers’ pools and spas across
seasons.

    - **_Commercial Pools & Spas. Sigura’s commercial pool brands have been at the cutting edge of_**
swimming pool water treatment for over 30 years. Its chlorination solutions are used worldwide for
amusement parks, community pools, hotels, resorts, and professional training venues. Sigura
specializes in powerful sanitizers, coagulants and pool maintenance products in order to deliver water
clarity, color and sparkle to customers’ pools, while ensuring the highest level of water quality, and
Sigura’s range of automated feed systems make such professional pool treatment easy to achieve.

**_Industrial & Municipal Water._** Sigura’s Industrial & Municipal Water segment offers treatment of water
for drinking, agriculture, irrigation, food processing and industrial applications. For the twelve months ended June
30, 2021, Sigura’s Industrial & Municipal Water segment had Net Sales of $63 million, of which 43% was
generated in North America, 43% in EMEA and 14% in Latin America.

      - **_Industrial Water. Sigura’s Industrial segment (56% of twelve month ended June 30, 2021 total_**
segment sales) is a leading specialty chemical supplier to the global water treatment market and is
also a specialty chemical manufacturer. Sigura offers oxidizing and non-oxidizing biocides,
feeders and dosing equipment to customers for use in power plants, cooling cycles, food and
beverage and the paper industry. The combination of innovative technologies, patented solid
biocide feed systems and thorough application knowledge allows Sigura to deliver leading edge
solutions to its customers’ most demanding problems.

      - **_Municipal Water. Sigura’s Municipal segment (44% of twelve month ended June 30, 2021 total_**
segment sales) is focused on helping provide access to clean drinking water and safe water
supplies, which is fundamental to human health. Sigura’s global team of drinking water experts
provide easy to use, modular, chlorination systems, designed to solve each locations’ unique
operational requirements.

**Combined Solenis Company Business Resegmentation**

Following a strategic review related to Solenis’ operating segments and in anticipation of the closing of the
Acquisition and the Reorganization, changes will be introduced in the segment reporting from October 1, 2021. To
ensure comparability, Solenis has prepared condensed segment reporting presented on the basis of the new business
segmentation (i) for the three months ended June 30, 2021 compared to the three months ended June 30, 2020 and
(ii) for the nine months ended June 30, 2021 compared to the nine months ended June 30, 2020. See “Management’s
Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations of Solenis—Segment Results.”

The segmentation changes are being made for the following reasons: (i) alignment of the segment structure
to ensure that the combined Solenis company’s financial reporting segments are in line with its strategic approach in

19


-----

demarcating its operations and (ii) in order to most effectively manage the combined Solenis company and make
business decisions based on product lines and services.

Major changes relate to: (i) the creation of a new Pool Solutions segment to account for the contribution of
Sigura’s Pools segment, focused on delivering products for the treatment of pools, spas and water parks, (ii) the
renaming of the Pulp & Paper business as the Consumer Solutions business, (iii) the renaming of the Industrial
Water business as the Industrial Solutions business, (iv) the reallocation of the food processing aspects of the
business from the newly named Industrial Solutions business to sit with the other consumer-based products and
services within the newly named Consumer Solutions business, (v) the reallocation of the pulp processing aspects of
the business from the newly named Consumer Solutions business to sit with the other industrial-focused products
and services within the newly named Industrial Solutions segment, (vi) the contribution of Sigura’s Industrial &
Municipal Water business to the newly named Industrial Solutions segment and (vii) the inclusion of Solenis’ RSA
business within the newly named Industrial Solutions segment.

**_Consumer Solutions._** The Pulp & Paper segment of the historical Solenis business will be renamed the
Consumer Solutions segment of the combined Solenis company. The Consumer Solutions segment is mostly
affected by the removal of Pulp and its reallocation to the Industrial Water segment (now renamed the Industrial
Solutions segment).

**_Industrial Solutions._** The Industrial Water segment of the historical Solenis business will be renamed the
Industrial Solutions segment of the combined Solenis company. The Industrial Solutions business is mostly affected
by the inclusion of the RSA segment, the removal of Food and its reallocation to the Pulp & Paper segment (now
renamed the Consumer Solutions segment) and the contribution of Sigura’s Industrial, & Municipal business.

**_Pool Solutions._** Sigura’s Pool segment, including residential and commercial pools, will form the new Pool
Solutions business segment of the combined Solenis company.

**The Transactions**

**The Acquisition and Reorganization**

In July 2014, Solenis (formerly named Ashland Water Technologies (“AWT”)) was acquired by Clayton,
Dubilier & Rice, LLC (“CD&R”) from Ashland Inc. (“Ashland”). In January 2019, as part of a joint venture
arrangement, Solenis merged with the paper and water chemicals business of BASF SE (“BASF”), a Germany-based
chemical manufacturer and distributor, creating a solutions provider for the pulp and paper and water treatment
industries, owned 49.5% by CD&R, 49% by BASF and 1.5% by members of the joint venture management team.

On July 3, 2021, the Sellers, Solenis UK International and Parent entered into the Acquisition Agreement
(which was amended and restated on September 4, 2021), pursuant to which the Solenis business will be acquired by
Parent through the acquisition, by the subsidiaries of Parent, of the Solenis group companies identified in the
Acquisition Agreement as the companies to be acquired pursuant to the Alternative Transaction Structure (as
defined therein), for an aggregate purchase price equal to $5.25 billion, subject to certain adjustments related to
retained capital leases, pension and other liabilities, tax adjustments and other fees. As part of the Acquisition, it is
intended that Solenis Technologies Mexico, S. de R.L. de C.V. (“Solenis Mexico”) will be acquired and form part of
the combined company. Affiliates of the Issuer have applied for antitrust approval in Mexico in relation to the
acquisition of Solenis Mexico (“Mexican Approval”). If Mexican Approval is obtained on or prior to the Acquisition
Closing Date, it is expected that Solenis Mexico will be acquired on the Acquisition Closing Date. If Mexican
Approval is not obtained by the Acquisition Closing Date, we may agree to initially acquire the combined company
without Solenis Mexico and delay the acquisition of Solenis Mexico until Mexican Approval is obtained. Solenis
Mexico represented approximately 2.9% of our Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA for the twelve months
ended June 30, 2021.

We expect the purchase price for the Acquisition will be financed through:

      - borrowings under the New Credit Facilities;

20


-----

      - proceeds of the Notes offered hereby; and

      - the Equity Investment.

For a detailed discussion of the expected sources and uses of funds for the Transactions, see “Use of
Proceeds,” “Capitalization,” “Certain Relationships and Related Party Transactions,” “Description of New Credit
Facilities and Other Indebtedness,” “Description of Unsecured Notes” and “Description of Secured Notes.”

The consummation of the Acquisition is subject to various closing conditions, including, among others, (i)
the receipt of certain required regulatory approvals or lapse of certain review periods with respect thereto, (ii) the
absence of a material adverse effect on the business, assets, liabilities, results of operations or financial condition of
Solenis and its subsidiaries, (iii) the accuracy of representations and warranties (subject to certain materiality
qualifiers), (iv) material compliance with covenants contained in the Acquisition Agreement and (v) the absence of
any law or order (U.S. or foreign) making illegal the consummation of the Acquisition. We currently expect to
receive final approvals and for the consummation of the Acquisition to occur in the third calendar quarter of 2021.
However, there can be no guarantee that we will receive the requisite approvals within this time frame or at all.
Pursuant to the terms of the Acquisition Agreement, the Acquisition is expected to close two (2) business days after
all of the requisite closing conditions have been satisfied or waived, unless otherwise agreed.

The Acquisition Agreement contains certain termination rights of the Sellers and Parent, including the right
to terminate if the Acquisition has not been consummated by the Acquisition Outside Date. The Acquisition
Agreement also contains customary representations, warranties and covenants. The representations and warranties
do not survive the consummation of the Acquisition, and we therefore will have no post-closing contractual
indemnification from the Sellers for any breaches of representations or warranties. Parent intends to purchase
representation and warranty insurance to mitigate some of this risk.

Concurrently with the Acquisition, pursuant to a transaction agreement, dated as of July 3, 2021 (the
“Transaction Agreement”), Platinum and certain of its affiliates will, following the closing of the transactions
contemplated by the Acquisition Agreement, contribute to Olympus Water Holdings I, L.P., a Cayman Islands
exempted limited partnership, all of the shares of common stock of IWC Holding Corporation, a Delaware
corporation, which represent all of the issued and outstanding capital stock of IWC Holding Corporation, in
exchange for newly issued units in Olympus Water Holding I, L.P., having a value equal to the contributed shares of
IWC Holding Corporation, which we expect will, through a series of transactions, ultimately be contributed to each
of Olympus Water Holding II, L.P., and to Olympus Water Holding III, L.P., and to Olympus Water Holding IV,
L.P. and to the Issuer, with the result that IWC Holding Corporation will be held as a subsidiary of the Issuer. The
Reorganization implies a rollover of existing equity interests of the Sponsor and certain of its affiliates in Sigura of
$500 million. See “—Sources and Uses.”

**The Offering, Escrow and Escrow Release**

This offering may close concurrently with the consummation of the Acquisition. If this offering closes
prior to the consummation of the Acquisition, the Issuer will deposit (or cause to be deposited) the gross proceeds
from the sale of each series of Notes into separate segregated escrow accounts pursuant to the Escrow Agreement.
At such time and until the Escrow Release Conditions are satisfied, each series of Notes will be secured by a firstpriority security interest in the applicable escrow account and the deposits and investments therein. The Escrow
Release will be subject to the Escrow Release Conditions. Assuming the Escrow Release Conditions have been
satisfied, on the Acquisition Closing Date, the Guarantors will become parties to the Indentures pursuant to one or
more supplemental indentures, and the obligations will become obligations of the Guarantors.

The escrowed funds will be released from escrow to consummate the Acquisition even if a default or event
of default has occurred and is continuing under the Indentures. See “Risk Factors—Risks Related to the Notes and
Our Indebtedness—If the Acquisition is completed on or prior to the Outside Date and the Escrow Release
Conditions are satisfied, the proceeds from the Notes will be released from escrow even if a default or event of
default under the Indentures has or would have occurred and is continuing.”

21


-----

In the event that (a) the Acquisition is not consummated on or prior to the Outside Date, (b) at any time
prior to the Outside Date, the Escrow Release Conditions are deemed, in the Issuer’s good faith judgment, to be
incapable of being satisfied on or prior to the Outside Date or (c) at any time prior to the Acquisition Outside Date,
the Acquisition Agreement is terminated in accordance with its terms without the closing of the Acquisition, each
series of Notes will be subject to a special mandatory redemption at a price equal to 100% of the initial issue price of
such series of Notes, plus accrued and unpaid interest from the Issue Date, to, but excluding, the date of such special
mandatory redemption. See “Risk Factors—Risks Related to the Notes and Our Indebtedness—In the event that the
Acquisition is not consummated on or prior to the Outside Date or upon the occurrence of certain other events, the
Notes will be subject to a special mandatory redemption, and, as a result, you may not obtain the return you expect
on the applicable series of Notes.”

If this offering closes substantially concurrently with the consummation of the Acquisition, the Notes will
not be subject to the escrow procedures described in this offering memorandum.

For additional information regarding the terms of, and procedures relating to, the escrow, see “Description
of Unsecured Notes—Escrow of Proceeds; Special Mandatory Redemption” and “Description of Secured Notes—
Escrow of Proceeds; Special Mandatory Redemption.”

**The Refinancing**

Concurrently with the closing of the Acquisition and the Reorganization and, if applicable, the satisfaction
of the Escrow Release Conditions, we will consummate the Refinancing using the proceeds from the Notes, the
Equity Investment and the New Credit Facilities.

**The New Credit Facilities**

Concurrently with the closing of the Acquisition and, if applicable, the satisfaction of the Escrow Release
Conditions, the Issuer and the Guarantors will enter into the New Term Loan Credit Agreement providing for the
New Term Loan Facility and will enter into the New ABL Credit Agreement providing for the New ABL Revolving
Credit Facility. See “Description of New Credit Facilities and Other Indebtedness.”

**Equity Investment**

As part of the Acquisition, the Sponsor will fund the Equity Investment of approximately $1,993 million in
cash to an indirect parent of Parent, which we expect will, through a series of transactions, ultimately be contributed
to each of the Issuer and to Olympus Water UK Holdings Ltd as common equity, and which will be used as part of
the consideration to be paid in connection with the Acquisition.

**Our Sponsor**

The Issuer is a corporation recently formed under the laws of the state of Delaware exclusively for purposes
of affecting the Acquisition and the Reorganization and this offering. Founded in 1995 by Tom Gores, Platinum is a
global investment firm with more than $25 billion of assets under management and a portfolio of approximately 50
operating companies that serve customers around the world. The firm is currently investing from Platinum Equity
Capital Partners V, a $10 billion global buyout fund, and Platinum Equity Small Cap Fund, a $1.5 billion buyout
fund focused on investment opportunities in the lower middle market. Platinum specializes in mergers, acquisitions
and operations—a trademarked strategy it calls M&A&O®—acquiring and operating companies in a broad range of
business markets, including manufacturing, distribution, transportation and logistics, equipment rental, metals
services, media and entertainment, technology, telecommunications and other industries. Over the past 26 years,
Platinum has completed more than 300 acquisitions.

**Unsecured Notes ......................** If this offering closes prior to the consummation of the Acquisition and
prior to the satisfaction of the Escrow Release Conditions, the Unsecured
Notes will be obligations solely of the Issuer, secured by a first-priority
security interest in the applicable escrow account and the deposits and
investments therein. From and after satisfaction of the Escrow Release
Conditions, or on the Issue Date if the Acquisition close concurrently with
this offering, the Unsecured Notes and the related guarantees will be
general, senior unsecured obligations of the Issuer and the Guarantors.

**Intercreditor Agreements ............** The liens on the Collateral securing the Secured Notes will be subject
initially to two separate intercreditor agreements. On the Acquisition
Closing Date, the Notes Collateral Agent and the collateral agent under our
New Term Loan Credit Agreement (the “Term Loan Collateral Agent”)
will enter into an intercreditor agreement (the “Pari Passu Intercreditor
Agreement ”) to set forth the relative rights of, and relationship among, the
Notes Collateral Agent, the holders of the Secured Notes, the Term Loan
Collateral Agent and the lenders under our New Term Loan Credit
Agreement and the applicable representative of the holders under any other
future parity lien indebtedness in respect of the exercise of rights and
remedies against the Issuer and the Guarantors. In addition, on the
Acquisition Closing Date, the Notes Collateral Agent, the Term Loan
Collateral Agent and the collateral agent under our New ABL Revolving
Credit Facility (the “ABL Collateral Agent”) will enter into an intercreditor
agreement (the “ABL Intercreditor Agreement” and, together with the Pari
Passu Intercreditor Agreement, the “Intercreditor Agreements”) to set forth
the relative priorities of the liens on the Collateral securing the Secured
Notes offered hereby and our New Term Loan Facility and other future
parity lien indebtedness, on the one hand, and our New ABL Revolving
Credit Facility (or any replacement facility) and other future indebtedness
that is pari lien with the New ABL Revolving Credit Facility, on the other
hand, and the relative rights of such parties to enforce such liens. See
“Description of Secured Notes—Security—Intercreditor Arrangements.”

**Ranking:**

**Secured Notes ...........................** From and after satisfaction of the Escrow Release Conditions, or on the
Issue Date immediately following the Acquisition if the Acquisition closes
concurrently with this offering, the Secured Notes and the related
guarantees will be general, senior secured obligations of the Issuer and the
Guarantors and will:

                   - be secured on a first-priority basis, equally and ratably with all
parity lien indebtedness of the Issuer and the Guarantors (including
our New Term Loan Facility), by security interests in all of the
Fixed Asset Collateral, subject to certain limitations and
exceptions and permitted liens;

                   - be secured on a second-priority basis, equally and ratably with all
parity lien indebtedness of the Issuer and the Guarantors (including
our New Term Loan Facility), by security interests in all of the
Current Asset Collateral, subject to certain limitations and

29


-----

exceptions and permitted liens (including liens on the Current
Asset Collateral securing our New ABL Revolving Credit
Facility);

                   - rank contractually senior in right of payment to all of the Issuer’s
and the Guarantors’ subordinated indebtedness;

                   - be effectively senior to any of the Issuer’s and the Guarantors’
unsecured indebtedness (including the Unsecured Notes) and
indebtedness secured by liens junior to the liens securing the
Secured Notes (including, in the case of the Fixed Asset Collateral,
our New ABL Revolving Credit Facility), in each case, to the
extent of the value of the Collateral;

                   - be effectively subordinated to any of the Issuer’s and the
Guarantors’ indebtedness that is secured by a senior-priority lien,
including our New ABL Revolving Credit Facility, to the extent of
the value of the Current Asset Collateral;

                   - without giving effect to collateral arrangements, rank pari passu in
right of payment with all of the Issuer’s and the Guarantors’ senior
indebtedness, including our New Term Loan Facility;

                   - be effectively equal to all of the Issuer’s and the Guarantors’
senior indebtedness secured on the same priority basis as the
Notes, including the New Term Loan Facility;

                   - be effectively subordinated to any of the Issuer’s and the
Guarantors’ indebtedness that is secured by assets that do not
constitute Collateral to the extent of the value of the assets
securing such indebtedness; and

                   - be structurally subordinated to the liabilities of any non-Guarantor
subsidiaries.

**Unsecured Notes ......................** From and after satisfaction of the Escrow Release Conditions, or on the
Issue Date immediately following the Acquisition if the Acquisition closes
concurrently with this offering, the Unsecured Notes and the related

the Guarantors and will:

                   - rank contractually senior in right of payment to all of the Issuer’s
and the Guarantors’ subordinated indebtedness;

                   - without giving effect to collateral arrangements, rank pari passu in
right of payment with all of the Issuer’s and the Guarantors’ senior
indebtedness, including our New Credit Facilities and the Secured
Notes offered hereby;

                   - be effectively subordinated to any secured indebtedness of the
Issuer and the Guarantors, including our New Credit Facilities, the
Secured Notes offered hereby and capital leases, if any, to the
extent of the value of the assets securing such indebtedness; and

**Escrow of Proceeds; Special**
**Mandatory Redemption ...............** This offering may close concurrently with the consummation of the
Acquisition. If this offering closes prior to the consummation of the
Acquisition, the Issuer will deposit (or cause to be deposited) the gross
proceeds from the sale of each series of Notes into separate segregated
escrow accounts pursuant to the Escrow Agreement. At such time and until
the Escrow Release Conditions are satisfied, each series of Notes will be
secured by a first-priority security interest in the applicable escrow account
and the deposits and investments therein. The Escrow Release will be
subject to the Escrow Release Conditions. Assuming the Escrow Release
Conditions have been satisfied, on the Acquisition Closing Date, the
Guarantors will become parties to the Indentures pursuant to one or more
supplemental indentures, and the obligations will become obligations of the
Guarantors. The escrowed funds will be released from escrow to
consummate the Acquisition even if a default or event of default has
occurred and is continuing under the Indentures. See “Risk Factors—Risks
Related to the Notes and Our Indebtedness—If the Acquisition is
completed on or prior to the Outside Date and the Escrow Release
Conditions are satisfied, the proceeds from the Notes will be released from
escrow even if a default or event of default under the Indentures has or
would have occurred and is continuing.”

In the event that (a) the Acquisition is not consummated on or prior to the
Outside Date, (b) at any time prior to the Outside Date, the Escrow Release
Conditions are deemed, in the Issuer’s good faith judgment, to be incapable
of being satisfied on or prior to the Outside Date or (c) at any time prior to
the Acquisition Outside Date, the Acquisition Agreement is terminated in
accordance with its terms without the closing of the Acquisition, each
series of Notes will be subject to a special mandatory redemption at a price
equal to 100% of the initial issue price of such series of Notes, plus accrued
and unpaid interest from the Issue Date, to, but excluding, the date of such
special mandatory redemption. See “Risk Factors—Risks Related to the
Notes and Our Indebtedness— In the event that the Acquisition is not
consummated on or prior to the Outside Date or upon the occurrence of
certain other events, the Notes will be subject to a special mandatory
redemption, and, as a result, you may not obtain the return you expect on
the applicable series of Notes.”

If this offering closes substantially concurrently with the consummation of
the Acquisition, the Notes will not be subject to the escrow procedures
described in this offering memorandum.

For additional information regarding the terms of, and procedures relating
to, the escrow, see “Description of Unsecured Notes—Escrow of Proceeds;
Special Mandatory Redemption” and “Description of Secured Notes—
Escrow of Proceeds; Special Mandatory Redemption.”

**Covenants ......................................** The Issuer will issue the Secured Notes under the Secured Notes Indenture
and the Unsecured Notes under the Unsecured Notes Indenture. The
Indentures will, among other things, limit the ability of Parent and its
restricted subsidiaries to:

                   - incur additional indebtedness and guarantee indebtedness;

                   - pay dividends or make other distributions in respect of, or
repurchase or redeem, its capital stock;

                   - prepay, redeem or repurchase certain debt;

                   - issue certain preferred stock or similar equity securities;

                   - make loans and investments;

                   - sell assets;

                   - incur liens;

                   - enter into agreements containing prohibitions affecting its
subsidiaries’ ability to pay dividends;

                   - enter into transactions with affiliates; and

-----

                   - consolidate, merge or sell all or substantially all of its assets.

These covenants will be subject to a number of important exceptions and
qualifications. For more details, see “Description of Unsecured Notes—
Certain Covenants” and “Description of Secured Notes—Certain
Covenants.”

Certain covenants will cease to apply to the Notes if, and for so long as, the
Notes have investment grade ratings from certain rating agencies and there
is no default or event of default under the Indenture. See “Description of
Unsecured Notes—Certain Covenants—Changes in Covenants When
Unsecured Notes Rated Investment Grade” and “Description of Secured
Notes—Certain Covenants—Changes in Covenants When Secured Notes
Rated Investment Grade.”

**Transfer Restrictions ....................** The Issuer has not registered the Notes under the Securities Act, and the
Notes are subject to restrictions on transferability and resale. The Issuer
does not intend to issue registered notes under the Securities Act or any
state or other securities laws in exchange for the Notes to be privately
placed in this offering, and the absence of registration rights may adversely
impact the transferability of the Notes. For more information, see “Transfer
Restrictions.”

**Absence of Public Market for the**
**Notes ...........................................** Each series of Notes will be a new issue of securities and there is currently
no established trading market for either series of Notes. We cannot assure
you that an active trading market for the Notes will develop and continue
after this offering.

The Issuer does not intend to apply for a listing of the Dollar Notes on any
securities exchange or automated quotation system.

The Issuer intends to apply to list each series of Euro Notes on the
Exchange following the consummation of this offering. There is no
assurance that the Euro Notes will be listed and admitted to trading on the
Exchange, and if listed and admitted to trading, there is no assurance that
the listing of the Euro Notes will be maintained. Consummation of the
offering of the Euro Notes is not contingent on the Issuer making an
application or obtaining such listing or admission to trading. There can be
no assurance as to the development or liquidity of any market for any series
of Notes.

Certain of the initial purchasers have advised the Issuer that they currently
intend to make a market in the Notes. However, they are not obligated to do
so, and any market making with respect to the Notes may be discontinued
without notice.

**Form and Denomination ..............** The Dollar Secured Notes and the Dollar Unsecured Notes will be issued in
registered form in minimum denominations of $200,000 and in integral
multiples of $1,000 in excess thereof maintained in book-entry form, and
the Euro Secured Notes and Euro Unsecured Notes will be issued in
minimum denominations of €100,000 and in integral multiples of €1,000 in
excess thereof maintained in book-entry form.
