**NOTES TO UNAUDITED PRO FORMA CONDENSED COMBINED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS**

**Note 1 — Description of the Transactions**

**Acquisition**

On July 3, 2021, the Sellers, Solenis UK International and Parent entered into the Acquisition
Agreement, pursuant to which the Solenis business will be acquired by Parent through the acquisition, by the
subsidiaries of Parent, of the Solenis group companies identified in the Acquisition Agreement as the companies
to be acquired pursuant to the Alternative Transaction Structure (as defined therein), for an aggregate purchase
price equal to $5.25 billion, subject to certain adjustments related to retained capital leases, pension and other
liabilities, tax adjustments and other fees.

We expect the purchase price for the Acquisition will be financed through:

       - borrowings under the New Credit Facilities;

97


-----

      - proceeds of the Notes offered hereby; and

      - the Equity Investment.

For a detailed discussion of the expected sources and uses of funds for the Transactions, see “Use of
Proceeds,” “Capitalization,” “Certain Relationships and Related Party Transactions,” “Description of New
Credit Facilities and Other Indebtedness,” “Description of Unsecured Notes” and “Description of Secured
Notes.”

The consummation of the Acquisition is subject to various closing conditions, including, among others,
(i) the receipt of certain required regulatory approvals or lapse of certain review periods with respect thereto, (ii)
the absence of a material adverse effect on the business, assets, liabilities, results of operations or financial
condition of Solenis and its subsidiaries, (iii) the accuracy of representations and warranties (subject to certain
materiality qualifiers), (iv) material compliance with covenants contained in the Acquisition Agreement and (v)
the absence of any law or order (U.S. or foreign) making illegal the consummation of the Acquisition. We
currently expect to receive final approvals and for the consummation of the Acquisition to occur in the third
calendar quarter of 2021. However, there can be no guarantee that we will receive the requisite approvals within
this time frame or at all. Pursuant to the terms of the Acquisition Agreement, the Acquisition is expected to close
two (2) business days after all of the requisite closing conditions have been satisfied or waived, unless otherwise
agreed.

The Acquisition Agreement contains certain termination rights of the Sellers and Parent, including the
right to terminate if the Acquisition has not been consummated by the Acquisition Outside Date. The
Acquisition Agreement also contains customary representations, warranties and covenants. The representations
and warranties do not survive the consummation of the Acquisition, and we therefore will have no post-closing
contractual indemnification from the Sellers for any breaches of representations or warranties. Parent intends to
purchase representation and warranty insurance to mitigate some of this risk.

Concurrently with the Acquisition, pursuant to a transaction agreement, dated as of July 3, 2021 (the
“Transaction Agreement”), Platinum and certain of its affiliates will, following the closing of the transactions
contemplated by the Acquisition Agreement, contribute to Olympus Water Holdings I, L.P., a Cayman Islands
exempted limited partnership, all of the shares of common stock of IWC Holding Corporation, a Delaware
corporation, which represent all of the issued and outstanding capital stock of IWC Holding Corporation, in
exchange for newly issued units in Olympus Water Holding I, L.P., having a value equal to the contributed
shares of IWC Holding Corporation, which we expect will, through a series of transactions, ultimately be
contributed to each of Olympus Water Holding II, L.P., and to Olympus Water Holding III, L.P., and to
Olympus Water Holding IV, L.P. and to the Issuer, with the result that IWC Holding Corporation will be held as
a subsidiary of the Issuer. The Reorganization implies a rollover of existing equity interests of the Sponsor and
certain of its affiliates in Sigura of $500 million. See “Use of Proceeds.”

**The Offering, Escrow and Escrow Release**

This offering may close concurrently with the consummation of the Acquisition. If this offering closes
prior to the consummation of the Acquisition, the Issuer will deposit (or cause to be deposited) the gross
proceeds from the sale of each series of Notes into separate segregated escrow accounts pursuant to the Escrow
Agreement. At such time and until the Escrow Release Conditions are satisfied, each series of Notes will be
secured by a first-priority security interest in the applicable escrow account and the deposits and investments
therein. The Escrow Release will be subject to the Escrow Release Conditions. Assuming the Escrow Release
Conditions have been satisfied, on the Acquisition Closing Date, the Guarantors will become parties to the
Indentures pursuant to one or more supplemental indentures, and the obligations will become obligations of the
Guarantors.

The escrowed funds will be released from escrow to consummate the Acquisition even if a default or
event of default has occurred and is continuing under the Indentures. See “Risk Factors—Risks Related to the
Notes and Our Indebtedness—If the Acquisition is completed on or prior to the Outside Date and the Escrow

98


-----

Release Conditions are satisfied, the proceeds from the Notes will be released from escrow even if a default or
event of default under the Indentures has or would have occurred and is continuing.”

In the event that (a) the Acquisition is not consummated on or prior to the Outside Date, (b) at any time
prior to the Outside Date, the Escrow Release Conditions are deemed, in the Issuer’s good faith judgment, to be
incapable of being satisfied on or prior to the Outside Date or (c) at any time prior to the Acquisition Outside
Date, the Acquisition Agreement is terminated in accordance with its terms without the closing of the
Acquisition, each series of Notes will be subject to a special mandatory redemption at a price equal to 100% of
the initial issue price of such series of Notes, plus accrued and unpaid interest from the Issue Date, to, but
excluding, the date of such special mandatory redemption. See “Risk Factors—Risks Related to the Notes and
Our Indebtedness—In the event that the Acquisition is not consummated on or prior to the Outside Date or upon
the occurrence of certain other events, the Notes will be subject to a special mandatory redemption, and, as a
result, you may not obtain the return you expect on the applicable series of Notes.” The escrowed funds will be
limited to the gross proceeds from this offering of the Notes, together with any earnings thereon and investments
thereof, if any, and will not include cash to fund any accrued and unpaid interest on the Notes that may be
payable in the event of a special mandatory redemption. An affiliate of Platinum will issue the Equity
Commitment Letter to the Issuer, for the benefit of the Trustee, the Escrow Agent and the holders of the Notes,
to transfer to the Issuer an amount necessary to fund the payment of accrued and unpaid interest on the Notes in
the event of a special mandatory redemption, plus certain fees and expenses.

If this offering closes substantially concurrently with the consummation of the Acquisition, the Notes
will not be subject to the escrow procedures described in this offering memorandum.

For additional information regarding the terms of, and procedures relating to, the escrow, see
“Description of Unsecured Notes—Escrow of Proceeds; Special Mandatory Redemption” and “Description of
Secured Notes—Escrow of Proceeds; Special Mandatory Redemption.”

**The Refinancing**

Concurrently with the closing of the Acquisition and the Reorganization and, if applicable, the
satisfaction of the Escrow Release Conditions, we will consummate the Refinancing using the proceeds from the
Notes, the Equity Investment and the New Credit Facilities.

**The New Credit Facilities**

Concurrently with the closing of the Acquisition and, if applicable, the satisfaction of the Escrow
Release Conditions, the Issuer and the Guarantors will enter into the New Term Loan Credit Agreement
providing for the New Term Loan Facility and will enter into the New ABL Credit Agreement providing for the
New ABL Revolving Credit Facility. See “Description of New Credit Facilities and Other Indebtedness.”

**Equity Investment**

As part of the Acquisition, the Sponsor will fund the Equity Investment of approximately $1,993
million in cash to an indirect parent of Parent, which we expect will, through a series of transactions, ultimately
be contributed to each of the Issuer and Olympus Water UK Holdings Ltd as common equity, and which will be
used as part of the consideration to be paid in connection with the Acquisition.

**Note 2 — Basis of Presentation**

The Unaudited Pro Forma Condensed Consolidated Financial Information was prepared using the
acquisition method of accounting in accordance with Accounting Standards Codification (“ASC”) Topic 805,
Business Combinations (“ASC 805”), and using the fair value concepts defined in ASC Topic 820, Fair Value
Measurement (“ASC 820”) and based on the historical consolidated financial statements of Solenis and Sigura.
Under ASC 805, all Solenis assets acquired and liabilities assumed in a business combination are recognized and
measured at their assumed acquisition date fair value, while transaction costs and restructuring costs associated

99


-----

with the business combination are expensed as incurred. The excess of merger consideration over the fair value
of assets acquired and liabilities assumed, if any, is allocated to goodwill.

The Transaction did not meet the definition under ASC 805 as a Business Combination for the Sigura
business but rather Transactions Between Entities Under Common Control (ASC 805-50). Under ASC 805-50
all Sigura assets acquired and liabilities assumed are recognized and measured at their historical carrying
amounts.

The allocation of the purchase consideration for the Acquisition depends upon certain estimates and
assumptions, all of which are preliminary. The allocation of the purchase consideration has been made for the
purpose of developing the Unaudited Pro Forma Condensed Consolidated Financial Information. A final
determination of fair values of assets acquired and liabilities assumed relating to the Acquisition could differ
materially from the preliminary allocation of the purchase consideration. This final valuation will be based on
the actual net tangible and intangible assets of Solenis and Sigura existing at the acquisition date. Pursuant to the
terms of the Acquisition Agreement, the Acquisition is expected to close the month in which all the requisite
closing conditions have been satisfied. The final valuation may materially change the allocation of the purchase
consideration, which could materially affect the fair values assigned to the assets and liabilities and could result
in a material change to the Unaudited Pro Forma Condensed Consolidated Financial Information.

The transaction accounting adjustments represent management’s best estimates and are based upon
currently available information and certain assumptions that management believes are reasonable under the
circumstances.

The Unaudited Pro Forma Condensed Consolidated Financial Information presented is for illustrative
purposes only and is not necessarily indicative of the financial position or results of operations that would have
been realized if the Acquisition had been completed on the dates indicated, nor is it indicative of future
operating results or financial position.

We have undertaken a preliminary review of both Solenis’ and Sigura’s accounting policies and did not
identify any significant adjustments that would be required to be made in order to conform the accounting
policies of the companies. Solenis has not adopted the new revenue recognition accounting standard as part of
the Unaudited Pro Forma Condensed Consolidated Financial Information. We do not expect that the adoption of
the new revenue recognition accounting standard would have a material impact.

**Overview**

Solenis is a leading manufacturer and distributor of specialty chemicals and solutions for consumer and
industrial water intensive industries, including the pulp, packaging paper and board, tissue and towel, oil and gas,
petroleum refining, chemical processing, mining, biorefining, power and municipal markets. Our product portfolio
includes a broad array of water treatment chemistries, process aids, functional additives as well as state-of-the-art
monitoring and control systems. These technologies are used by customers to improve operational efficiencies,
enhance product quality, protect plant assets and minimize environmental impact.

Founded in 1907 and headquartered in Wilmington, Delaware, in July 2014, Solenis (formerly named
Ashland Water Technologies (“AWT”)) was acquired by Clayton, Dubilier & Rice, LLC (“CD&R”) from Ashland
Inc. (“Ashland”). In January 2019, as part of a joint venture arrangement (the “JV”), Solenis merged with the paper
and water chemicals business of BASF SE (“BASF”), a Germany-based chemical manufacturer and distributor,
creating a solutions provider for the pulp and paper and water treatment industries, owned 49.5% by CD&R, 49% by
BASF and 1.5% by members of the joint venture management team.

**Factors Affecting Our Operating Results**

The following discussion sets forth certain components of our statements of operation as well as factors
that impact those items:

**_Net sales_**

We generate revenue from the sale of products and services within each of the four geographic markets that
we serve. Our Net sales represents gross revenue net of estimates for returns and price allowances. Price allowances

107


-----

are inclusive of discounts for prompt payment, customer specific rebates, continuous improvement rebates, and
other volume based incentives. Our overall Net sales are impacted by the following factors:

      - Fluctuations in overall economic activity within the geographic markets that we serve;

      - Fluctuations in foreign exchange rates;

      - Changes in the prices charged for products and services;

      - Changes in the overall volume of customers served based on underlying fluctuations in supply and
demand;

      - Changes in the level of competition in the marketplace, either via price, or the launch of new products
by competitors;

      - Changes in the application or applied usage of our products and services; and

      - Sales and amortization of reverse supply agreements acquired as part of the acquisition of BASF.

**_Cost of sales_**

Our Cost of sales consists primarily of the following:

      - _Materials and production costs: We purchase raw materials from a global network of suppliers to_
support the production of finished products and the delivery of services;

      - _Employee Costs: To retain the talent necessary to deliver high-quality products and services, we incur_
significant employee compensation and benefits costs. Payroll costs recognized via Cost of sales relate
specifically to those employees involved in the manufacturing process;

      - _Depreciation and Amortization Expense: Property, plant and equipment are stated at cost and_
depreciated based on their estimated useful lives. Acquired property, plant and equipment and definitelived intangible assets are recognized at their acquired fair values and amortized over their respective
useful lives. Assets specifically related to the production of goods and services such as an allocated
portion of costs incurred for our plant and buildings, and machine and equipment as well as
amortization expense relative to patents, process know-how and supply agreements are recognized via
Cost of sales; and

      - _Other: Remaining Cost of sales relates to freight costs, warehousing expenses, costs associated with the_
idling of production facilities, product claims, or other general manufacturing costs.

Our overall Cost of sales is impacted by the following factors:

      - Changes in the price of raw materials, i.e. deflationary or inflationary price changes in the costs of
commodities;

      - Production volumes and utilization;

      - Improvement in production efficiency or other post-acquisition process improvements or cost savings
initiatives; and

      - Fluctuations in foreign exchange rates.

**_Selling, general and administrative expense_**

Our Selling, general and administrative expense of all expenditures incurred in connection with the sales
and marketing of our products and services, in addition to general and administrative costs, including:

      - Compensation and benefits costs for management, including stock-based compensation expenses;

108


-----

      - Expenses relating to sales personnel primarily resulting from increases or decreases in sales volume or
to meet changes in anticipated demand;

      - Expenses related to support functions and executives;

      - Depreciation expense excluding that recognized via Cost of sales in addition to other general selling
expenses incurred in the normal course of business; and

      - Service cost on our pension and other post-employment benefit plans.

Changes in our Selling, general and administrative expense as a percentage of Net sales are primarily
driven by:

      - Variances in sales volume, as fixed costs can be spread to higher sales totals;

      - Changes in demand which can impact our determinations of budgeted costs necessary to both maintain
our customer base and increase our gross revenue on a constant currency basis;

      - Frequency and depth of product launches or entrances and exits into market or geographical segments;
and

      - Fluctuations in foreign exchange rates.

**_Research and development expense_**

Our Research and development expense represents costs incurred to develop new products or services or
those incurred to develop and improve upon existing products or processes.

**_Amortization of intangibles_**

Amortization of intangibles represents the ratable recognition of expense relative to acquired definite-life
intangible assets that were initially recorded at fair value. This expense is exclusive of amortization recognized
through Cost of sales. Expense incurred and recognized via Amortization of intangibles primarily relates to assets
that are not directly related to revenue generating activities, i.e. customer relationships, trademarks and tradenames,
and land use rights.

**_Restructuring and severance expense_**

Our Restructuring and severance expense relates to costs incurred for implemented reductions in force and
strategic restructuring decisions designed to reduce overall spend and better align the personnel and leadership with
our organizational structure.

**_Impairment of goodwill and intangible assets_**

We perform impairment assessments at least annually relative to any acquired goodwill and indefinite-lived
intangible assets, including in-process research and development assets. Additionally, we assesses definite-lived
intangible assets for impairment to determine whether a qualitative or quantitative triggering event has occurred.

**_Acquisition and transaction related expenses_**

We continually seek opportunities to improve upon our market position and gain synergies via business
combinations. Acquisition and transaction related expenses represents costs incurred from completed, in-process, or
abandoned mergers and acquisition opportunities primarily for due diligence and valuation efforts.

**_Other operating (income) expense, net_**

We recognize Other operating (income) expense, net as a result of income and expense realized in the
ordinary course of our operations but are not classified as expense types identified above. Examples include realized

109


-----

foreign exchange gains on operational transactions and gains and losses on sales of property, plant, and equipment,
as well as bank fees and other financial costs.

**_Non-operating expense (income), net_**

We recognize Non-operating expense (income), net as a result of income and expense which arise from
transactions or other items which give rise to income or expense which are not in the ordinary course of our
operations. Such items include the following:

      - Unrealized foreign exchange gains and losses;

      - Our share of income from our joint ventures accounted for under the equity method of accounting net of
distributions;

      - Royalty income;

      - Pension expense (excluding Service cost, which is included in Selling, general and administrative
expense); and

      - Adjustments in the value of tax indemnification assets.

Other items which influence Non-operating expense (income), net include certain non-recurring items
which are not related to our operations such as:

      - Gains and losses on foreign currency forward contracts; and

      - Losses on extinguishment of debt.

**_Interest expense_**

Interest expense primarily relates to costs incurred for interest expense on our external borrowings and
other long-term liabilities. Other elements included in interest expense include:

      - Amortization of deferred financing costs incurred in connection with our debt borrowings and Revolving
Credit Facility;

      - Accretion of original issue discount on our debt borrowings;

      - Interest expense on our note payable to our shareholders; and

      - Reclassifications from Other comprehensive income related to our interest rate swaps.

**_Income tax provision_**

We are subject to income tax in the various jurisdictions in which we operate. Though the extent of our
future tax liabilities is uncertain, changes to our corporate structure, capitalization and future acquisitions are all
factors which may impact future book and taxable income of our subsidiaries and Solenis as a whole. Our effective
tax rate fluctuates from period to period due to changes in the mix of income or losses in jurisdictions with a wide
range of tax rates, permanent differences between U.S. GAAP and local tax laws, and certain one-time items
including tax rate changes, benefit of non-U.S. taxes, and adjustments related to unremitted earnings of our
subsidiaries. The amortization and increased interest expense related to our acquisitions and capital structure reduces
our profit before tax to a level where the effective tax rate is highly sensitive.

_Net sales_

Net sales increased by $104.5 million, or 15.7%, to $772.4 million for the three months ended June 30,
2021 as compared to Net sales of $667.9 million for the three months ended June 30, 2020. The increase in Net sales
was primarily driven by increases in sales volume, the effect of fluctuations in foreign currency exchange rates,
increases in pricing, and the incremental impact in the current year of our acquisitions which increased Net sales by
$42 million, $41 million, $14 million, and $8 million, respectively.

_Cost of sales_

Cost of sales increased by $90.6 million, or 19.7%, to $551.7 million for the three months ended June 30,
2021, as compared to Cost of sales of $461.0 million for the three months ended June 30, 2020. The increase in Cost
of sales was primarily attributable to fluctuations in foreign currency exchange rates, incremental sales volume, the
impact of raw material inflation, and the incremental impact in the current year of our acquisitions which increased
Cost of sales by $31 million, $29 million, $27 million, and $5 million, respectively.

_Selling, general and administrative expense_

Selling, general and administrative expense increased by $7.9 million, or 6.2%, to $134.0 million for the
three months ended June 30, 2021, as compared to Selling, general, and administrative expense of $126.1 million for
the three months ended June 30, 2020. The overall increase in Selling, general and administrative expense was
driven by the wind-down of various temporary cost reduction programs actioned in 2020 which increased Selling,
general and administrative expense by $12 million, as well as the effect of fluctuations in foreign currency exchange
rates which increased Selling, general and administrative expense by $7 million. These increases were primarily
offset by the incremental cost savings realized as a result of permanent cost reduction programs actioned during
2020 which resulted in reductions to Selling, general and administrative expense of $10 million.

_Net sales_

as compared to Net sales of $2,509.7 million for the year ended September 30, 2019. The increase in Net sales was
primarily driven by incremental Net sales of heritage BASF Paper & Water materials of $247 million resulting from
the incremental four months of consolidated BASF P&W results in 2020 relative to the eight month post-acquisition
period of 2019. Additionally, the increase in Net sales was partially attributable to increases in pricing primarily
related to the recapture of historical changes in raw material costs of $30 million, offset by the effect of fluctuations
in foreign currency exchange rates which reduced Net sales by $61 million. The remainder of the variance in Net
sales was primarily attributable to changes in volume.

_Cost of sales_

Cost of sales increased by $123.8 million, or 6.8%, to $1,939.4 million for the year ended September 30,
2020, as compared to Cost of sales of $1,815.7 million for the year ended September 30, 2019. The increase was
primarily driven by incremental sales of heritage BASF Paper & Water materials which increased Cost of sales by
$193 million which was offset by the effect of fluctuations in foreign currency exchange rates which reduced Cost
of sales by $43 million as well as the impact of raw material deflation which reduced our Cost of sales by $38
million. The remainder of the variance was primarily driven by changes in volume and mix, the impact of
compensation incentive increases, and the realization of certain procurement and production cost synergies that were
identified prior the acquisition of the BASF Paper & Water business on January 31, 2019.

year ended September 30, 2020, as compared to Selling, general, and administrative expense of $535.3 million for
the year ended September 30, 2019. The overall increase in Selling, general and administrative expense was driven
by a combination of factors specific to the incremental impact of the full year consolidation of the BASF Paper &
Water business (increase of $52 million), the realization of cost synergies identified as part of the pre-acquisition

of $34 million). These net increases were primarily offset by a reduction in non-recurring costs primarily related to
the 2019 consummation of the JV (reduction of $21 million) as well as the effect of fluctuations in foreign exchange
rates (reduction of $15 million).

primarily driven by the acquisition of BASF Paper & Water which resulted in net increases of approximately $64
million inclusive of realized cost synergies. In addition, we incurred $35 million of internal costs related to the JV
related to deal specific compensation, travel and training costs necessary to help ensure the close of the transaction
and realized the related cost synergies. These increases were offset by decreases driven by the restructuring of our
IWT business and the favorable impact of fluctuations in foreign currency exchange rates, each of which reduced
our Selling, general and administrative expense by $12 million.

Despite the increase in our overall costs, Selling, general, and administrative expense as a percentage of
Net sales decreased between periods from 24.1% to 21.3% for the years ended September 30, 2018 and 2019,
respectively. This relative decrease was driven by the acquisition of the BASF Paper & Water for which the costs to
serve our acquired customers is generally lower (on both a pre-synergy, and post-synergy basis) than that of the
heritage Solenis business.

_Research and development expense_

Research and development expense increased $1.3 million, or 3.2%, to $42.0 million for the year ended
September 30, 2019, as compared to $40.7 million for the year ended September 30, 2018. Research and
development expense as a percentage of Net sales decreased between periods, from 2.1% for the year ended
September 30, 2018, to 1.7% for the year ended September 30, 2019.

_Amortization of intangible assets_

Amortization of intangible assets increased $10.5 million, or 32.2%, to $43.0 million for the year ended
September 30, 2019, as compared to $32.5 million for the year ended September 30, 2018. The increase in
Amortization of intangible assets was driven primarily by our incremental amortization from new customer
relationships assets acquired in connection with the acquisition of BASF Paper & Water.

_Impairment of goodwill_

There was no impairment of goodwill for the year ended September 30, 2019. Impairment of goodwill was
$27.7 million for the year ended September 30, 2018. For the year ended September 30, 2018, the impairment
charge related to our Asia Pacific Pulp & Paper and Latin America IWT reporting units, for which we determined
that the carrying values exceeded the determined fair values for each reporting unit. As of September 30, 2018 (prior
to the acquisition of BASF Paper & Water), the remaining goodwill ascribed to each of these reporting units was $0.

_Impairment of intangible assets_

There was no impairment of intangible assets for the year ended September 30, 2019. Impairment of
intangible assets was $2.8 million for the year ended September 30, 2018. The entirety of the impairment during the
year ended September 30, 2018 related to the abandonment of our remaining research and development projects
which were originally acquired in connection with our acquisition of the AWT business from Ashland. As of both
September 30, 2019 and 2018, we have total remaining in-process research and development assets of $0.

_Restructuring and severance expenses_

Restructuring and severance expenses increased by $24.7 million, or 425.2%, to $30.5 million for the year
ended September 30, 2019, as compared to $5.8 million for the year ended September 30, 2018. The increase was
primarily driven by the timing of our cost-savings initiatives primarily related to planned reductions in force in
connection with the synergy objectives for the JV.

primarily related to planned reductions in force in connection with the synergy objectives for the JV.

_Interest expense_

Interest expense increased by $41.1 million, or 31.9%, to $170.0 million for the year ended September 30,
2019, as compared to $128.9 million for the year ended September 30, 2018. This increase in our interest expense

122


-----

was primarily driven by the incremental First Lien debt obtained in connection with the financing of our acquisition
of BASF Paper & Water for which we obtained approximately $525 million in aggregate proceeds from our USD
and EUR tranches, in addition to $124 million of revolver borrowings available under the First Lien USD
borrowings. As of September 30, 2019 and 2018, Solenis UK International had total debt of $2.4 billion, and $1.6
billion, respectively. The incremental borrowings were outstanding for the majority of the year ended September 30,
2019 as the acquisition of BASF Paper & Water closed on January 31, 2019.

_Income tax provision_

Income tax provision increased $12.8 million, or 148.7%, to $21.4 million for the year ended September
30, 2019, as compared to $8.6 million for the year ended September 30, 2018. While we continue to generate
significant pre-tax losses in foreign jurisdictions, those losses are less than those generated in the prior year. The
United States generated a large pre-tax loss, mainly driven by intercompany transactions and the shifting of the debt
and related interest expense to the U.S. operating entity. Our effective tax rate fluctuates from year-to-year due to
changes in the mix of income or losses in jurisdictions with a wide range of tax rates, permanent differences
between GAAP and local tax laws, and certain one-time items including tax rate changes, benefit of non-US taxes,
and adjustments related to the unremitted earnings of our subsidiaries. The amortization and increased interest
expense related to our acquisitions reduces our profit before tax to a level where the effective tax rate is highly
sensitive. Our effective tax rate for the year ended September 30, 2019 decreased as a result of the aforementioned
pre-tax loss position and the corresponding increase in our income tax expense. In comparison to the year ended
September 30, 2018, the increase in income tax expense was largely attributable to the foreign tax rate differential
between the United States and our foreign jurisdictions, the valuation allowances in jurisdictions for which deferred
tax benefits are not expected to be fully realizable, and the recognition of uncertain tax positions in various
jurisdictions. Other factors contributing to the fluctuation in the effective tax rate are the impact of the Tax Cuts and
Jobs Act’s new Base Erosion Anti-Avoidance Tax (“BEAT”), which was effective beginning fiscal year 2019, along
with transaction costs related to the BASF acquisition that must be permanently disallowed in certain jurisdictions
where goodwill is non-deductible.

Reverse supply agreements is a new commercial unit conceived as a result of the JV. As such, the RSA
business has no results prior to our acquisition of the BASF P&W business on January 31, 2019. This business unit
is comprised of the aggregated business results of our Reverse supply agreements which require us to provide
finished goods to BASF at a cash cost consistent with their legacy internal costing. These relationships enable BASF
to continue servicing the businesses that they retained after the closing of the JV. Because of the nature of these
agreements, the sales price to which we are entitled is generally below that which would we would receive in an
orderly third-party transaction, and generally results in limited Gross profit and Segment profit margins. While the
finished goods produced and sold under Reverse supply agreements are within our core operations and can
otherwise be ascribed to our other commercial units, we have elected to evaluate these results separately because we
do not have discretion over the timing or frequency whereby BASF will order these materials and lack the ability
under the terms of the agreements to determine pricing for these transactions. As the inclusion of these results in our
other operating segments would compromise the usefulness of the financial results, this commercial unit will be
separately reported until the underlying agreements expire and we reassert the opportunity to charge prices
commensurate with true costs and operating margins consistent with other market participants.

The increased profitability of our RSA business in 2020 is not expected to continue on a long-term basis
and was driven in part by the current year release of prior year reserves for potential claims from our customers that
ultimately were settled in full in normal course during 2020.

Reverse supply agreements is a new commercial unit conceived as a result of the JV. As such, the RSA
business has no results for the year ended September 30, 2018. This business unit is comprised of the aggregated
business results of our reverse supply agreements which require us to provide finished goods to BASF at a cash cost
consistent with their legacy internal costing. These relationships enable BASF to continue servicing the businesses
that they retained after the closing of the JV. Because of the nature of these agreements, the sales price to which we
are entitled is generally below that which would we would receive in an orderly third-party transaction, and
generally results in limited Gross profit and Segment profit margins. While the finished goods produced and sold
under reverse supply agreements are within our core operations and can otherwise be ascribed to our other
commercial units, we have elected to evaluate these results separately because we do not have discretion over the
timing or frequency whereby BASF will order these materials and lack the ability under the terms of the agreements
to determine pricing for these transactions. As the inclusion of these results in our other operating segments would
compromise the usefulness of the financial results, this commercial unit will be separately reported until the
underlying agreements expire and we reassert the opportunity to charge prices commensurate with true costs and
operating margins consistent with other market participants.

**Non-GAAP Financial Metrics**

To supplement our financial information presented in accordance with U.S. GAAP, we use the following
non-GAAP financial measures to clarify and enhance an understanding of past performance; EBITDA, Segment
profit, Adjusted net operating cash flows, and Adjusted net investing cash flows. We believe that the presentation of
these financial measures enhances an investor’s understanding of our financial performance. We further believe that
these financial measures are useful financial metrics to assess our operating performance from period-to-period by
excluding certain items that we believe are not representative of our core business. We use certain of these financial
measures for business planning purposes and in measuring our performance relative to that of our competitors. We
utilize Segment profit as the primary measure of our segment specific performance.

**_Reconciliation of Net (Loss) to EBITDA and Segment profit_**

EBITDA consists of net (loss) before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization. Segment profit consists
of EBITDA adjusted for (i) non-operating income or expense, (ii) the impact of certain non-cash, non-recurring or
other items that are included in net (loss) and EBITDA that we do not consider indicative of our ongoing operating
performance and (iii) certain unusual or non-recurring items impacting results in a particular period. We believe that
making such adjustments provides investors with meaningful information to understand our operating results and
ability to analyze financial and business trends on a period-to-period basis.

We believe these financial measures are commonly used by investors to evaluate our performance and that
of our competitors. However, our use of the terms EBITDA and Segment profit may vary from that of other
competitors in our industry. These financial measures should not be considered alternatives to income before income
taxes, net (loss), or any other performance measures derived in accordance with U.S. GAAP as measures of
operating performance.

131


-----

EBITDA and Segment profit have limitations as analytical tools and you should not consider them in
isolation or as substitutes for analysis of our results as reported under U.S. GAAP. Some of these limitation are:

EBITDA and Segment profit:

      - Do not reflect the significant interest costs relative to our first and second lien term notes as well as
our revolving credit facility;

      - Eliminate the impact of income taxes from the results of our operations;

      - Although depreciation and amortization are non-cash charges, the assets being depreciated and
amortized will often have to be replaced in the future, and EBITDA and Segment profit do not
reflect any expenditures for such replacements; and

      - Other companies in our industry may calculate EBITDA or Segment profit differently than we do,
limiting their usefulness as comparative measures.

We compensate for these limitations by using EBITDA and Segment profit along with other comparative
tools, together with U.S. GAAP measurements, to assist in the evaluation of operating performance. Such U.S.
GAAP measurements include income before income taxes, and net (loss) amongst other performance metrics.

In evaluating these financial measures, one should be aware that in the future we may incur expenses
similar to those eliminated in this presentation. Our presentation of EBITDA and Segment profit should not be
construed as an inference that our future results will be unaffected by unusual or non-recurring items.

**_Reconciliation of Cash Flows_**

Adjusted net operating cash flows and Adjusted net investing cash flows consists of reported Net cash
(used in) provided by operating activities and Net cash provided by (used in) investing activities, each adjusted for
the effects of cash subsequently received as part of our Accounts Receivable Financing. Accounting Standards
Update (“ASU”) 2016-15 requires us to evaluate the transfer of title of receivables sold under Accounts Receivable
Financing against cash received on previously-sold receivables in exchange for the transfer of title. Since there is a
dichotomy between when we legally transfer title of receivables to ING Luxembourg S.A. (“ING”) or MUFG Bank,
Ltd (“MUFG”) under the ING Receivables Purchasing Agreement or MUFG Receivables Purchasing Agreement,
respectively, and when the cash received on previously-sold receivables, receivables are deemed transferred in
exchange for a beneficial interest in the collection of that receivable. This is considered a non-cash investing
activity. Furthermore, ultimate receipts of cash, when settled with ING or MUFG, are considered cash flows from
investing activities, as the receipt is considered a return of capital on the beneficial interest.

We believe that this may cause Net cash (used in) provided by operating activities and Net cash provided
by (used in) investing activities to be potentially misleading to investors. While Solenis UK International does not
retain legal ownership of the receivables sold, the nature, timing, and extent of cash flows have not materially
changed as a result of the agreement. We use these Non-GAAP metrics to assess our own liquidity.

**Other Matters**

During the first quarter of 2019, Solenis entered into three interest rate swap arrangements to hedge
variable interest rate risk exposure specific to Solenis’ First Lien US Dollar-denominated debt. The aggregate
notional value for the three interest rate swap agreements is $600.0 million in the aggregate. As a result of these

135


-----

arrangements, Solenis collectively converted $600.0 million of its US Dollar-denominated debt from a floating
three-month LIBOR interest rate to fixed rates of 3.27%, 3.13%, and 3.13%, respectively for the 36-month period
from May 31, 2019 through May 31, 2022. Our total outstanding debt subject to variable interest rates is in excess of
the notional value of our interest rate swaps. As such, we are subject to additional interest rate-risk that may increase
our debt service costs in the future.

**Overview**

Headquartered in Alpharetta, Georgia, Sigura (Innovative Water Care Global Corporation, doing business
as Sigura) is a leading supplier of sanitizers and other water treatment solutions featuring top consumer brands in
residential and commercial pool and industrial water care markets. Water care products and value-added services are
offered for residential and commercial pools and spas in consumer channels such as Mass Retail, Professional
Dealer and Commercial, and for Industrial and Municipal Water addressing drinking water, process water,
wastewater, irrigation, surface water and industrial applications. It features top consumer brands in the pool care
market and strong positions in high-growth Industrial & Municipal water markets. Key brands include HTH®,
Poolife®, GLB®, Leisure Time®, Sirona Spa Care®, HTH Spa®, and more.

Sigura maintains six production facilities throughout North America, South America, Europe and South
Africa, with approximately 1,000 employees globally, located in all major regions. Sigura has three manufacturing
facilities that primarily produce calcium hypoclorite (“cal-hypo”) for water treatment and three packaging plants that
produce finished products for sale to customers.

**BUSINESS**

**Company Overview**

**_Solenis_**

Founded in 1907 and headquartered in Wilmington, Delaware, Solenis is a leading manufacturer and
distributor of specialty chemicals and solutions for consumer and industrial water intensive industries, including the
pulp, packaging paper and board, tissue and towel, oil and gas, petroleum refining, chemical processing, mining,
biorefining, power and municipal markets. Our product portfolio includes a broad array of water treatment
chemistries, process aids, functional additives as well as state-of-the-art monitoring and control systems. These
technologies are used by customers to improve operational efficiencies, enhance product quality, protect plant assets
and minimize environmental impact.

Solenis has 41 manufacturing facilities strategically located near customers in approximately 19 countries
around the globe to ensure seamless supply continuity and employs a team of more than 5,200 professionals
(including 1,600 field representatives with deep industry knowledge) in 120 countries across five continents. Solenis
has nine labs consisting of R&D centers and Customer Applications Laboratories spanning every region it serves,
aimed at making water work more effectively and more sustainably for its more than 11,000 customers. Key brands
include Zetag™, Kymene™, Hercobond™, Spectrum™, Praestol™, PerForm™ and Percol™.

For the twelve months ended June 30, 2021, Solenis generated Net sales and Adjusted EBITDA of $2.86
billion and $485 million, respectively, reflecting an Adjusted EBITDA margin of 17%. See “Summary— Summary
Historical Financial and Pro Forma Financial Data.”

**_Sigura_**

Headquartered in Alpharetta, Georgia, Sigura (Innovative Water Care Global Corporation, doing business
as Sigura) is a leading supplier of sanitizers and other water treatment solutions featuring top consumer brands in
residential and commercial pool and industrial water care markets. Water care products and value-added services are
offered for residential and commercial pools and spas in consumer channels such as Mass Retail, Professional
Dealer and Commercial, and for Industrial and Municipal Water addressing drinking water, process water,
wastewater, irrigation, surface water and industrial applications. It features top consumer brands in the pool care
market and strong positions in high-growth Industrial & Municipal water markets. Key brands include HTH®,
Pulsar®, Poolife®, GLB®, Applied Biochemists®, Leisure Time®, Baquacil®, HTH Spa®, and more.

Sigura maintains six production facilities throughout North America, South America, Europe and South
Africa, with approximately 1,000 employees globally, located in all major regions. Sigura has three manufacturing
facilities that primarily produce calcium hypoclorite (“cal-hypo”) for water treatment and three packaging plants that
produce finished products for sale to customers.

For the twelve months ended June 30, 2021, Sigura generated Net sales and Adjusted EBITDA of $625
million and $88 million, respectively, reflecting a 14% Adjusted EBITDA margin. See “Summary— Summary
Historical Financial and Pro Forma Financial Data.”

**Combined Company Overview**

We believe that the combination of Solenis and Sigura will create a global market leader across all water
intensive industries. We believe that we will be well-positioned to benefit from growing Environmental, Social and
Governance (“ESG”) and macroeconomic mega trends, including around customer sustainability goals and focus
points, such as: water recycle and energy and raw material management, consumer focus on hygiene, environmental
legislation globally, increased levels of shipping and packaging, among others. Together, we will offer a diverse,
comprehensive portfolio of solutions and services, which will limit any obsolescence risk as no product or solution
represents a material part of our business. Our cutting edge technology is at the forefront of the digitization of the

142

water treatment industry and we have a strong pipeline of new and innovative products that drive significant value
for our customers. We will operate across a diverse set of growing end markets and our broad geographic reach
allows us to meet the needs of our customers globally. Our footprint spans six continents, with both laboratories and
production facilities across North America, LatAm, EMEA, and APAC, where we serve all major developed
markets and are closely integrated with our customers throughout the world. Through our global presence and
differentiated service offering in growing markets, we believe we will be an industry leader in all of our segments.

We believe our business exhibits highly attractive financial characteristics, including significant recurring
revenues, improving margin profile and substantial free cash flow conversion. The combined Solenis company will
provide greater scale to capture tailwinds from growing end markets. For the twelve months ended June 30, 2021,
we generated pro forma Net sales and Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA (After Synergies) of $3,491 million
and $613 million, inclusive of $40 million of estimated run-rate annual cost synergies from actions taken within 18
months of the closing of the Transactions, respectively. We believe our combined earnings profile will generate
significant free cash flow, which we expect will be used to support growth initiatives and drive de-leveraging.

We believe the Transactions create an opportunity to realize meaningful synergies resulting from the
integration of Solenis and Sigura in addition to standalone cost savings at Solenis from management plans already
underway. We expect to realize approximately $40 million of synergies from integration related to the consolidation
of support functions and sales teams, sourcing of direct materials, and consolidation of facilities between the two
businesses, from actions taken within 18 months of the closing of the Transactions. Additionally, Solenis, along with
Platinum, has identified approximately $72 million in annual run-rate cost savings related to raw material sourcing
capabilities at Solenis, pricing and mix optimization, shared service and indirect spend optimization, and 4-wall
improvement on controllable costs at existing facilities from additional actions taken within four years of the
Transactions closing. We believe the total synergy and cost savings plan represents an approximately $113 million
opportunity based on actions implemented over the first four years from the closing of the Transactions. However,
there can be no assurance that we will be able to achieve these synergies or operational improvements. For more
information on anticipated synergies, including certain factors that may impact our ability to achieve such synergies
or operational improvements, see “Risk Factors—Risks Related to the Acquisition and the Reorganization—The
anticipated benefits of the Acquisition and the Reorganization may not be fully realized or may take longer to realize
than expected, which may adversely affect our results of operations.”

**_Pool Solutions Segment_**

Our Pool Solutions segment offers water care solutions and value-added services for residential and
commercial pools and spas. The water treatment process begins with testing, which requires testing for a pool’s pH
and chlorine levels on a weekly basis. The next step is balancing, i.e., maintaining certain levels of pH, total
alkalinity and calcium hardness. Sanitizing, which is keeping water clean and disinfected, is most frequently done
using stabilized chlorine products. Specialty maintenance products such as algaecides and clarifiers are typically
used on a semi-monthly basis, in addition to the normal sanitizing process, to target specific pool needs such as
algae prevention or stain control. Lastly, shock treatment can be used to address one-off pool care needs, especially
following inclement weather and high pool usage.

We are a leading producer of pool chemicals for the residential and commercial markets worldwide and
provide various water treatment products including shock, sanitizer, specialty maintenance products, and test strips.
Our offerings include a full suite of products and applications aimed at public pools, health clubs, aquatic parks,
hotels, motels, apartments and condominiums in the form of water-soluble pods, convenient floaters and automatic
feeders. Our portfolio of brands includes iconic brands such as HTH®, Poolife® and GLB®. We believe we are the
world’s largest producer of cal-hypo, a primary chemical used in water treatment and sanitation.

We believe we are one of only two players with a complete brand and product offering in the U.S. pool and
spa chemicals market and we believe we are the only player with a truly global offering. We have total market
access to all residential channels from Mass Retail (41% of Pool Solutions Net Sales for the twelve months ended
June 30, 2021) to Professional Dealer (48% of Pool Solutions Net Sales for the twelve months ended June 30, 2021)

**Customers and Suppliers & Procurement**

_Customers_

We serve a large base of customers across a diverse set of end markets. Our customer base includes many
of the top paper and industrial players across our Industrial Solutions and Consumer Solutions segments, including
WestRock, International Paper, and Marathon Petroleum and across big-box retailers such as Wal-Mart and Leslie’s
Poolmart in our Pool Solutions segment. We believe that the combination of Solenis and Sigura will further reduce
customer concentration. The top five customers for the combined Solenis company are expected to represent
approximately 13% of total sales with the largest customer representing 4% of the combined company sales.

At Solenis today, the top five customers represent approximately 15% of total Net sales with the top three
customers representing approximately 11%. No Solenis customer represents more than approximately 5% of total
sales. Historically, large accounts have grown 1.5x faster than the base business, driven by collaboration with
customers on new technology development, embedded service engineers and focus on consistent delivery and
service. At Sigura today, customer concentration has been relatively higher than that of Solenis due to large
corporate accounts and big-box retailers. Sigura is expected to increase direct-to-consumer sales and convert new
dealers over the next several years, which is expected to significantly reduce dependency on big-box retailers.

We believe our customer base is inherently sticky, attributable to the mission critical nature and service-led
models that we provide, leading to highly recurring, non-discretionary spend on Solenis’ products and services.
Solenis’ on-site technicians, employees and equipment at customer locations create high switching costs and
disruption risk. As a result, we believe Solenis’ Net sales is 95% recurring, driven by our differentiated solutions and
value proposition.

products are produced in-house, which has increased from approximately 70% since 2014 at the time of the initial
carve-out transaction from Ashland, and which Solenis plans to continue to increase in the next five years.
Additionally, there are several initiatives underway to drive insourcing for Solenis that will be implemented
following the Transactions to drive productivity and cost savings.

**Industry Overview**

**_Specialty Chemicals – Consumer_**

The consumer market is comprised of water treatment chemicals and solutions for pulp and paper specific
process applications (e.g., strength additives and sizing agents across wet-end/dry-end of paper process). Based on a
report by a third party expert advisor completed in June 2021, the global consumer market was estimated to be
approximately $8 billion in 2020.

The Packaging market is one of the key market segments within the consumer market that can be broken
into consumer packaging and food packaging. Based on the same report, the consumer packaging market was
estimated to be $2.7 billion in 2020 and is expected to grow at a 3.4% CAGR for the ten-year period 2020 to 2030,
which we believe will be driven primarily from the growth of e-commerce and megatrends in pharmaceuticals and
cosmetics and beauty. Approximately 18% of our pro forma Net sales for the twelve months ended June 30, 2021
was generated from the consumer packaging market. Based on the same report, the food packaging market was
estimated to be $1.8 billion in 2020 and is expected to grow at a 1.9% CAGR for the ten-year period 2020 to 2030,
driven by increased demand for ecofriendly packaging and changing lifestyles centering on more take-away and
individually packed food. We believe the shift away from plastic and the growth in the barrier coating market, which
is not included in the market size estimate, may drive additional growth in food packaging over this period.
Approximately 10% of our pro forma Net sales for the twelve months ended June 30, 2021 was generated from the
food packaging market.

The Graphic & Specialty Paper market has been adversely impacted by the continued substitution of
printed material with electronic media. Reduced use of commercial office spaces in Europe and North America as a
result of COVID-19 is also a negative factor for the sector outlook. The Graphic & Specialty Paper market, based on
the same report, was estimated to be $1.9 billion in 2020 and is expected to decline at a 1.9% CAGR for the ten-year
from 2020 to 2030. However, we have limited exposure to newsprint, which accounts for less than 2% of Consumer
Solutions sales, and we are shifting our focus to higher margin products to offset the expected volume decline in this
market. Approximately 11% of our pro forma Net sales for the twelve months ended June 30, 2021 was generated
from the Graphic & Specialty Paper market.

The Tissue & Towel market is benefiting from strong demographic/socioeconomic trends and increasing
hygiene standards, especially in developing markets. However, stagnating population growth in some mature
markets, and cost-cutting in the public sector and private company spending is expected to limit global market

150


-----

growth. The Tissue & Towel market, based on the same report, was estimated to be $1.2 billion in 2020 and is
expected to grow at a 2.6% CAGR for the ten-year period 2020 to 2030. Approximately 10% of our pro forma Net
sales for the twelve months ended June 30, 2021 was generated from the Tissue & Towel market.

**_Specialty Chemicals — Industrial_**

The industrial market supplies water treatment chemicals and solutions for heavy and light industries and
municipalities (e.g., cooling tower, boiler, influent/effluent, process water). Broadly speaking, the industrial market
consists of core water treatment which includes end markets such as pulp, mining and oil and gas, and wastewater,
which includes end markets such as municipal and industrial wastewater markets.

Based on the same report, the global industrial market was estimated to be approximately $23 billion in
2020 and is expected to grow at a 4.0% CAGR for the five-year period 2020 to 2025. The municipal market is
expected to grow at a 4.3% CAGR for the five-year period from 2020 to 2025, based on the same report, as demand
continues to increase from higher per capita usage of water, population growth and increasing regulatory demands.
The core water treatment market growth is expected to be driven by increasing sustainability and environmental
policies, growing regulatory demands and global industrial growth. This growth is expected to be highest in the food
and beverage market (5.5% CAGR for the five year period from 2020 to 2025, based on the same report) and the
refining and petrochemicals market (4.0% CAGR for the five-year period from 2020 to 2025, based on the same
report).

**_Pool_**

The aftermarket for the residential pool industry is comprised of three main segments: (1) Chemicals, (2)
Equipment, Parts, and Accessories and (3) Services. Our main focus is on the Chemicals segment which is the
largest and most stable component of aftermarket pool spend.

Pool chemicals sales are tied to: (1) the pool installed base and (2) total gallons of treatable water, and not
new builds. The U.S pool installed base has displayed long-term stability as it has consistently grown for decades,
including all years through the housing-led recession and during the COVID-19 pandemic period, which is
providing current tailwinds for the business. However, new builds account for less than 4% of the installed base
annually, meaning that new build rates are unlikely to materially impact our long-term performance.

The Pool Solutions segment also benefits from a stable aftermarket spend that mirrors the steady dynamic
of the installed base. Our chemical-based products result in 100% aftermarket exposure, which reduces our exposure
to cyclical industry trends such as housing starts. Pool chemical use is entirely non-discretionary in that it is a
requirement for owning and using a pool. Pool owners who have already made the significant upfront investment of
constructing a pool, estimated to cost $40,000 to $100,000, will continue to purchase pool chemicals, at the de
minimis annual expense of only $300 to $400 in order to maintain their pools.

Based on data contained in the Pkdata US Residential Swimming Pool Market Report (2020), the market
for chemicals for U.S. residential pools was estimated to be $2.6 billion in 2020. While according to the same
Pkdata report, the market is expected to grow at a 3+% CAGR in the five-year period 2020 – 2025, we believe our
Pool Solutions segment will grow in excess of that as we expand our customer base and increase market share with
new dealer relationships and e-commerce channel.

**_Competitive Landscape_**

_Consumer Solutions_

We believe, based on a report by a third party expert advisor completed in June 2021, that we are the
market leader in specialty chemicals for the Consumer Solutions segment with an estimated 20% of global market
share, based on Net sales. Based on the same report, we believe that we maintain market leadership positions in
almost all technologies and regions. The competitive landscape, as segmented by geography or technology, remains
fragmented. We have particularly strong market positions in process chemicals within the biocide, contaminant
control, defoamer, tissue specialties and pulp specialties technologies.

Our strength is based on the complete product portfolio, premium product performance and strong technical
support we offer. We believe we have the best and the broadest offering to help customers achieve their operational
efficiencies. We are a trusted supplier known for our data analytics capacities, with focus on service excellence,
sustainability, productivity and cost savings for our customers.

Certain competitors, such as Ecolab / Nalco and BASF have reduced their focus on the pulp and paper
market. Kemira is the only global competitor that has stated its intention to invest in the market. We believe we are
well positioned to not only remain the market leader but also expand our leadership position. With no obvious
consolidator and more than a hundred market participants, the market presents a significant consolidation
opportunity.

152


-----

Many customers are starting to embrace digital technology / data analytics to help track performance and
starting to partner with suppliers with strong R&D capabilities to develop innovative solutions to drive efficiency
and achieve sustainability objectives. This trend is expected to continue and we expect to benefit from it due to our
robust value-added chemistry and technology solutions offering.

_Industrial Solutions_

The global industrial water chemicals market is fragmented, with the top seven players, of which we are
one, covering only approximately 30% of the market, based on a report by a third party expert advisor completed in
June 2021. This is due to the required application-specific expertise and track-record of performance. Hence, by
region and by end-user market, three to five players may have disproportionately high share. We believe we have an
outsized share of the global pulp and paper market, which is one of our larger markets within the Industrial
Solutions segment.

We believe we offer the lowest per unit cost for comparable chemicals compared to our industry peers and
believe that the competitive pricing is our greatest strength in the Industrial Solutions segment. Additionally, we
offer an array of innovative solutions and comprehensive product lines both in core water treatment and wastewater
segment. Notable competitors include Ecolab / Nalco, Suez, ChemTreat, Kurita, Kemira and SNF. Ecolab which
acquired Nalco in 2011 is the largest water treatment player followed by Suez.

Similar to the consumer market, technology and R&D are becoming increasingly important beyond the
chemical product itself as customers are moving towards advanced analytics to optimize the volume of chemical
treatment, driving select industry participants to increasingly focus on equipment / engineering solutions as opposed
to chemical solutions.

_Pool Solutions_

We believe we are the only true global player in the Pool Solutions segment with leading market positions
in North America, South America, and EMEA. Our primary competitor in this segment is KIK Custom Products,
which provides various pool chemical solutions, with a focus on North America. Other smaller competitors also
compete in this market, with varying breadth and geographical focus, including Hasa Pool, Jandy, Lo-chlor and
Jack’s Magic.

We believe we are the world’s largest producer of cal-hypo, a primary chemical used in water treatment
and sanitation. All three of our cal-hypo facilities are co-located with chlor-alkali producers meaning that raw
materials (chlorine and caustic soda) are delivered into our production plants via a direct pipeline. We believe this is
a major competitive advantage and barrier to entry in the Pool Solutions segment as we believe it would not be
economical for our competitors to open a new cal-hypo facility that is not co-located with a supply of raw materials.

**_Sustainability and Environmental and Social Governance_**

We drive sustainability by reducing water and energy use and raw materials waste while improving
operational productivity. Increased focus on sustainability and ESG is a key trend across both Consumer Solutions
and Industrial Solutions segments and is driving demand as our customers aim to reduce water and energy
consumption, optimize raw materials spend and reduce waste emission. These objectives require increased chemical
use which is driving increased demand for our business.

At the micro level, we provide solutions to customers with specific sustainability goals. For example, our
offering of PFAS-free oil and grease resistant technology has been selected by major brand owners as a replacement
in food service bowls. We also made a series of recommendation to a petroleum company which resulted in a
reduction of 162 million gallons of water per year and approximately $45,000 of savings per year on energy and
chemicals. Our management is dedicated to, and focused on, building and marketing our strong ESG reputation,
shifting to green products and providing value-added services to help our customers achieve their sustainability
targets.

153


-----

Focus on solving customers’ environmental and sustainability challenges has led to notable results for
Solenis. In the twelve months ended September 30, 2020, (1) 84% of innovation projects in the pipeline had
sustainability / circularity focus, (2) 84% of Net sales was driven by projects that support customers’ sustainability
goals, (3) 12% of innovation programs focused on Carbon footprint projects, (4) CO2 emission was reduced by 16%
from the twelve months ended September 30, 2019 and (5) we had an Environmental Incident Classification (EIC)
score of 75, which was a 12% improvement from the twelve months ended September 30, 2019.

We are also focused on long term sustainability goals for our business that include: (1) over 50% of raw
material suppliers to be compliant with sustainable procurement, (2) 20% reduction in CO2 emissions, (3) 5%
reduction in water consumption, (4) over 80% of our revenues to support our customers’ sustainability goals, (5)
100% of our plants to be ISO 9001, RC14001 and SEDEX certified, (6) to have a 5% return on investment from
every commercial person focusing on reduction in energy, water and raw materials as well as improved productivity
and (7) water consumption to be reduced by 5% from the twelve months ended September 30, 2018 by 2030.

**Summary of Operational Improvements and Synergies Initiatives**

We, along with Platinum, have identified synergies resulting from the combination of Sigura and Solenis.
We expect to achieve an estimated $40 million in annual cost synergies from actions taken within 18 months of the
closing of the Transactions. The synergies are expected to be realized through consolidation of support and sales
functions, materials sourcing and facility consolidation.

  - Approximately $33 million of cost synergies are expected to be achieved through Sigura’s back office
consolidation into Solenis, as well as consolidation of the Sigura industrial sales organization.

  - Approximately $3 million of cost synergies relate to leveraging Solenis’ infrastructure and resources to
better drive Sigura’s direct materials sourcing through spend scaling.

  - Approximately $4 million of cost synergies are attributable to warehouse and distribution center
optimization as well as the consolidation of Sigura’s Alpharetta facility.

To achieve the identified synergies, we expect to incur approximately $28 million of one-time costs. The
majority of these one-time costs are related to implementation support with the balance related to severance and
other integration costs to ensure business continuity.

Additionally, we, along with Platinum, have identified operational improvements at the existing Solenis
business, resulting from plans from management that are currently underway. We expect to achieve an estimated
$72 million in annual cost savings based on actions implemented over the first four years from the closing of the
Transactions. The cost savings are expected to be realized through raw material sourcing capabilities at Solenis,
pricing and mix optimization, shared service and indirect spend optimization, and 4-wall improvement on
controllable costs at existing facilities.

  - Approximately $31 million of cost savings are expected to be achieved through improvement in sourcing
capabilities at Solenis.

  - Approximately $20 million of cost savings relate to driving pricing adherence to above floor pricing and
our ability to shift margin mix away from lower margin business.

  - Approximately $14 million of cost savings are attributable to expanding the scope of share service
organization (India and Poland) while driving savings in indirect spend categories.

  - Approximately $8 million relate to focus on reducing controllable costs at plants and facilities.

To achieve the identified synergies, we expect to incur approximately $25 million of one-time costs. The
majority of these one-time costs are related to implementation support and other costs to ensure business continuity.
