**Competitive Strengths**

_Leading Provider in Growing Water Intensive Industrial, Consumer & Pool Markets_

We believe the size of our total addressable market is $39 billion and that the market is relatively
fragmented, with the top six players holding only approximately 40% market share, presenting an opportunity for us
to capture share. Our combined platform will create a scaled leader across all water intensive industries. Based on a
report by a third party expert advisor completed in June 2021, we believe that we have that we have the #1 market
position in the Consumer Solutions segment and are one of the top market players in the highly fragmented
Industrial Solutions segment. Additionally, we believe we are one of two top players in the U.S. pool and spa
chemicals market.

We serve a variety of growing diverse water-intensive end markets, including consumer chemicals
(estimated by a third party expert advisor to grow at 1.8% CAGR for the ten-year period 2020 to 2030), industrial
chemical (estimated by a third party expert advisor to grow at 4.0% CAGR for the five-year period 2020 to 2025),
and pool and spa (estimated by the Pkdata US Residential Swimming Pool Market Report (2020) at 3%+ CAGR).
We have a comprehensive portfolio of solutions including Biocides, Antifoams, Raw and Waste Water treatments,
and Deposit Control, among others for our customers to address their needs in these growing end markets.

_Global Leader with Diverse Sticky Customer Base_

We have a large geographical footprint that enables us to provide global service to our customers. We are
present on six continents, with both laboratories and production facilities, across North America, LatAm, EMEA,
and APAC, where we serve all major developed markets. At Solenis, we have more than 5,200 employees with a
substantial presence across the North America, LatAm, EMEA, and APAC regions. At Sigura, we have a global
footprint in all key pool and water care regions, with approximately 1,000 employees globally across operations and
retail channels. Our strategic global footprint allows us to efficiently and effectively serve customers around the
world by providing consistent products and service.

Our service and technical abilities are mission critical to our customers. Typically our trained value-add
employees, scientists, and service engineers are embedded at customers’ sites, creating strong and long-term
relationships. We represent a lower overall percentage of our customers’ cost base and have been able to achieve
significant value add documented savings for our customers. We are highly engrained in our customers’ workflow,
and it is often difficult, expensive, and potentially disruptive for customers to switch to a competitor. As a result,
more than 95% of Solenis’ Net sales is recurring. Sigura’s Net sales are 90%+ driven by established, branded
products that carry strong customer recognition and loyalty and unique potential in their geographic end markets.
Further, our customer concentration is low with the top five customers representing approximately 13% of pro forma
combined company sales and the top customer represents approximately 4% of Net sales.

_Differentiated Business Model with Best in Class Service, Chemistry, and Technology_

We believe our suite of comprehensive products and services unlocks customer value as a result of our
industry leading employees and innovative technology offerings. Our solutions represent a small portion of our
customers’ overall end costs and provide a significant return on investment. Our differentiated service model, with
over 1,500 of our sales and service engineers on site with our customers, leads to highly recurring, non-discretionary
spending on our products and services, and with our solutions and value propositions including industry leading

155


-----

technology, Solenis was able to achieve $194 million of value-add documented savings for our customers in the
twelve months ended September 30, 2020.

We offer innovative chemistries to address customers’ operational and sustainability challenges while our
technology is at the forefront of the digitization of the water treatment industry. Further, we have product
development capabilities to meet customers’ new and evolving needs, based on three main pillars. First, we have
260 dedicated research and development professionals with two-thirds of our annual technology spend supporting
those efforts. Second, our innovation pipeline includes approximately 50 projects, representing significant potential
run-rate revenue, and we have approximately 2,000 patents, including patents for chemical and equipment
technologies. Lastly, our strategically located facilities around the world focus on analyzing and diagnosing products
and processes, as well as conducting testing to recommend effective improvements that enhance both productivity
and quality for our customers. This is critical as new and innovative products carry a higher than average margin and
this mix shift is expected to drive increased profitability for our business.

_Attractive Financial Profile with Strong Top Line Growth, Expanding Margins, and Robust Free Cash Flow_
_Generation_

Our global business has shown strong topline growth, with over 95% of Solenis’ Net sales being recurring
in nature, with the core business growing during the COVID-19 pandemic. By optimizing our cost structure through
a strict focus on maximizing operational efficiencies through new technologies, reducing redundancies and
leveraging existing infrastructure, we have seen improved Adjusted EBITDA growth and attractive margin
expansion. For the twelve months ended June 30, 2021, our Pro Forma Combined Adjusted EBITDA (After
Synergies) margin was approximately 18%. Our topline growth and impressive margin expansion with low working
capital intensity and minimal capital expenditures allow for significant free cash flow generation. See “Summary—
Summary Historical Financial and Pro Forma Financial Data.”

_Long Tenured, Industry leading Management Team with Strong Track Record_

We have an experienced management team with long tenures in the industry and experience in the sector.
Following consummation of the Transactions, the combined company will be led by John E. Panichella, who has
been CEO of Solenis since its inception in 2014, following the initial carve-out from Ashland. Through organic
growth and M&A, particularly the merger with BASF, Panichella has steered Solenis to global leadership in the
specialty chemicals for water-intensive industries. Prior to leading Solenis, John served as President of Ashland
Water Technologies, SVP of Ashland, Group Operating Officer of Ashland Specialty Ingredients and Ashland
Water Technologies, and President of Ashland Aqualon Functional ingredients. Surrounding John is a deep bench
across operations, technology, commercial and finance, including Philip M. Patterson, Jr, current CFO of Solenis
(and who will be CFO of the combined Solenis company following the Transactions), Andreas Tuerk, present and
continuing President of the Consumer Solutions business, Edward Connors, present and continuing President of the
Industrial Solutions business, and Robert Baird, current CEO of Sigura (and who will be President of the Pool
Solutions business following the Transactions). Solenis’ experienced team will drive long-term stability of the
combined business and support future growth.

**Growth Strategy**

We believe we are well positioned to grow organically and capture share through several distinct strategies.
Supportive end market trends that drove historical growth are expected to continue over the next five to ten years.
We have successfully maintained strong pricing discipline to offset inflationary increases to input costs and shift
customers to a more profitable mix, driving margin growth. The combination creates unique, value accretive
synergy opportunities, with line of sight on approximately $40 million of cost synergies (resulting from actions
taken within 18 months of the closing of the Transactions) and an additional approximately $72 million of
operational improvement opportunities within the combined Solenis company (based on further actions
implemented over the first four years from the closing of the Transactions). Our new partnership with Diversey will
allow Solenis access to a greater portion of the attractive Food & Beverage market.

We are also well positioned to continue to grow through acquisitions via multiple M&A avenues. We have
a proven track record as an M&A platform, with 11 transactions completed since 2014, including the transformative

2019 merger with BASF’s water and paper business. We believe there is opportunity for both strategic bolt-ons and
transformational targets going forward.

_Well positioned to grow with macro and ESG mega trends_

We believe our sophisticated product development capabilities meet our customers’ evolving needs and
help keep us at the forefront of macroeconomic trends. Our ability to evolve is based on three pillars that allow us to
grow our product offering alongside client demands: R&D, Innovation and Customer Application Laboratories. Our
R&D team has 260 dedicated professionals and two thirds of annual technology investment supports R&D. Our
robust innovation pipeline currently has approximately 40 projects and features approximately 2,000 patents,
including those for chemical and equipment technologies. Customer application laboratories are strategically located
facilities around the world focused on analyzing and diagnosing products and processes, as well as conducting
testing to recommend effective improvements that enhance both productivity and quality.

We focus on solving our customers’ environmental and sustainability challenges, placing us at the forefront
of the ESG mega trend. Through identification of specific goals such as reduction of water consumption, reduction
of energy consumption, reduction of waste emissions or optimization of raw materials utilization, we have been able
to work with customers to meet their unique needs. Our sophisticated capabilities have helped customers meet
evolving sustainability goals and achieve measureable results.

_Pricing discipline to drive margin growth_

We have a track-record of actively monitoring and managing prices, enabling the pass-through of raw
material cost increases to maintain margins. Through Solenis’ value-documentation program, sales teams have
accountability requirements to show that at least 5% of Net sales is value advantage to customers, which enables
price capture even in deflationary environments. This has enabled us to pass through a majority of increases in raw
chemical materials, which are one of the major drivers for cost inflation, to customers by adjusting prices
accordingly. As a result of recent increases in raw material prices, Solenis has executed over 26,000 price increases
between February and July 2021. The charts below summarize our success in implementing price increases and
maintaining price ahead of cost.

While our primary focus is on organic growth, our global presence, scale and broad product offering
position us well to execute on opportunistic acquisitions given the large and fragmented nature of the markets we
serve or to expand into new markets. We estimate that the markets adjacent to our market represent a total market
size of $42 billion and represent potential expansion areas, including the ion exchange and coagulants markets. We
believe that we can create significant value through strategic acquisitions given our track record of integration.
Solenis has completed 11 acquisitions since 2014, including the transformative and successful merger with BASF’s
water and paper business in 2019. We will focus on maintaining a disciplined acquisition strategy centered on: (i)
expanding our customer base in new and growing end markets and geographies; (ii) improving our customer
offering through access to new products and technological capabilities; and (iii) generating significant purchasing
and other operational synergies.

**Historical Business Segmentation**

**_Solenis_**

Since the joint venture arrangement with BASF in January 2019, Solenis’ business has principally
consisted of three operating segments: Pulp & Paper, Industrial Water, and Reverse Supply Agreements.

**_Pulp & Paper. The Pulp & Paper (“P&P”) business manufactures and sells a broad array of process_**
chemistry for the pulp and paper industry including deposit and scale control agents, defoamers, biocides, retention
aids and crepe and release additives. These products are designed to deliver benefits such as enhanced operational
efficiencies, system cleanliness and superior performance in a wide variety of manufacturing operations globally.

In addition, the P&P business offers functional chemistry for packaging, tissue and towel, and printing and
writing producers that impart specific properties such as wet or dry strength, colorants, surface size, liquid holdout
and printing ability to the final paper or board. Products and technologies include internal and surface sizing agents
and wet and dry strength additives.

**_Industrial Water. The Industrial Water (“IWT”) business offers specialized chemicals for the utility water_**
treatment market including influent water, boiler water, cooling water and effluent water treatments. Products
include scale and corrosion inhibitors, coagulants and flocculants, biocides, defoamers, anti-scaling for desalination,
membrane treatments and sludge dewatering. In addition, the IWT business offers process additives such as frothers
and collection aids, dust control additives, sterilization treatments, corn oil extraction and scale and corrosion
inhibitors for mining and mineral processing, food processing, oil refining, chemicals processing and general
manufacturing markets.

**_Reverse Supply Agreements. As part of the joint venture with BASF in January 2019, Solenis agreed to_**
provide certain finished goods to BASF, consistent with BASF’s historical cost and pricing structure, intended to
allow BASF to uninterruptedly sustain its retained businesses. These arrangements and related activities comprise
the Reverse Supply Agreements (“RSA”) segment of Solenis. As part of the resegmentation described below, RSA
will become part of the go-forward Industrial Solutions segment.

Solenis also provides automated equipment, including performance-based feed and control systems,
proprietary monitoring devices and remote system surveillance. The utility products, services and equipment
offerings are designed to protect plant assets and optimize energy, water and operational costs at customers’
facilities. As part of the resegmentation described below, equipment destined for packaging mills will become part
of the go-forward Consumer Solutions segment. Equipment provided by refineries will form part of the go-forward
Industrial Solutions segment.

159


-----

**_Sigura_**

Beginning with the quarter ended March 31, 2021, and following the divestiture of its Surface Water
business in October 2020, Sigura moved its commercial pools segment from the previous Industrial, Commercial,
Municipal & Surface Water segment (now known as Industrial & Municipal Water segment) to be consolidated with
residential pool segment under a newly named Pools Solutions segment. Additionally Sigura has a third Other
segment for other operations.

**_Pools._** Sigura’s pool business offers the sale of sanitizers and other treatment chemicals for pools, spas and
water parks. For the twelve months ended June 30, 2021, Sigura’s Pool segment had Net sales of $540 million, of
which 71% was generated in North America, 22% in EMEA and 7% in Latin America.

    - **_Recreational Water. Sigura’s recreational pool and spa care portfolio brings clean, healthy water to_**
households worldwide with a variety of shock, sanitizers, oxidizers, algaecides and balancers. Sigura’s
trusted brands ensure clean and healthy water for its customers’ and consumers’ pools and spas across
seasons.

    - **_Commercial Pools & Spas. Sigura’s commercial pool brands have been at the cutting edge of_**
swimming pool water treatment for over 30 years. Its chlorination solutions are used worldwide for
amusement parks, community pools, hotels, resorts, and professional training venues. Sigura
specializes in powerful sanitizers, coagulants and pool maintenance products in order to deliver water
clarity, color and sparkle to customers’ pools, while ensuring the highest level of water quality, and
Sigura’s range of automated feed systems make such professional pool treatment easy to achieve.

**_Industrial & Municipal Water._** Sigura’s Industrial & Municipal Water segment offers treatment of water
for drinking, agriculture, irrigation, food processing and industrial applications. For the twelve months ended June
30, 2021, Sigura’s Industrial & Municipal Water segment had Net Sales of $63 million, of which 43% was
generated in North America, 43% in EMEA and 14% in Latin America.

      - **_Industrial Water. Sigura’s Industrial segment (56% of twelve month ended June 30, 2021 total_**
segment sales) is a leading specialty chemical supplier to the global water treatment market and is
also a specialty chemical manufacturer. Sigura offers oxidizing and non-oxidizing biocides,
feeders and dosing equipment to customers for use in power plants, cooling cycles, food and
beverage and the paper industry. The combination of innovative technologies, patented solid
biocide feed systems and thorough application knowledge allows Sigura to deliver leading edge
solutions to its customers’ most demanding problems.

      - **_Municipal Water. Sigura’s Municipal segment (44% of twelve month ended June 30, 2021 total_**
segment sales) is focused on helping provide access to clean drinking water and safe water
supplies, which is fundamental to human health. Sigura’s global team of drinking water experts
provide easy to use, modular, chlorination systems, designed to solve each locations’ unique
operational requirements.

**Combined Solenis Company Business Resegmentation**

Following a strategic review related to Solenis’ operating segments and in anticipation of the closing of the
Acquisition and the Reorganization, changes will be introduced in the segment reporting from October 1, 2021. To
ensure comparability, Solenis has prepared condensed segment reporting presented on the basis of the new business
segmentation (i) for the three months ended June 30, 2021 compared to the three months ended June 30, 2020 and
(ii) for the nine months ended June 30, 2021 compared to the nine months ended June 30, 2020. See “Management’s
Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations of Solenis—Segment Results.”

The segmentation changes are being made for the following reasons: (i) alignment of the segment structure
to ensure that the combined Solenis company’s financial reporting segments are in line with its strategic approach in

160


-----

demarcating its operations and (ii) in order to most effectively manage the combined Solenis company and make
business decisions based on product lines and services.

Major changes relate to: (i) the creation of a new Pool Solutions segment to account for the contribution of
Sigura’s Pools segment, focused on delivering products for the treatment of pools, spas and water parks, (ii) the
renaming of the Pulp & Paper business as the Consumer Solutions business, (iii) the renaming of the Industrial
Water business as the Industrial Solutions business, (iv) the reallocation of the food processing aspects of the
business from the newly named Industrial Solutions business to sit with the other consumer-based products and
services within the newly named Consumer Solutions business, (v) the reallocation of the pulp processing aspects of
the business from the newly named Consumer Solutions business to sit with the other industrial-focused products
and services within the newly named Industrial Solutions segment, (vi) the contribution of Sigura’s Industrial &
Municipal Water business to the newly named Industrial Solutions segment and (vii) the inclusion of Solenis’ RSA
business within the newly named Industrial Solutions segment.

**_Consumer Solutions._** The Pulp & Paper segment of the historical Solenis business will be renamed the
Consumer Solutions segment of the combined Solenis company. The Consumer Solutions segment is mostly
affected by the removal of Pulp and its reallocation to the Industrial Water segment (now renamed the Industrial
Solutions segment).

**_Industrial Solutions._** The Industrial Water segment of the historical Solenis business will be renamed the
Industrial Solutions segment of the combined Solenis company. The Industrial Solutions business is mostly affected
by the inclusion of the RSA segment, the removal of Food and its reallocation to the Pulp & Paper segment (now
renamed the Consumer Solutions segment) and the contribution of Sigura’s Industrial, & Municipal business.

**_Pool Solutions._** Sigura’s Pool segment, including residential and commercial pools, will form the new Pool
Solutions business segment of the combined Solenis company.

**Sustainability Strategy**

Global demand for solutions that save water, use less energy, eliminate waste, and convert everyday
products to more sustainable materials is continuing to grow. As a leader in sustainability, Solenis has been helping
its customers tackle these complex challenges for more than 100 years.

Global trends show that sustainability strategies are becoming strong differentiators for businesses and that
stakeholders are increasingly interested in how key Environmental, Social and Governance (“ESG”) issues are
managed. ESG covers a broad set of issues, from the carbon dioxide footprint to labor practices to corruption.
Consumers and employees are demanding higher standards of sustainability and quality of employment. Regulators
and policy-makers are also interested in sustainability, and they see the corporate sector as a key player in the
journey toward achieving sustainable development.

One of the most relevant environmental issues for the chemical industry is the management of water
resources. As freshwater sources like rivers or lake become increasingly stressed, the chemical industry is working
with other sectors to increase water efficiency and to reduce water use in their operations and value chain.
Businesses are also investing in recycling technologies, as well as incorporating renewable and recyclable materials
in their product portfolio.

With a water treatment heritage of more than a century, helping customers meet their environmental goals
has always been one of the company’s highest priorities. Sigura supplies advanced product technologies to support
the sustainability of water, energy and the protection of critical water management assets. The combination of
Solenis and Sigura will enable the combined Solenis company to expand its presence across markets, to increase its
customer base and to reinforce its position as a sustainability leader.

In 2020, with a view to advancing our sustainability goals and commitments, we carried out a materiality
assessment to identify the most material topics to stakeholders and the business. The aim was to identify ways to
enhance the company’s existing sustainability efforts, improve transparency and disclosure, look for more

161


-----

opportunities to drive sustainable solutions and improve operational efficiency and productivity. Although involved
in numerous sustainability initiatives for many years, the materiality assessment helped to inform the development
of the company’s strategic sustainability approach going forward, organizing its actions and commitments across
four focus areas:

**_Wellbeing, Health & Safety of Our People. Our long-standing reputation for solving highly complex_**
customer challenges is directly attributed to our approximately 5,200 outstanding professionals, including 1,600
field representatives, working in 120 countries across five continents. It is our ambition to educate and engage our
employees to reach their full potential and to create a safe and inclusive work environment in which they can
continuously grow and succeed, and this is prioritized in our approach to culture, health and safety, diversity and
inclusion, and training and development.

**_Protecting our Planet. In our operations, our focus is on ensuring responsible stewardship of the natural_**
environment, by focusing on climate change and energy use initiatives, supporting circular economy and material
use principles (increasing the contribution of recycled materials to overall materials demand), promoting water
management and waste and pollution management and enabling our customers to manage resources and
manufacturing processes more effectively. This includes continuing to ensure that all our sites meet, or exceed, all
regulatory and environmental requirements, keeping abreast of changing applicable environmental laws and
regulations, and providing products and services to our customers to help them meet, or exceed, their own
environmental objectives.

**_Partnerships in Our Value Chain. Given our global reach, we recognize our responsibility towards_**
employees, customers, suppliers, governments, investors and the local communities of which we are part. We are
dedicated to responsibly managing relationships with our key stakeholders. An important element of this is
partnering with employees to help address the needs of the communities where we operate and collaborating with
our suppliers to increase transparency and sustainability in our supply chain.

**_Responsible Business Practices. We focus on operating with the highest ethical standards in all aspects of_**
our business and protecting the rights and interests of all our stakeholders, individually and collectively. We treat
personal data confidentially, adhering to effective policies and procedures securing lawfulness, fairness,
transparency, integrity and confidentiality of personal data entrusted to Solenis by our employees, customers,
suppliers, business partners and other individuals with whom we work. We are recognized globally for our legacy of
technology innovation and we invest in developing new chemistries to improve customers’ products and processes.
In 2020, Solenis embarked on a digital transformation effort focused on enhancing the customer experience using
digital solutions.

Our ambition for the future is to create more value for all our stakeholders while consuming less, thereby
minimizing our impact on the environment and society. Supporting our customers in their sustainability journeys
will always be central to our business. However, going forward we will also look inward, with a focus on
consumption reduction and on product development with sustainability at its core.

Following completion of the Transactions, the Sigura business will be integrated into these sustainability
goals and commitments.

**Impact of COVID-19**

Although the COVID-19 pandemic presented us with many hurdles to overcome, we achieved considerable
business successes through our business agility and creative approaches to solving customer problems. During the
pandemic, the business remained strong, owing to the essential markets we serve, which include consumer
packaging, tissue and towel, municipal and many other essential goods producers. These customers have ongoing
needs for products and services to protect water and production assets. For consumer-related manufacturing, such as
bath tissue and packaging for e-commerce, our customers increased production significantly in response to demand
driven by the COVID-19 pandemic and its consequences.

162


-----

In addition, COVID-19 has accelerated and driven many trends and changing behaviors globally, one of
which is the concept of “cocooning.” This has resulted in a greater focus on the home environment, which has
translated into increased residential pool builds in the North American and European geographies. Additionally,
greater focus on home entertainment and health has increased residential pool usage and maintenance, which has
positively impacted the demand for pool chemicals. A downside experienced from COVID-19 is the reduction in
tourism and travel, which has resulted in a negative impact on commercial pool usage and resulted in decreased
chemical usage in commercial pools.

Overall, we believe that the positive impact on residential pools chemical usage during the COVID-19
pandemic has outweighed the negative impact to the commercial pools chemicals usage.

We continued to observe strong market trends driving growth in sustainability, recycling, water reuse and
plastic conversion to fiber. We are moving numerous programs through our R&D processes to put new services and
products in the hands of our commercial team.

**Environmental Matters**

Due to the nature of our business, we are subject to various laws and regulations pertaining to the
environment, manufacturing, sale, transportation and disposal of hazardous products. These laws pertain to, among
other things, air and water, management of solid and hazardous wastes, transportation, and human health and safety.
We maintain reserves for any anticipated liabilities pertaining to environmental laws and regulations. The total
reserves for environmental remediation, reflect estimates of the most likely costs that will be incurred over an
extended period to remediate identified conditions for which the costs are reasonably estimable, without regard to
any third-party recoveries. Environmental remediation reserves are subject to numerous inherent uncertainties that
affect our ability to estimate our share of any such costs. Such uncertainties involve the nature and extent of
contamination at any site, the extent of required cleanup efforts under existing environmental regulations, widely
varying costs of alternate cleanup methods, changes in environmental regulations, the potential effect of continuing
improvements in remediation technology, and the number and financial strength of other potentially responsible
parties at multiparty sites.

As of both June 30, 2021 and September 30, 2020, Solenis had recorded environmental remediation
reserves of $1.8 million, related to two ongoing and probable environmental remediation proceedings. Of the $1.8
million reserved, $1.0 million relates to potential exposure surrounding groundwater and soil contamination
associated with a plant in Araraquara, Brazil. The remaining $0.8 million relates to management’s best estimate for
potential exposure related to ground contamination at Solenis’ Milwaukee, Wisconsin plant as well as a reserve for a
potential Environmental Protection Agency matter. The amount reserved for both matters represents management’s
then-current best estimate of total expenses to be incurred, made with the assistance of a third-party specialist.

We are not currently aware of any other material environmental liabilities or other material environmental
issues at our properties or arising from our current operations. However, we cannot assure you that such liabilities or
issues will not materially adversely affect our business, financial position or results of operations in the future.

We review environmental, health and safety laws and regulations pertaining to our operations and believe
that compliance with current environmental and workplace health and safety laws and regulations has not had a
material effect on our capital expenditures or consolidated financial condition.

**Competition**

Our business competes on the basis of its demonstrated value, technical expertise, innovation, chemical
formulations, customer support, detection equipment, monitoring capabilities, and dosing and metering equipment.
Our principal competitors include Ecolab (Nalco), Kemira and SNF.

We believe that we are well positioned to compete in our markets. In particular, we believe Solenis’
differentiated product portfolio, with strong intellectual property, gives us a real competitive advantage. We
executed a clear strategy around several growth vectors, including corporate accounts, emerging markets, new

163


-----

technologies, focused investment in water-intensive industries and polyacrylamide (PAM) manufacturing
capabilities investment — and all showed good returns.

Our scale provides a competitive benefit when compared with the smaller local or regional competitor
providers, as we are able to leverage our distribution network to service smaller customers in a cost-effective way.
We also differentiate from our competitors through (i) the breadth of our offering — Solenis is one of three global
players with a full portfolio of water-intensive industry solutions, with best-in-class dosing and dispensing
technologies and advanced analytics to optimize the processes for the customer, (ii) our delivery of a total solution
to customers — operating as their trusted advisor in assessing operational efficiencies and leveraging our network of
experts to solve customers’ most difficult problems on a time-critical path through our fast track laboratories, (iii)
our commitment to constantly developing our portfolio to improve products, our development of new technologies
to deliver increased customer savings, and our addition of new product categories to meet more customer needs, and
(iv) the expertise of our workforce — who are highly trained in focused industries, and the majority of whom are
embedded in customer facilities.

**Personnel**

As of June 30, 2021, after giving effect to the Transactions, we had approximately 6,296 employees
worldwide directly supporting our operations with approximately 1,847 employed in the United States. As of June
30, 2021, 142 of our employees in the United States, representing 7.7% of our employees in the United States, were
subject to collective bargaining agreements. These collective bargaining agreements are negotiated with various
unions representing our employees. Our employees are at the heart of our mission and strategies, and to drive both,
we focus on our culture.

**_Our Culture. Our mission is to strive to be each customer’s most trusted supplier. Our solutions drive_**
sustainability by reducing water and energy use and raw material waste while improving operational efficiency and
productivity. At its core, our focus is on profitable sustainability. Our culture is centered on fundamental beliefs
around the importance of our people, continuous performance improvement and creating positive experiences in our
interactions for every customer to fuel the growth of the business. Solenis brings together diverse perspectives in a
safe, collaborative workplace that empowers our employees to solve the world’s most challenging process and
sustainability challenges. We nurture a culture of inclusion and accountability and promote learning and
development of all employees.

**_Health & Safety. We continuously strive to be a leader in health and safety. Our long-term ambition is to_**
operate with zero injuries. To support this ambition, we have set a target to reduce our total recordable incident rate
by at least 10% versus the prior year.

**_Diversity & Inclusion. A diverse workforce is integral to deliver our strategy. By embracing the unique_**
strengths of each person and respecting and promoting differences, we believe that we can build the most effective
teams and enhance Solenis’ performance across our global operations. Our ambition is to double the number of
diverse people in the company by 2030.

**_Training and Development. In addition to recognizing and rewarding our employees for their_**
achievements, we offer continuous learning and development opportunities. We proactively focus on creating
personalized development plans for every individual, ensuring that joining Solenis — and staying with us — leads
to a rewarding career that focuses on lifelong learning as well as personal and professional growth opportunities.

**Intellectual Property**

We strategically manage our portfolio of patents, trade secrets, copyrights, trademarks and other
intellectual property. Specifically, we rely upon trade secrets to protect the formulation of many of our chemical
products, as well as our manufacturing processes. We own or have licenses under patents and trademarks which are
used in connection with our business. Some of these patents or licenses cover significant product formulations and
processes used to manufacture our products.

The trademarks of major products in each business are registered in key jurisdictions or licensed from third
parties. Certain intellectual property is also protected by confidentiality agreements or other agreements with
suppliers, employees and other third parties. In part, our success can be attributed to the existence and continued
protection of these trademarks, patents and trade secrets.

We do not believe that our overall business is materially dependent on any individual trade name,

**About Parent and the General Partner**

Parent is a Cayman Islands exempted limited partnership that was formed and registered under the
Exempted Limited Partnership Act (as amended) (“ELP Act”) on June 29, 2021.

A key feature of an exempted limited partnership is that it is not a separate legal person distinct from its
partners. Under Cayman Islands law, any rights or property of an exempted limited partnership (whether held in that
partnership's name or by any one or more of its general partners) shall be held or deemed to be held by the general
partner (in the case of Parent, this will be the General Partner), and if more than one by the general partners jointly,
upon trust as an asset of the exempted limited partnership in accordance with the terms of the partnership agreement.
Any debts or obligations incurred by the general partner in the conduct of Parent’s business are the debts and
obligations of the Parent. In the event that the assets of the Parent are inadequate, the General Partner will be liable
for all such debts and obligations of the Parent.

Registration under the ELP Act entails that the exempted limited partnership becomes subject to, and the
limited partners therein are afforded the limited liability (subject to the partnership agreement) and other benefits of,
the ELP Act.

As a general matter, a limited partner of an exempted limited partnership will not be liable for the debts and
obligations of the exempted limited partnership save (i) as provided in the partnership agreement or otherwise

169


-----

agreed, (ii) if such limited partner becomes involved in the conduct of the partnership’s business and holds himself
out as a general partner to third parties or (iii) if such limited partner is obliged pursuant to section 34 of the ELP
Act to return a distribution made to it where the exempted limited partnership is insolvent and the limited partner has
actual knowledge of such insolvency at the time of such distribution.

The General Partner was incorporated as a Cayman Islands exempted limited company on June 29, 2021.
The business of the Parent will be conducted by the General Partner.

**DESCRIPTION OF NEW CREDIT FACILITIES AND OTHER INDEBTEDNESS**

The following is a description of our New Credit Facilities that we will enter into in connection with the
Acquisition. The following summary of certain provisions of the New Credit Facilities does not purport to be
complete and may not contain all of the information that is important to you, and is subject to, and qualified in its
entirety by reference to, all of the provisions of the corresponding agreements. All terms of the New Credit Facilities
described herein are subject to the marketing process and remain subject to change.

**New ABL Revolving Credit Facility**

On the Acquisition Closing Date, we expect to enter into our New ABL Revolving Credit Facility. Our
New ABL Revolving Credit Facility will be available to the Issuer and certain of its affiliates that are designated as
co-borrowers therein and provide for senior secured asset-based, multi-currency revolving loans, swingline loans
and letter of credit availability in an aggregate principal amount of up to $500 million, subject to borrowing base
capacity. Letters of credit will be limited to the lesser of (a) an amount to be agreed and (b) the aggregate unused
amount of commitments under our New ABL Revolving Credit Facility then in effect, subject to borrowing base
capacity. Bank of America, N.A. will act as administrative agent and collateral agent for our New ABL Revolving
Credit Facility. Our New ABL Revolving Credit Facility will mature five years after the Acquisition Closing Date.
We expect to use borrowings under our New ABL Revolving Credit Facility (a) on the Acquisition Closing Date, (i)
to fund certain original issue discount and upfront fees, (ii) to replace, backstop or cash collateralize existing letters
of credit and similar instruments of the Issuer and certain of its affiliates, (iii) for working capital needs, earn-outs,
or purchase price adjustments under the Acquisition Agreement, (iv) to finance the Closing Date Cash Purchase (as
such term shall be defined in the New ABL Credit Agreement) (which shall not exceed $175.0 million) and (v) for
any other purpose permitted by the lenders under the New ABL Revolving Credit Facility and (b) after the
Acquisition Closing Date, for working capital and general corporate purposes and borrowings and issuances of
letters of credit.

Borrowings under our New ABL Revolving Credit Facility will be limited by borrowing base calculations
based on the sum of specified percentages of eligible accounts receivable, eligible inventory and unrestricted cash,
minus the amount of any applicable reserves. Borrowings will bear interest at a floating rate, which can be either an
adjusted Eurodollar rate plus an applicable margin or, at our option, a base rate plus an applicable margin. We may
borrow on the New ABL Revolving Credit Facility only up to the lesser of (i) the level of our then-current
borrowing base and (ii) our committed maximum borrowing capacity of $500 million. Subject to certain conditions,
our New ABL Revolving Credit Facility may be expanded by up to the greater of (a) the greater of (i) $250 million
and (ii) a percentage of Consolidated EBITDA (as such term shall be defined in the New ABL Credit Agreement) of
Parent and its restricted subsidiaries for the most recent twelve-month period that will be equal to a percentage of
Consolidated EBITDA as of the Acquisition Closing Date equaling the equivalent of $250 million and (b) the excess
of the borrowing base at such time over the aggregate commitments under the New ABL Revolving Credit Facility
at such time. Our ability to draw under our New ABL Revolving Credit Facility or issue letters of credit thereunder
after the Acquisition Closing Date will be conditioned upon, among other things, our delivery of prior written notice
of a borrowing or letter of credit request, as applicable, our ability to reaffirm the representations and warranties
contained in the New ABL Credit Agreement in all material respects and the absence of any default or event of
default thereunder.

Our obligations under our New ABL Revolving Credit Facility will be guaranteed by Parent and its direct
and indirect wholly owned U.S. subsidiaries (subject to certain permitted exceptions, including exceptions based on
immateriality thresholds of aggregate assets and revenues of excluded U.S. subsidiaries) as well as certain of
Parent’s direct and indirect wholly owned foreign subsidiaries organized in jurisdictions where borrowing base
assets are located (subject to certain permitted exceptions; provided that no foreign Subsidiary shall guarantee any
obligations of any U.S. entity). As detailed in the immediately succeeding sentence, our New ABL Revolving Credit
Facility will be secured by a lien on substantially all of Parent’s, the Issuer’s and each of their direct and indirect
wholly owned U.S. subsidiaries’ current and fixed assets (subject to certain exceptions), as well as certain assets of
certain of their direct and indirect wholly owned foreign subsidiaries; provided that no foreign assets shall secure
any obligations of any U.S. entity. Our New ABL Revolving Credit Facility will have a first-priority lien on the
Current Asset Collateral (as such term shall be defined in the New ABL Credit Agreement) and a second-priority
lien on the Fixed Asset Collateral (as such term shall be defined in the New ABL Credit Agreement) (second in

172


-----

priority to the liens securing our New Term Loan Facility discussed below), in each case, subject to other permitted
liens.

The following fees will be applicable under our New ABL Revolving Credit Facility: (a) an unused line fee
of (i) 0.375% per annum of the unused portion of our New ABL Revolving Credit Facility (excluding any swingline
loans) when the average daily unused portion of such facility is less than 50% of the aggregate commitments under
our New ABL Revolving Credit Facility or (ii) 0.250% per annum of the unused portion of our New ABL
Revolving Credit Facility when the average daily unused portion of such facility (excluding any swingline loans) is
equal to or greater than 50% of the aggregate commitments under our New ABL Revolving Credit Facility, (b) letter
of credit fees of (i) a participation fee equal to the applicable margin for adjusted Eurodollar rate loans, as
applicable, in each case, on the undrawn amount of all outstanding letters of credit under the New ABL Revolving
Credit Facility and (ii) a fronting fee equal to 0.125% on the average daily amount of undrawn and unreimbursed
letters of credit per annum and (c) certain other customary fees and expenses of the lenders, letter of credit issuers
and agents thereunder. Subject to customary provisions for discretionary and protective overadvances, we will be
required to make prepayments under our New ABL Revolving Credit Facility at any time when, and to the extent
that, the aggregate amount of the outstanding loans and letters of credit under our New ABL Revolving Credit
Facility exceeds the then applicable borrowing base.

Our New ABL Revolving Credit Facility will contain customary covenants, including, but not limited to,
restrictions on our ability and that of our restricted subsidiaries to merge and consolidate with other companies,
incur indebtedness, grant liens or security interests on assets, make acquisitions, loans, advances or investments, pay
dividends, sell or otherwise transfer assets, optionally prepay or modify terms of certain junior indebtedness, enter
into transactions with affiliates or certain burdensome agreements, modify our governing documents or certain
junior debt documents or change our line of business. Our New ABL Revolving Credit Facility will require the
maintenance of a minimum Fixed Charge Coverage Ratio (to be set forth in the New ABL Credit Agreement) of
1.00 to 1.00 (tested for the four fiscal quarter period ending on the last day of the most recently ended fiscal quarter
for which financials have been delivered, and at the end of each succeeding fiscal quarter thereafter) during any
period commencing on the date when Adjusted Availability (as such term shall be defined in the New ABL Credit
Agreement) is less than the greater of (a) 10% of the Line Cap (as such term shall be defined in the New ABL Credit
Agreement) and (b) $25 million and ending on the date on which Adjusted Availability has exceeded the greater of
10% of the Line Cap and (b) $25 million for at least 30 consecutive calendar days.

Our New ABL Revolving Credit Facility will provide that, upon the occurrence of certain events of default,
our obligations thereunder may be accelerated and the lending commitments terminated. Such events of default
include payment defaults to the lenders thereunder, material inaccuracies of representations and warranties, covenant
defaults, cross-defaults to other material indebtedness, voluntary and involuntary bankruptcy proceedings, material
money judgments, pension-plan events reasonably likely to have a material adverse effect, certain change of control
events and other customary events of default, subject to certain materiality levels, default triggers, cure and grace
periods and/or baskets.

Bank USA, as administrative agent and collateral agent, and certain other arrangers and lenders, which will be fully
drawn to fund, in part, the Acquisition, and will be available to the Issuer in the amount of approximately $1,400

Subject to certain conditions, our New Term Loan Facility, without the consent of the then-existing lenders
(but subject to the receipt of commitments), may be increased (or new incremental term loan facilities added) in an

no greater than (a) the greater of (x) $600 million and (y) 100.0% of Consolidated EBITDA (as such term shall be

Closing Date or (y) at the election of the Issuer if incurred in connection with a permitted acquisition or other
permitted investment, would not increase or (2) the Fixed Charge Coverage Ratio (as such term shall be defined in
the New Term Loan Credit Agreement) is not less than the Fixed Charge Coverage Ratio prior to such increase.

Our loans incurred under the Dollar tranche of our New Term Loan Facility will amortize in equal quarterly
installments in an amount equal to 1.00% per annum of the principal amount. The interest rate margin applicable to
borrowings under the Dollar tranche of our New Term Loan Facility will be, at our option, either (1) the base rate

New Term Loan Facility is expected to be subject to a LIBOR floor.

Our loans incurred under the Euro tranche of our New Term Loan Facility will not have scheduled
amortization payments prior to maturity. The interest rate margin applicable to borrowings under the Euro tranche of
our New Term Loan Facility will be either one-, three- or six-month EURIBOR or, if agreed to by all relevant
lenders, 12-month EURIBOR or any shorter period (selected at our option) plus an applicable margin. The Euro
tranche under our New Term Loan Facility is expected to be subject to a EURIBOR floor.

We may voluntarily prepay loans under our New Term Loan Facility, in whole or in part, subject to
minimum amounts, with prior notice but without premium or penalty (other than, subject to certain exclusions, a
1.00% premium on any prepayment in connection with a repricing transaction prior to the date that is six months
after the Acquisition Closing Date).

We will be required to prepay our New Term Loan Facility with the net cash proceeds of certain asset sales
and casualty events relating to our assets (other than Current Asset Collateral), the incurrence or issuance of
specified refinancing indebtedness or any indebtedness not permitted under the New Term Loan Facility and 50% of
excess cash flow, in each case, subject to certain reinvestment rights, thresholds, step-downs and other exceptions.

Our obligations under our New Term Loan Facility will be guaranteed by Parent and its direct and indirect
wholly owned U.S. subsidiaries (subject to certain customary exceptions, including exceptions based on
immateriality thresholds of aggregate assets and revenues of excluded U.S. subsidiaries). Our New Term Loan
Facility will be secured by a lien on substantially all of Issuer’s and each of the New Term Loan Facility guarantors’
current and fixed assets (subject to certain exceptions), and our New Term Loan Facility will have a first-priority
lien on the Fixed Asset Collateral and certain material real property and a second-priority lien on the Current Asset
Collateral (second in priority to the liens securing our New ABL Revolving Credit Facility discussed above), in each
case, subject to other permitted liens.

Our New Term Loan Facility will contain customary negative covenants generally consistent with those
applicable to the Notes, including, but not limited to, restrictions on our ability and that of our restricted subsidiaries
to merge and consolidate with other companies, incur indebtedness, grant liens or security interests on assets, make
acquisitions, loans, advances or investments, pay dividends or other restricted payments, make investments, sell or
otherwise transfer assets, optionally prepay or modify terms of certain junior indebtedness, enter into transactions
with affiliates or certain burdensome agreements, modify our governing documents or certain junior debt documents
or change our line of business.

Our New Term Loan Facility will provide that, upon the occurrence of certain events of default, our
obligations thereunder may be accelerated. Such events of default will include payment defaults to the lenders
thereunder, material inaccuracies of representations and warranties, covenant defaults, cross-defaults to other
material indebtedness, voluntary and involuntary bankruptcy proceedings, unpaid material money judgments,
pension-plan events reasonably likely to have a material adverse effect, change of control and other customary
events of default subject to certain materiality levels, default triggers, cure and grace periods and or baskets.

Facility”) pursuant to the terms of that certain Receivables Purchasing Agreement, dated as of March 26, 2018, (as
amended and restated on September 30, 2019, as further amended and restated on March 18, 2020 and as further
amended, restated, amended and restated, modified and supplemented from time to time). Under the Accounts
Receivables Facility upon satisfaction of conditions precedent, the Originators will periodically sell to the Purchaser
up to an aggregate of EUR 110 million in eligible accounts receivable and certain related rights created in the
ordinary course of business. The Master Servicer and the Originators, acting as servicers, service the purchased
receivables on behalf of the Purchaser. The Accounts Receivable Facility will terminate on March 21, 2022, unless

The following fees are applicable under the Accounts Receivable Facility: (a) an administrative fee of
0.05% per annum of EUR 110 million, payable monthly, (b) fees of (i) a funding cost equal to EURIBOR or onemonth USD LIBOR, as applicable, plus an applicable margin, charged on the purchase price of a pool of purchase
receivables for a given month and (ii) a commitment fee of 0.60% per annum of the unused portion of the Accounts
Receivable Facility for the same period and (c) certain other customary fees and expenses incurred by the Purchaser.

The Accounts Receivable Facility contains customary covenants, including, but not limited to, restrictions
on the ability of the Master Servicer and the Originators to merge and consolidate with other companies, incur
indebtedness, sell or otherwise transfer or grant liens or security interests on any purchased receivables other than in
accordance with the Accounts Receivable Facility, and modify or fail to comply with their credit and collection
policies.

The Accounts Receivable Facility provides that, upon the occurrence of certain termination events, the
Purchaser will cease to purchase new receivables, a backup servicer will assume the servicing duties of the Master
Servicer, collections on the purchased receivables will be made on a daily basis and certain of our obligations
thereunder may be accelerated. Such termination events include payment defaults, material inaccuracies of
representations and warranties, covenant defaults, cross-defaults to other material indebtedness, voluntary and
involuntary bankruptcy proceedings, change of control, failure to meet certain financial tests or maintain certain
financial ratios and other customary termination events subject to certain materiality levels, default triggers, cure and
grace periods.

The terms and covenants discussed above may be amended or waived and amounts owing under the ING
Receivables Purchasing Agreement will remain outstanding following consummation of the Transactions.

**Brief Description of the Unsecured Notes**

**_The Unsecured Notes_**

If the Acquisition is not consummated on the Issue Date, prior to the Escrow Release (as defined below),
the Unsecured Notes will be senior secured obligations of the Issuer secured by the Escrowed Funds on a first
priority basis. From and after the Escrow Release (or on the Issue Date immediately following the Acquisition and
Reorganization if the Acquisition and Reorganization close concurrently with this offering), the Unsecured Notes
will be senior unsecured obligations of the Issuer and will:

    - without giving effect to collateral arrangements, rank contractually equal in right of payment with all
existing and future senior Indebtedness of the Issuer (including Indebtedness under the New Credit
Agreements and the Secured Notes);

    - rank contractually senior in right of payment to all future Subordinated Indebtedness of the Issuer, if
any;

Indebtedness under the New Credit Agreements, the Secured Notes and capital leases, if any), to the
extent of the value of the assets securing such obligations;

    - be structurally subordinated to all existing and future liabilities of all Non-Guarantor Subsidiaries; and

    - from and after the Acquisition Closing Date, be guaranteed on a senior unsecured basis by Parent and
each Wholly Owned Subsidiary that guarantees any obligations under the New Term Loan Credit
Agreement.

**_Unsecured Note Guarantees_**

Prior to the Acquisition Closing Date, the Unsecured Notes will not be guaranteed. On the Acquisition
Closing Date, Parent and each of Parent’s Wholly Owned Subsidiaries that are Domestic Subsidiaries (other than
Excluded Subsidiaries) that is a borrower and/or guarantor under the New Term Loan Credit Agreement will jointly
and severally, irrevocably, fully and unconditionally guarantee on a senior unsecured basis the performance and
punctual payment when due, whether at Stated Maturity, by acceleration or otherwise, of all Obligations of the
Issuer under the Unsecured Indenture and the Unsecured Notes (including interest, fees and expenses which, but for
the filing of a petition in bankruptcy with respect to the Issuer, would have accrued on any Obligation, whether or
not a claim is allowed against the Issuer for such interest, fees and expenses in the related bankruptcy proceeding) to
the holders and the Trustee, whether for payment of principal or interest on the Unsecured Notes, fees, expenses,
indemnification or otherwise (all such obligations guaranteed by such Guarantors being herein called the
“Unsecured Guaranteed Obligations”).

Each Unsecured Note Guarantee of a Guarantor will be a senior unsecured obligation of such Guarantor
and will:

    - without giving effect to collateral arrangements, rank contractually equal in right of payment with all
existing and future senior Indebtedness of such Guarantor (including Indebtedness under the Secured
Notes and the New Credit Agreements);

    - rank contractually senior in right of payment to all existing and future Subordinated Indebtedness of
such Guarantor, if any;

    - be effectively subordinated to any existing and future secured Indebtedness of such Guarantor
(including such Guarantor’s guarantee of Indebtedness under the New Credit Agreements, Secured
Notes and capital leases, if any), to the extent of the value of the assets securing such Indebtedness;
and

    - be structurally subordinated to all existing and future liabilities of such Guarantor’s Non-Guarantor
Subsidiaries.

Each Unsecured Note Guarantee will be limited in amount to an amount not to exceed the maximum
amount that can be guaranteed by the applicable Guarantor without rendering the Unsecured Indenture or the
Unsecured Note Guarantee, as it relates to such Guarantor, voidable under applicable law relating to fraudulent
conveyance or fraudulent transfer or similar laws affecting the rights of creditors generally. See “Risk Factors—
Risks Related to the Notes and Our Indebtedness—Fraudulent transfer or fraudulent conveyance laws may permit a
court to void the Notes and/or the guarantees thereof (or the related security interests with respect to the Secured
Notes) and, if that occurs, you may not receive any payments on the Notes.” After the Acquisition Closing Date, the
Issuer will cause each Restricted Subsidiary (unless such Subsidiary is an Excluded Subsidiary or is already a
Guarantor) that is a guarantor or a borrower under the New Term Loan Credit Agreement to execute and deliver to
the Trustee a supplemental indenture, pursuant to which such Restricted Subsidiary will guarantee performance and
payment of the Unsecured Notes on the same senior unsecured basis. See “—Certain Covenants—Future
Guarantees.”

**Issuance in euro; payment on the Euro Unsecured Notes**

Initial holders of the Euro Unsecured Notes will be required to pay for the Euro Unsecured Notes in euro,
and all payments of principal of, premium, if any, and interest, will be payable in euro; provided, that if on or after
the Issue Date, (i) the euro is unavailable to the Issuer due to the imposition of exchange controls or other
circumstances beyond its control or (ii) the euro is no longer being used by the then member states of the European
Monetary Union that have adopted the euro as their currency or for the settlement of transactions by public
institutions of or within the international banking community (clauses (i) and (ii), each a “Euro Unavailability
_Event”), then all payments in respect of the Euro Unsecured Notes will be made in U.S. dollars until the end of such_
Euro Unavailability Event. The amount payable on any date in euro will be converted into U.S. dollars at the rate
mandated by the U.S. Federal Reserve Board as of the close of business on the second business day prior to the
relevant payment date or, in the event the U.S. Federal Reserve Board has not mandated a rate of conversion, on the
basis of the most recent U.S. dollar/euro exchange rate published in The Wall Street Journal (or, if not published by
the Wall Street Journal, other national news source) on or prior to the second business day prior to the relevant
payment date. Any payment in respect of the Euro Unsecured Notes so made in U.S. dollars during the continuance
of a Euro Unavailability Event will not constitute a Default or Event of Default under the Euro Unsecured Notes or
the Unsecured Indenture. In no event shall the Trustee or paying agents be responsible for monitoring any exchange
rates or effecting any conversions.

_Payment”) in cash equal to 101% of the aggregate principal amount of Unsecured Notes repurchased, plus accrued_

(1) accept for payment all Unsecured Notes or portions of Unsecured Notes properly tendered
pursuant to the Change of Control Offer;

(2) deposit with the paying agent an amount equal to the Change of Control Payment in respect of all

with an Officer’s Certificate stating the aggregate principal amount of Unsecured Notes or

The paying agent will promptly deliver to each holder of Unsecured Notes properly tendered the Change of

Except as described above with respect to a Change of Control, the Unsecured Indenture will not contain

The definition of “Change of Control” includes a phrase relating to the direct or indirect sale, lease,
transfer, conveyance or other disposition of “all or substantially all” of the properties or assets of Parent and its
Subsidiaries taken as a whole, to any Person other than one or more Permitted Holders. Although there is a limited
body of case law interpreting the phrase “substantially all,” there is no precise established definition of the phrase
under applicable law. Accordingly, the ability of a holder of Unsecured Notes to require the Issuer to repurchase its
Unsecured Notes as a result of a sale, lease, transfer, conveyance or other disposition of less than all of the assets of
Parent and its Subsidiaries taken as a whole to another Person or group may be uncertain. See “Risk Factors—Risks
Related to the Notes and Our Indebtedness—Holders of the Notes may not be able to determine when a change of
control giving rise to their right to have the Notes repurchased has occurred following a sale of “substantially all” of
our assets.”

The occurrence of a Change of Control under the Unsecured Indenture may also constitute a default under
the New Credit Agreements that permits the lenders to accelerate the maturity of borrowings thereunder. As a result,
following a Change of Control, the Issuer may not be able to repurchase the Unsecured Notes unless all
indebtedness outstanding under the New Credit Agreements is first repaid and any other Indebtedness that contains
similar provisions is repaid, or we obtain a waiver from the holders of such indebtedness to provide the Issuer with
sufficient cash to repurchase the Unsecured Notes. In addition, the Secured Notes will have similar requirements
regarding the Issuer’s obligation to offer to purchase such Secured Notes upon the occurrence of a Change of
Control. See “Risk Factors—Risks Related to the Notes and Our Indebtedness—We may not be able to repurchase
the Notes upon a change of control or pursuant to an asset sale offer.”

The Issuer’s obligation to make a Change of Control Offer may be waived or modified or terminated with
the written consent of the holders of a majority in aggregate principal amount of the Unsecured Notes then
outstanding (including consents obtained in connection with a tender offer or exchange offer for the Unsecured
Notes) prior to the occurrence of such Change of Control.

**_Asset Sales_**

Parent will not, and will not permit any of its Restricted Subsidiaries to, consummate an Asset Sale unless:

(1) Parent (or the Restricted Subsidiary, as the case may be) receives consideration (including by way
of relief from, or by any other person assuming responsibility for, any liabilities, contingent or otherwise) at the time
of the Asset Sale at least equal to the Fair Market Value of the assets sold or otherwise disposed of; and

(2) except in the case of a Permitted Asset Swap, in the case of any single transaction that involves
assets having a fair market value of more than the greater of (x) $45.0 million and (y) 7.5% of Consolidated
EBITDA, at least 75% of the consideration received in the Asset Sale by Parent or such Restricted Subsidiary is in
the form of cash or Cash Equivalents. For purposes of this provision, each of the following will be deemed to be
cash:

(a) any liabilities (as shown on Parent’s or such Restricted Subsidiary’s most recent balance
sheet or in the footnotes thereto for which internal financial statements are available) of Parent or such Restricted

been reflected on Parent’s or such Restricted Subsidiary’s balance sheet (or in the footnotes thereto) (other than
liabilities that are by their terms subordinated to the Unsecured Notes or any Unsecured Note Guarantee)) that are
assumed by the transferee with respect to the applicable disposition and for which Parent and the Restricted
Subsidiaries shall have been validly released by all applicable creditors in writing,

(b) any securities, notes, other obligations or assets received by Parent or such Restricted
Subsidiary from such transferee that are convertible by Parent or such Restricted Subsidiary into cash or Cash

The agreements governing our Indebtedness, including the New Credit Agreements and the Secured
Indenture, contain, and future agreements may contain, prohibitions of certain events, including events that would
constitute a Change of Control or an Asset Sale. The exercise by the holders of Unsecured Notes and holders of
Secured Notes of their right to require the Issuer to repurchase the Unsecured Notes and Secured Notes,
respectively, upon a Change of Control or an Asset Sale could cause a default under these other agreements, even if
the Change of Control or Asset Sale itself does not cause a default, due to the financial effect of such repurchases on
us. In the event a Change of Control or Asset Sale occurs at a time when the Issuer is prohibited from purchasing
Unsecured Notes or Secured Notes, we could seek the consent of lenders under the New Credit Agreements or such
other Indebtedness to the purchase of Unsecured Notes or Secured Notes or could attempt to refinance the
borrowings that contain such prohibition. If we do not obtain a consent or repay those borrowings, the Issuer will
remain prohibited from purchasing Unsecured Notes or Secured Notes. In that case, the Issuer’s failure to purchase
tendered Unsecured Notes and Secured Notes would constitute an Event of Default under the Unsecured Indenture
and the Secured Indenture, respectively, which could, in turn, constitute a default under the New Credit Agreements
and such other Indebtedness. Finally, the Issuer’s ability to pay cash to the holders of Unsecured Notes and the
holders of Secured Notes upon a repurchase may be limited by the Issuer’s then existing financial resources. See
“Risk Factors—Risks Related to the Notes and Our Indebtedness—We may not be able to repurchase the Notes
upon a change of control or pursuant to an asset sale offer.”

Because the Obligations under the New Credit Agreements and the Secured Indenture are secured by
substantially all of the Issuer’s and the Guarantors’ properties and assets, and since the definition of “Net Proceeds”
excludes all amounts in respect of any Asset Sale that are used to repay any Indebtedness that is secured by property
or assets that are the subject of such Asset Sale, it is unlikely that any meaningful amount of Net Proceeds will be
generated from any Asset Sale so long as the New Credit Agreements and Secured Notes remain outstanding.

The Issuer’s obligation to make an Asset Sale Offer may be waived or modified or terminated with the
written consent of the holders of a majority in aggregate principal amount of the Unsecured Notes then outstanding
(including consents obtained in connection with a tender offer or exchange offer for the Unsecured Notes) prior to

**Certain Covenants**

**_Changes in Covenants When Unsecured Notes Rated Investment Grade_**

If on any date following the Acquisition Closing Date:

(1) a Series of Unsecured Notes have Investment Grade Ratings from both of the Ratings Agencies;
and

(2) no Default or Event of Default shall have occurred and be continuing,

then, beginning on that day and continuing at all times thereafter and subject to the provisions of the second
succeeding paragraph, (i) the Unsecured Note Guarantees will be automatically and unconditionally released and
discharged and (ii) the covenants specifically listed under the following sections in this offering memorandum
(collectively, the “Suspended Covenants”) will be suspended with respect to such Series of Unsecured Notes:

(1) “—Repurchase at the Option of Holders—Asset Sales”;

(2) “—Restricted Payments”;

(3) “—Incurrence of Indebtedness and Issuance of Disqualified Stock or Preferred Stock”;

(4) “—Dividend and Other Payment Restrictions Affecting Restricted Subsidiaries”;

(5) “—Transactions with Affiliates”;

(6) “—Future Guarantees”;

(7) “—Designation of Restricted Subsidiaries and Unrestricted Subsidiaries”; and

(8) clause (4) of the covenant described below under “—Merger, Consolidation or Sale of Assets.”

During any period that the foregoing covenants have been suspended, the Board of Directors of the Issuer
or any direct or indirect parent of the Issuer may not designate any of Parent’s Subsidiaries as Unrestricted
Subsidiaries pursuant to the covenant described below under “—Designation of Restricted Subsidiaries and
Unrestricted Subsidiaries” unless the Board of Directors of the Issuer or any direct or indirect parent of the Issuer
would have been able, under the terms of the Unsecured Indenture, to designate such Subsidiaries as Unrestricted
Subsidiaries if the Suspended Covenants were not suspended. Notwithstanding that the Suspended Covenants may
be reinstated, the failure to comply with the Suspended Covenants during the Suspension Period (as defined below)
(including any action taken or omitted to be taken with respect thereto and including any actions taken at any time
pursuant to any contractual obligations arising during the Suspension Period) will not give rise to a Default or Event
of Default under the Unsecured Indenture.

Notwithstanding the foregoing, if the applicable Series of Unsecured Notes no longer have an Investment
Grade Rating from both of the Ratings Agencies, the foregoing covenants will be reinstituted as of and from the date
of such rating decline (any such date, a “Reversion Date”). The period of time between the suspension of covenants
as set forth above and the Reversion Date is referred to as the “Suspension Period.” All Indebtedness incurred
(including Acquired Debt) and Disqualified Stock or preferred stock issued during the Suspension Period will be
deemed to have been incurred or issued in reliance on the exception provided by clause (2) of the definition of
“Permitted Debt.” Calculations under the reinstated “Restricted Payments” covenant will be made as if the
“Restricted Payments” covenant had been in effect prior to, but not during, the period that the “Restricted Payments”
covenant was suspended as set forth above. For purposes of determining compliance with the covenant described
above under “—Repurchase at the Option of Holders—Asset Sales,” the Excess Proceeds from all Asset Sales not
applied in accordance with such covenant will be deemed to be reset to zero after the Reversion Date. In addition,
for purposes of the covenant described under “—Transactions with Affiliates,” all agreements and arrangements

-----

entered into by Parent and any Restricted Subsidiary with an Affiliate of Parent during the Suspension Period prior
to such Reversion Date will be deemed to have been entered pursuant to clause (12) of the second paragraph of “—
Transactions with Affiliates,” and for purposes of the covenant described under “—Dividend and Other Payment
Restrictions Affecting Restricted Subsidiaries,” all contracts entered into during the Suspension Period prior to such
Reversion Date that contain any of the restrictions contemplated by such covenant will be deemed to have been
entered pursuant to clause (1) of the second paragraph of “—Dividend and Other Payment Restrictions Affecting
Restricted Subsidiaries.”

During the Suspension Period, any reference in the definition of “Unrestricted Subsidiary” to the covenant
described under “—Incurrence of Indebtedness and Issuance of Disqualified Stock or Preferred Stock” or any
provision thereof shall be construed as if such covenant had remained in effect since the Issue Date and during the

Upon the Reversion Date, the obligation to grant Unsecured Note Guarantees pursuant to the covenant
described under “—Future Guarantees” will be reinstated (and the Reversion Date will be deemed to be the date on
which any guaranteed Indebtedness was incurred for purposes of the covenant described under “—Future
Guarantees”).

Notwithstanding that the Suspended Covenants may be reinstated, no Default or Event of Default will be
deemed to have occurred as a result of any failure to comply with the Suspended Covenants during any Suspension
Period and Parent and its Restricted Subsidiaries will be permitted, without causing a Default or Event of Default or
breach of any of the Suspended Covenants (notwithstanding the reinstatement thereof) under the Unsecured

contractual commitments or obligations following a Reversion Date and to consummate the transactions

Payment shall be made under clause (c) of the first paragraph or under the second paragraph of the covenant

The Issuer shall provide an Officer’s Certificate to the Trustee indicating the occurrence of any Suspension
Period or Reversion Date. The Trustee shall have no obligation to monitor the ratings of the Unsecured Notes,
independently determine or verify if such events have occurred or notify the holders of Unsecured Notes of any
Suspension Period or Reversion Date. The Trustee may provide a copy of such Officer’s Certificate to any holder of
Unsecured Notes upon written request.

There can be no assurance that either Series of Unsecured Notes will ever achieve an Investment Grade
Rating or that any such rating will be maintained.

**_Incurrence of Indebtedness and Issuance of Disqualified Stock or Preferred Stock_**

Parent will not, and will not permit any of its Restricted Subsidiaries to, directly or indirectly, create, incur,

(collectively, “incur”) any Indebtedness (including Acquired Debt), and Parent will not issue any Disqualified Stock

Subsidiary of Parent may incur Indebtedness (including Acquired Debt) or issue Disqualified Stock, and any NonGuarantor Subsidiary of Parent may issue shares of preferred stock, if either (1) the Fixed Charge Coverage Ratio
for Parent’s most recently ended four full fiscal quarters for which internal financial statements are available
immediately preceding the date on which such additional Indebtedness is incurred or such Disqualified Stock or

1.00 or (y) at the election of the Issuer if such Indebtedness, Disqualified Stock or preferred stock is incurred in
connection with a Permitted Investment, the Fixed Charge Coverage Ratio in effect immediately prior to the
consummation of such transaction or (2) the Consolidated Total Debt Ratio for Parent and its Restricted
