###### Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements

 Retirement Plans and Other Post-Retirement Benefits

 In connection with the acquisition of AWT, the Company assumed certain defined benefit and defined contribution plan obligations for current and former employees of non-U.S. subsidiaries. All defined contribution pension plan obligations for current and former employees in the United States, as well as certain defined benefit and contribution pension plan obligations of former employees of non-U.S. subsidiaries, were retained by Ashland.

 In connection with the JV, certain employees of the former BASF Paper and Water Chemicals business transferred to subsidiaries of Solenis on January 31, 2019 and employment agreements were entered into between the respective parties on that date. As applicable, certain defined benefit plan obligations related to the transferred employees were acquired by the Company in connection with the JV are primarily within continental Europe. While the majority of the transferred employees are employed by Solenis' subsidiaries in the United States ("US") or the United Kingdom ("UK"), no defined benefit plan obligations were transferred to Solenis for any US, or UK based employees. Employees in these jurisdictions participate only in employer-sponsored defined contribution plans.

 Defined benefit plans specify an amount of pension benefit that an employee will receive on retirement, usually dependent on factors such as age, years of service and compensation. The net obligation in respect of defined benefit plans is calculated separately for each plan by estimating the amount of the future benefits that employees have earned in return for their service in the current and prior periods. These benefits are then discounted to determine the present value of the obligations and are then adjusted for the impact of any unamortized prior service costs. The net obligation is then determined with reference to the fair value of the plan assets (if any). The discount rate used is the yield on bonds that are denominated in the currency in which the benefits will be paid and that have maturity dates approximating the terms of the obligations.

 Share-based Compensation

 The Company recognizes share-based compensation expense for all options and other arrangements within the scope of Accounting Standards Codification ("ASC") 718. Awards are classified as equity if such options are settled in shares and classified as liabilities if they are settled in cash. Share-based compensation expense for equity-classified awards is measured at the date of grant, based on the fair value of the award, and is recognized using the "straight-line attribution method" over the employee’s requisite service period. Awards classified as liabilities are measured for fair value at each reporting date, with any changes to fair value recognized currently in earnings based on the extent of the requisite service period elapsed. The fair value of awards classified as liabilities are presented as a component of Accrued expenses on the Consolidated Balance Sheets.

 Share-based awards with vesting conditions other than service are recognized over the performance period based on the probability that those conditions will be achieved.

 For additional information on the Company`s share-based compensation plan, see Note 16.

 Fair Value Measurements

 U.S. GAAP defines a fair value hierarchy that prioritizes the inputs to valuation techniques used to measure fair value. The hierarchy gives the highest priority to unadjusted quoted prices in active markets for identical assets or liabilities (Level 1 measurements) and the lowest priority to unobservable inputs (Level 3 measurements). A financial instrument’s level within the fair value hierarchy is based on the lowest level of any input that is significant to the fair value measurement.


-----

###### Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements

 The following valuation techniques are used to measure fair value for assets and liabilities:

 Level 1—Quoted market prices in active markets for identical assets or liabilities;

 Level 2—Significant other observable inputs (e.g., quoted prices for similar items in active markets, quoted prices for identical or similar items in markets that are not active, inputs other than quoted prices that are observable such as interest rate and yield curves, and market-corroborated inputs); and

 Level 3—Unobservable inputs for the assets or liabilities which are valued based on management’s estimates of assumptions that market participants would use in pricing the asset or liability.

 Net Asset Value ("NAV") - The Company invests in funds which are not quoted on an active market. These funds are valued based on the underlying fair value of the funds investments less the funds liabilities or net asset value.

 Derivatives

 The Company is exposed to the effects of changes in interest rates, foreign currency, changes in commodity prices and credit risk. The Company utilizes interest rate swap agreements to hedge a portion of its exposure to fluctuating interest rates on its long term debt. Refer to specific discussion of these arrangements within Note 12. Cash flows from derivatives are recognized in the Statement of Cash Flows as part of Cash Flows from Operations.

 Sale of Accounts Receivable

 The Company accounts for sales of accounts receivables when control of receivables is surrendered. Whether control has been relinquished requires, among other considerations, an evaluation of the relevant legal considerations and an assessment of the nature and extent of the Company's continuing involvement with the assets transferred. Assets obtained and liabilities incurred in connection with the transfers reported as sales are initially recognized in the Consolidated Balance Sheets at fair value.

 Accounts receivable sold are deemed transferred to the counterparty in accordance with the prevailing purchase agreement applicable to the relevant jurisdiction. In situations where cash is immediately received from the counterparty upon sale of the receivable, such cash is classified as cash received from operating activities. In situations where cash is not received immediately from the counterparty upon sale of the receivable, the transfer is deemed to represent a non-cash investing activity whereby the receivable is sold for a subordinated interest in future cash collections. Ultimate collections of cash on the subordinated interest in future cash collections are treated as cash flows from investing activities.

 Recently Adopted Accounting Standards

 Announced Accounting Standards

 In May 2014, the FASB issued accounting guidance outlining a single comprehensive five step model for entities to use in accounting for revenue arising from contracts with customers (ASC 606 Revenue from Contracts with Customers) (the "new revenue standard"). The new revenue standard supersedes most current revenue recognition guidance, in an effort to converge the revenue recognition principles within U.S. GAAP. This new guidance also requires entities to disclose certain quantitative and qualitative information regarding the nature, amount, timing and uncertainty of qualifying revenue and cash flows arising from contracts with customers. Entities have the option of using a full retrospective or a modified retrospective approach to adopt the new guidance. In June 2020,


-----

###### Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements

 the FASB issued ASU 2020-05, which results in a one-year deferral of the revised revenue recognition standard. As a result, the provisions of the new guidance were effective for the Company on October 1, 2020, immediately subsequent to the most recent fiscal year results presented within these consolidated financial statements. In adopting the new standard, management reviewed material contracts to identify key provisions that could cause differences in revenue recognition. Management is finalizing its review of the cumulative impact of the adoption of this standard and expects substantial changes to the substance and form of the Company's disclosures relative to the current presentation. 

 During February 2016, the FASB issued ASU 2016-02, "Leases". The initial guidance and the subsequent amendments and deferrals issued, require that companies recognize right of use assets and lease liabilities relative to at least all leasing arrangements with terms in excess of 12 months. The guidance is expected to eliminate the majority of off-balance sheet financing arrangements and provide clarity around actual contractual obligations of the business. This guidance is effective for all private entities for fiscal years beginning after December 15, 2021. In connection with its adoption of ASC 606 on October 1, 2020, management also determined to early adopt ASC 842 on the same date. In adopting the standard, management determined to adopt the package of practical expedients provided by the FASB and will utilize a "modified retrospective transition approach" such that balance sheet as of September 30, 2020 will not be recasted in connection with the adoption of the standard.

 In June 2016, the FASB issued ASU 2016-13, "Measurement of Credit Losses on Financial Instruments." The guidance requires immediate recognition of estimated credit losses that are expected to occur over the remaining life of many financial assets. This new guidance is effective for private companies for fiscal years beginning after December 15, 2020, but early adoption is permitted. Management is evaluating the impact this standard would have on the Company's financial condition, results of operations and cash flows; the most notable impact of this ASU will relate to the Company's processes around the assessment of the adequacy of the allowance for doubtful accounts on trade receivables.

 In August 2017, the FASB issued ASU 2017-12, "Targeted Improvements to Accounting for Hedging Activities." The update changes the process by which the Company identifies and designates a component for hedging activity; allowing companies to specify a component of overall cash flows for which the Company is trying to manage some form of risk. Adoption of this standard is required for fiscal years beginning after December 15, 2019 for private companies. Early adoption is permitted for any interim or annual period. Retrospective application is required upon adoption. Management is currently evaluating the impact of adopting this standard.

 In August 2018, the FASB issued ASU 2018-13, "Disclosure Framework - Changes to the Disclosure Requirements for Fair Value Measurement". The update removed the disclosure requirements from Topic 820 for the valuation process for Level 3 fair value measurements. Adoption of this standard is required for fiscal years beginning after December 15, 2019. Early adoption is permitted upon issuance of the update. Retrospective application is required upon adoption. Management is currently evaluating the impact of adopting this standard.

 In August 2018, the FASB issued ASU 2018-14, "Disclosure Framework - Changes to the Disclosure Requirements for Defined Benefit Plans." The update removed the disclosure requirements from Subtopic 715-20 for the amounts in accumulated other comprehensive income expected to be recognized as components of net periodic benefit cost over the next fiscal year and removed the disclosure requirements for the amount and timing of plan assets expected to be returned to the employer. Adoption of this standard is required for fiscal years beginning after December 15, 2020. The Company adopted this standard during the year ended September 30, 2020. There is no impact of early adoption other than the removal of a potential current year disclosure.

 In August 2018, the FASB issued ASU 2018-15, "Intangibles - Goodwill and other Internal-Use-Software Customer's Accounting for Implementation Costs Incurred in a Cloud Computing Arrangement That Is a Service


-----

###### Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements

 Contract." The guidance aligns the requirements for capitalizing implementation costs in a cloud computing arrangement service contract with the requirements for capitalizing implementation costs incurred for an internal use software license. Capitalized implementation costs should be amortized over the term of the service agreement on a straight line basis and should be assessed for impairment in a manner similar to long-lived assets. This new guidance is effective for private companies in fiscal years beginning after December 15, 2020. Early adoption is permitted. Management is currently evaluating the impact of adopting this standard.

 In October 2018, the FASB issued ASU 2018-16, "Derivatives and Hedging : Inclusion of the Secured Overnight Financing Rate (SOFR) Overnight Index Swap (OIS) Rate as a Benchmark Interest Rate for Hedge Accounting Purposes". Previously under Topic 815, the eligible benchmark interest rates in the United States were the interest rates on direct Treasury obligations of the U.S. government (UST), the LIBOR swap rate, the OIS Rate based on the Fed Funds Effective Rate, and the Securities Industry and Financial Markets Association (SIFMA) Municipal Swap Rate, which was introduced in ASU 2017-12, Derivatives and Hedging: Targeted Improvements to Accounting for Hedging Activities (“ASU 2017-12”). The amendments in ASU 2018-16 permit the use of the OIS rate based on SOFR as a benchmark interest rate for hedge accounting purposes under Topic 815. The guidance is effective at the same time as adoption of ASU 2017-12. Management is currently evaluating impact of adopting this standard.

 Chemsystems' Pulp and Paper Business

 Poliquimicos

These adjustments to the purchase price which have not been settled in cash at September 30, 2020 represent non-cash investing activities for the year ended September 30, 2020.  Prior Year Business Combinations

 On January 31, 2019 Solenis, through its holding and operating Companies, acquired BASF's Paper & Water Chemicals Business ("BASF Paper & Water"). The acquisition advances the Company's strategic position in the global specialty chemical marketplace and provides significant advancements to manufacturing capability, sourcing channels, sales channels, economies of scale, and other operational efficiencies. A joint, pre-combination valuation exercise between the Company and BASF resulted in the determination of BASF Paper & Water's stand-alone enterprise value of approximately $900 million. After working capital and other adjustments, the final fair value of the assets acquired was determined to be $881.7 million.

 To acquire the net assets of BASF Paper & Water, Solenis issued 40,113,302 Ordinary shares in the Company, representing 49% of Ordinary shares outstanding after the issuance. The net book value of BASF's equity in the combined business was determined to be $677.8 million, representing 49% of the pre-combination equity value of the combined business. The remaining consideration was comprised of cash of $213.5 million prior to final working capital adjustments. ###### In connection with the acquisition, the Company recognized $150.8 million of Goodwill, representing the excess consideration transferred over the fair value of net assets acquired. Of the acquired Goodwill, $77.1 million is deductible for tax purposes. Goodwill is primarily attributable to anticipated revenue growth from the combined product portfolio and the assembled workforce of BASF Paper & Water and Solenis.

 The fair value of intangible assets, exclusive of Supply Agreements and Reverse Supply Agreements, were estimated using an income approach, either the excess earnings method or the relief from royalty method. Under the excess earnings method, an intangible asset’s fair value is equal to the present value of the incremental after- tax cash flows attributable solely to the intangible asset over its remaining useful life. Under the relief from royalty method, fair value is measured by estimating future revenue associated with the intangible asset over its useful life and applying a royalty rate to the revenue estimate. These intangible assets collectively enable the Company to manufacture and develop new products to meet evolving business needs as well as competitively produce our existing products.

 The Supply agreements require BASF to sell finished goods at a below-market rate to Solenis, generally at the approximate cash costs to produce the finished goods, over a specified period of time. Such agreements are intended to allow the Company to uninterruptedly sustain the acquired businesses without disruption in instances where BASF Paper and Water assets were retained by BASF as part of the JV. The fair value ascribed to these assets was determined using the with-or-without method, whereby cash flows to Solenis both with, and without the existence of the underlying agreements. The fair value ascribed to these assets is amortized through Cost of sales, straight-line, over their respective contractual lives. Refer to Note 7 for additional information.

 Reverse supply agreements require the Company to sell finished goods at a below-market rate to BASF, generally at the approximate cash costs to produce the finished goods, over a specified period of time. Such agreements are intended to allow BASF to uninterruptedly sustain the businesses that they've retained after the acquisition which were serviced significantly by BASF Paper & Water. The fair value ascribed to these liabilities was determined using the with-or-without method, whereby cash flows to Solenis both with, and without the existence of such obligations. The fair value ascribed to these liabilities are amortized through Net sales, straight-line, over their respective contractual lives. Refer to Note 7 for additional information.

 Note 5  Sale of Trade Receivables

 On March 26, 2018, the Company sold certain accounts receivable under the terms of a Receivables Purchase Agreement ("RPA" or "Accounts Receivable Financing") with ING Luxembourg ("ING"). The RPA carried a maximum capacity of $120.0 million and was scheduled to expire on September 30, 2020.

 On March 20, 2020, the Company entered into an amended agreement with ING and a new agreement with MUFG Bank, Ltd (“MUFG”), through which ING will continue to service non-US markets with a maximum funding capacity of €110 million and further sell its interest in US markets to MUFG. The maximum funding capacity carried by MUFG to serve the US market is $75 million. As of September 30, 2020, the total capacity of the amended RPA agreements among the Company, ING and MUFG is $204.1 million, both of which are scheduled to expire in March of 2022.

 Through the Accounts Receivable Financing facilities with both counterparties, the Company sells eligible short- term trade receivables on the initial transfer date to either ING or MUFG in exchange for consideration inclusive of cash conveyed to Solenis (referred to as the Initial Purchase Price, or "IPP") and a beneficial interest in the receivables collected by either ING or MUFG (referred to as the Deferred Purchase Price, or "DPP"). The Company continues to service the receivables sold in connection with the arrangement. The RPA requires Solenis to pledge its cash collection accounts for the underlying receivables to ING for the non-US market and to MUFG for US markets, whereby neither the receivables sold to ING or MUFG nor the future cash collections on the sold receivables are assets of Solenis post-transfer.

 Through maturity, ING and MUFG purchases new receivables from Solenis on a daily, weekly, or monthly basis, depending on the jurisdiction, in exchange for incremental DPP. These amounts are settled monthly against sold receivables which were previously collected.

 The DPP is carried at fair value, which is remeasured weekly to take into account activity during the period (the Company's interest in the newly-transferred receivables and collections on previously transferred receivables attributable to the DPP), as well as changes in estimates of future interest rates and anticipated credit losses. Refer to Note 12 for additional discussion surrounding the fair value of the DPP.

 Receivables are sold to ING and MUFG with the condition that Solenis indemnify ING and MUFG in the event of non-collection. Consequently, non-collections on sold receivables could expose the Company to losses. The maximum potential loss surrounding this transaction is equal to the face amount of receivables sold. The Company has evaluated the probability of loss, concluding the risk of material losses associated with this sale is remote. Credit losses and delinquencies with respect to receivables sold in the arrangement for year ended September 30, 2020 is $0.9 million, and were less than $0.1 million for the years ended 2019, and 2018.

###### The Company primarily defines its reporting units as its two primary operating segments: P&P and IWT, divided into four geographic regions: North America, EMEA (Europe, Middle East, and Africa), Asia Pacific (APAC), and Latin America (LA). The Company's ninth reporting unit is its collective Reverse Supply Agreement business. The Company does not disaggregate the results of its RSA business at a regional level for review by a chief operating decision maker ("CODM").

 As discussed in Note 2, the Company recorded impairment of Goodwill of $19.2 million, and $27.7 million, for the years ended September 30, 2020, and 2018, respectively. There was no impairment of Goodwill for 2019.

 In connection with Solenis' Goodwill impairment assessment as of July 1, 2018, the Company determined that the carrying value of the LA IWT and APAC P&P reporting units were each individually in excess of their fair values. As a result of this assessment, Solenis recorded a pre-tax impairment charge for Goodwill during the year ended September 30, 2018 of $27.7 million. Of this amount, $13.9 million was ascribable to LA IWT and $13.8 million was ascribable to APAC P&P. As of September 30, 2018, the remaining goodwill, net of accumulated impairment charges ascribed to LA IWT and APAC P&P were both $0.

 Subsequent to the full impairment of the Goodwill previously ascribed to APAC P&P, the acquisition of the BASF P&W business on January 31, 2019 again resulted in the determination to ascribe Goodwill to APAC P&P. In connection with our Goodwill impairment assessment as of July 1, 2020, the Company determined that the carrying value of the APAC P&P reporting unit was in excess of its fair value. As a result of this assessment, Solenis recorded a pre-tax impairment charge for Goodwill during the year ended September 30, 2020 of $19.2 million. As of September 30, 2020, the remaining Goodwill, net of accumulated impairment charges ascribed to APAC P&P was $0.

 Both the impairment charges recorded during the years ended September 30, 2020, and 2018 were driven by revisions to post-acquisition and post-investment (specific to long-lived assets) cash flow projections resulting from unrealized market-participant synergy objectives and changes in the broader macro-economic environment in which the Company operates.

###### Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements

 The Company estimates the fair value of its reporting units by using both income and market-based methodologies. Solenis' income approach is based on an estimate of future cash flows, discounted to the present using a risk-adjusted market rate. Key assumptions involved in this determination include forecasted revenue, cost of sales, operating expenses (net of depreciation and amortization expenses), and adjusting these items for annual working capital needs and investments in property, plant, and equipment. Such forecasts are rooted in the macroeconomic factors, such as expectation of growth of gross domestic product in a particular region during the forecast period, industry factors, such as the expectation of increased demand from a particular region over the forecast period, and company-specific factors, such as the expectation for additional investment in a particular region based on discussions with management. These future cash flows are discounted to present value using a weighted average cost of capital, determined by a capital asset pricing model. Inputs into the capital asset pricing model include market-observed assumptions such as the risk-free rate of return, premia for credit risk, equity risk, small stock, and country risk, as applicable, and systematic and unsystematic returns on capital observed in market-comparable companies; all of these assumptions are observable in the marketplace.

 Such assumptions are based off of expectations of future company, industry, and macroeconomic growth in the future which may not ultimately be realized and, in such a circumstance, could reasonably be expected to negatively affect the future cash flows of the reporting unit.

 The discount rate used in these analyses represents the weighted average cost of capital for the relevant reporting units considering the risks and uncertainties inherent in the cash flows and in the internally developed forecasts. The discount rate is determined based on market factors which exist at the time of the analysis, including a risk- free rate tied to US treasuries, market-observed equity risk premia, and country risk premia where applicable, and other unsystematic adjustments added to account for Company-specific and region-specific factors. The weighted average capitalization is determined based on the debt and equity capitalization of comparable companies. Increases to the risk-free rate or other risk premia, through actions by central banks or reactions to the marketplace by investors, whether globally or concentrated in a particular geographic region, could increase the discount rate in the analysis and negatively impact the evaluation for a particular reporting unit. Similarly, legislation which would decrease tax rates in a particular reporting unit could increase the weighted average cost of capital, negatively impacting the valuation.

 Solenis' market-based approach employs a valuation technique based on multiples of earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortization (EBITDA) and revenue for comparable companies that is consistent with the objective of measuring fair value. Solenis' use of this market based methodology is restricted to circumstances in which comparable companies have observable operations and economic characteristics which are similar to those of Solenis. All comparable companies operate in the specialty chemicals industry. Changes in investor confidence regarding the industry or the market as a whole could cause equity values for these companies to fall relative to their overall performance. Such changes could negatively affect the valuation of Solenis and its reporting units.

 When necessary, the use of unobservable inputs resulted in the fair value estimate being classified as a Level 3 asset measured at fair value on a nonrecurring basis subsequent to its original recognition. The determination of whether or not goodwill is impaired involves a significant level of judgment in the assumptions underlying the approaches used to determine the estimated fair value of our reporting units. Solenis believes that assumptions and rates used in the impairment assessment are reasonable. However, these assumptions are judgmental and variations in any assumptions could result in materially different calculations of fair value. The Company will continue to evaluate Goodwill on an annual basis as of July 1, and whenever events or changes in circumstances occur, such as significant adverse changes in operating results, market conditions or changes in management’s business strategy, indicate that there may be a probable indicator of impairment. It is possible that the assumptions used by management related to the evaluation may change or that actual results may vary significantly from management’s estimates.

###### On July 31, 2014, International and Solenis Holdings 3 LLC, then a subsidiary of International, entered into a First Lien Credit Agreement ("First Lien Credit Agreement due 2021"), comprised of a $630.0 million loan ("First Lien Dollar Loan due 2021"), a €230.0 million loan ("First Lien Euro Loan due 2021"), and a $200.0 million Revolving Credit Facility ("Revolving Credit Facility due 2019"). On that same day, International and Solenis Holdings 3 LLC entered into a Second Lien Credit Agreement comprising a $470.0 million loan (the "Second Lien Credit Agreement due 2022"). Subsequent to these transactions, the Company entered into two additional


-----

###### Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements

 term loans under the First Lien Credit Agreement due 2021: one for €85 million during the second quarter of 2015 and one for €100 million during the third quarter of 2016. These agreements are collectively referred to as the "Old Debt".

 On June 26, 2018, Solenis Holdings LLC, a wholly-owned subsidiary of the Company, entered into the First Lien Credit Agreement (the "First Lien Credit Agreement") which includes a $200 million Revolving Credit Facility (the "Revolving Credit Facility"), and a Second Lien Credit Agreement through which the company borrowed aggregate principal amount of $1.8 billion, with original maturity dates of December 2023, and June 2024 for the First Lien Credit Agreement, and Second lien Credit Agreement, respectively. The First and Second Lien Credit Agreements were consummated to provide net proceeds which facilitated the Joint Venture between Solenis and BASF and allow for an extension of the terms of each of the credit agreements and the Revolving Credit Facility. These agreements are collectively referred to as the "New Debt". The proceeds from each of these borrowings were used in combination with one another to repay the remaining principal balance on the Company's Old Debt. 

 As part of the closing of the Joint Venture on January 31, 2019, the Company borrowed an incremental $170 million and €330 million under the First Lien Credit Agreement, and increased the borrowing capacity of the Revolving Credit Facility from $200 million to $375 million, at which time the Company borrowed an incremental $124 million on the Revolving Credit Facility. The closing of the Joint Venture also extended the maturity date of all term loans under the First Lien Credit Agreement (except for the Revolving Credit Facility) by 18 months, from December 26, 2023 to June 26, 2025, and extended the maturity date of the Second Lien Credit Agreement by 24 months, from June 25, 2024 to June 26, 2026.

 For both the June 26, 2018 refinancing and the incremental borrowing on January 31, 2019 the Company applied the guidance prescribed by Accounting Standards Codification ("ASC") 470-50, Modifications and Extinguishments, to determine the appropriate accounting treatment regarding unamortized deferred financing costs and original issue discounts related to the original borrowing. As a result of these transactions, the Company recorded a loss on extinguishment of debt of $0.6 million and $10.7 million during the years ended September 30, 2019, and September 30, 2018, respectively. These amounts primarily related to deferred financing costs and original issue discount ascribable to lenders who did not participate in the June 26, 2018 refinancing or the January 31, 2019 incremental borrowing. These amounts are included as part of Non-operating expense (income), net in the Consolidated Statements of Operations for the years ended September 30, 2019 and 2018, respectively. All deferred financing costs and original issue discount associated with portions of the debt determined to be modified were allocated to the First Lien Credit Agreement due 2025 and Second Lien Credit Agreement due 2026 to be amortized over the life of the associated agreements.

 On February 5, 2020, the Company entered into an agreement to supplement its First Lien Credit Agreement which resulted in incremental gross proceeds of $150 million and €100 million. The Company used the proceeds to pay down outstanding borrowings on its Revolving Credit facility by the same amount as the incremental proceeds. An incremental debt discount of $1.3 million and incremental deferred financing costs of $1.6 million were capitalized consistent with the guidance prescribed above within ASC 470-50, Modifications and Extinguishments. All other terms of the First Lien Credit Agreement remained consistent, including but not limited to, the outstanding indebtedness thereunder being due June 26, 2025.

 First Lien Credit Agreement

 Obligations under the First Lien Credit Agreement are guaranteed by the Company's wholly-owned UK subsidiaries, subject to certain exceptions (collectively, the "Subsidiary Guarantors"), and, solely by recourse to the equity of the Company, by Solenis UK Industries Limited, a wholly-owned subsidiary of the Company, and Solenis Holdings Sub II B.V. (collectively, the "Holdings Guarantors"). The First Lien Credit Agreement is collateralized by substantially all of the assets of the Company and the Subsidiary Guarantors, subject to certain


-----

###### Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements

 exceptions, as well as the equity of the Company held by the Holdings Guarantors. Principal is paid on the last day of each quarter in an amount equal to $2.8 million and €2.0 million for the First Lien Dollar Loan and First Lien Euro Loan, respectively.

 Interest rates on all term loans under the First Lien Credit Agreement are variable. The First Lien Dollar Loan carries an interest rate of 4%, plus the greater of the USD London Interbank Offered Rate ("LIBOR") or 0%. The First Lien Euro Loan carries an interest rate of 4.25% plus the greater of the Euro London Interbank Offered Rate ("EURIBOR") or 0.5%. Interest elections are made on the last day of the second month of every quarter and are effective for three months.

 Term loans under the First Lien Credit Agreement mature on June 26, 2025. The Company is permitted to prepay all term loans under the First Lien Credit Agreement at any time. Through September 30, 2020, the Company has not made any voluntary prepayments on the First Lien Loans in normal course.

 The First Lien Loans are subject to mandatory prepayments equal to 50% of the Company's Excess Cash Flow, as defined in the First Lien Credit Agreement, subject to certain conditions, beginning in the fiscal year ended September 30, 2019. As of September 30, 2020, a mandatory prepayment of $12.4 million is required and will be remitted during the first fiscal quarter of 2021. There was no mandatory prepayment required as of September 30, 2019. As such, the Company's current portion of long-term debt as of September 30, 2020 is inclusive of this mandatory prepayment.

 The obligations under the First Lien Credit Agreement are effectively senior to all of the Company's Second Lien Debt and unsecured debt, in each case to the extent of the value of the collateral securing such obligations.

 In addition, if, at the end of any quarter, borrowings under the Revolving Credit Facility exceed 35% of the aggregate amount available, or $326.8 million, the First Lien Credit Agreement requires the Company to maintain a Consolidated First Lien Leverage Ratio, as defined in the First Lien Credit Agreement, of 7.30 to 1. The First Lien Credit Agreement also includes customary negative and affirmative covenants including, among others, limitations on the Company's ability to: (i) incur additional debt; (ii) create liens; (iii) make certain investments, loans and advances; (iv) sell assets; (v) pay dividends or make distributions or other restricted payments; (vi) engage in mergers or consolidations; or (vii) change the nature of our business. As of September 30, 2020, the Company is in compliance with all positive and negative and affirmative covenants under the First Lien Credit Agreement.

 The Revolving Credit Facility allows maximum borrowings of $375.0 million and matures on June 26, 2023. The interest rate on the Revolving Credit Facility is, at the election of the Borrower, ABR plus 2.5% per annum or LIBOR plus 3.5% per annum. As of September 30, 2020, the company had $34.2 million of revolver borrowings outstanding on the Revolving Credit Facility.

 The Company had $326.8 million of borrowings available under the Revolving Credit Facility due 2023 as of September 30, 2020. This amount consisted of $340.8 less undrawn standby letters of $14.0 million.

 Second Lien Credit Agreement

 The Second Lien Credit Agreement carries the same guaranty and security package as the First Lien Credit Agreement. No principal payments are due in connection with the Second Lien Credit Agreement until maturity. The Second Lien Credit Agreement matures on June 26, 2026.


-----

###### Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements

 The Company is permitted to prepay the Second Lien Credit Agreement at any time. Prepayments made prior to June 26, 2020 would have incurred a 2% penalty of the principal balance prepaid. Prepayments made after June 26, 2020 but prior to June 26, 2021 will incur a 1% penalty on the principal balance prepaid. Prepayments made after June 26, 2021 are free of penalty. The prepayment penalty is assessed regardless of whether or not the prepayment was mandatory or voluntary.

 The interest rate on the Second Lien Credit Agreement is 8.5% plus the greater of LIBOR or 0%. Interest elections are made on the last day of the second month of every quarter and are effective for three months. The Second Lien Credit Agreement is junior in priority to the First Lien Credit Agreement and senior to all other unsecured debt.

 The Second Lien Credit Agreement includes customary negative and affirmative covenants including, among others, limitations on the Company's ability to: (i) incur additional debt; (ii) create liens; (iii) make certain investments, loans and advances; (iv) sell assets; (v) pay dividends or make distributions or other restricted payments; (vi) engage in mergers or consolidations; or (vii) change the nature of our business.

 As of September 30, 2020, there are no co-borrowers on either the First Lien Credit Agreement or the Second Lien Credit Agreement and the company is in compliance with all related covenants therein.

 Equipment Financing

 On December 31, 2019, the Company entered into a $25.0 million equipment financing (leaseback) arrangement with a third party maturing on December 31, 2023. In accordance with ASC 840-40-25-5, Sale-Leaseback Transactions, the transaction was accounted for as a financing arrangement and is reflected as debt on the Consolidated Balance Sheet as of September 30, 2020. Solenis did not account for this transaction as a "sale" as the Company retains the risks and benefits of ownership during the term of the arrangement and has a bargain- purchase option at maturity to re-acquire legal title to the collateralized assets. In connection with the transaction, the Company paid $0.5 million in deferred financing fees which were capitalized at the transaction date and will be amortized over the term of the arrangement.

 Deferred Financing Costs and Original Issue Discount

 • Financing costs and original issue discount carried over from the Old Debt related to portions which were determined to be modified. These amounts generally relate to portions of the debt held by lenders who participated in both syndicates comprising the Old Debt and the June 26, 2018 borrowing;

 • Financing fees paid in connection with December 31, 2019 Equipment Financing.

 Note 11  Employee Benefit Plans

 Pension Plans

 Qualifying employees participate in specific defined-benefit pension plans, which typically provide pension payments based on an employee’s length of service and compensation during the years immediately preceding retirement or have a cash balance design.

 In connection with the Acquisition, we assumed certain defined benefit plan obligations for both current and former employees of certain subsidiaries. All defined benefit pension plan obligations for current and former employees in the U.S., as well as certain defined benefit pension plan obligations of former employees of non- U.S. subsidiaries, were retained by Ashland.

 The defined benefit obligations for remaining current employees of non-U.S. subsidiaries assumed by Solenis were carved out of defined benefit pension plans retained by Ashland. The Company has created new defined benefit pension plans for all affected participants. The Acquisition Agreement required Ashland to transfer assets from Ashland’s funded defined benefit pension plans to our defined benefit pension plans. The determination of asset transfers was completed as of September 30, 2014 for all plans.

 On January 1, 2015, the Company created a new defined benefit plan for certain participants in the Netherlands. Amounts recorded in our consolidated financial statements as of, and for the year ended September 30, 2020, and 2019 include balances and activity specific to this plan.

 In connection with the JVFA, Solenis assumed defined benefit plan obligations for transferred employees in six countries. Where funded, BASF transferred plan assets to Solenis. In the aggregate, the Company assumed a net obligation of $2.4 million related to the transferred employees which was recorded against Goodwill on the


-----

###### Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements

 Consolidated Balance Sheet. Transferred employees with existing BASF-sponsored defined benefit plans were primarily transferred to existing Solenis plans as of January 31, 2019. Amounts recorded within the Company's consolidated financial statements as of, and for the years ended September 30, 2020, and 2019 include balances and activity specific to the transferred employees.

 Post-Retirement Plans

 Solenis also assumed in connection with the Acquisition certain long-term employee health care and life insurance benefits for certain eligible employees. Certain programs are noncontributory and other programs share the cost with retirees through payment of premiums, deductibles and coinsurance provisions. Where not restricted by law or by separate agreements with the workforce, the Company also committed to maintain comparable employee benefits to what was provided for preexisting employees for a period of eighteen months from the date of the Acquisition.

###### Investment Strategy

 In developing an investment strategy for its defined benefit plans, the Company considered the following factors: the nature of the plans’ liabilities, the allocation of liabilities between active, deferred and retired members, the funded status of the plans, the applicable investment horizon, the respective size of the plans and historical and expected capital market returns. Pension plan assets are managed by outside investment managers, which are monitored against investment return benchmarks and our established investment strategy. Investment managers are selected based on an analysis of, among other things, their investment process, historical investment results, and frequency of management turnover, cost structure and assets under management. Assets are periodically reallocated between investment managers to maintain an appropriate asset mix and diversification of investments and to optimize returns.

 Plan assets include both fixed income and traditional equity securities that are allocated across both domestic and international markets. Additionally, certain pension plan assets are dictated by applicable regulations within the respective country.

The Company's believes that these instruments qualify as Level 2 measurements.  Derivatives and Hedging Activities

 In order to reduce the Company's exposure to fluctuations in the cash flows associated with changes in interest rates, Solenis may create offsetting positions through the use of derivative financial instruments. The Company does not enter into derivative financial instruments for trading or speculative purposes.

 In November 2014, the Solenis entered into three interest rate swap arrangements to hedge interest rate exposure related to a portion of the Company's long-term debt. As a result of these arrangements, the Company effectively converted $440.0 million of its US Dollar denominated debt from a floating interest rate to a fixed LIBOR rate of 2.59% for a 2.5 year period from November 30, 2016 through May 30, 2019.

 On June 26, 2018, a wholly-owned subsidiary of the Company entered into the First and Second Lien Credit Agreements, the proceeds from which were used to pay off outstanding principal amounts on the First Lien Dollar Loan due 2021. More information regarding this refinancing event can be found in Note 10. Despite the payoff of the First Lien Dollar Loan due 2021, (i) the Company still bore interest rate risk exposure through its wholly- owned subsidiary; (ii) the First Lien Dollar Loan due 2023 still carried an outstanding principal balance in excess of the $440.0 million notional amount in the interest rate and; (iii) interest payments under the First Lien Dollar Loan due 2023 carried a variable interest rate tied to LIBOR. As such, the Company determined that the hedge continued to be effective after the refinancing and, therefore, Solenis continued to apply cash flow hedge accounting through the maturity date of the swaps. As of May 30, 2019, these swaps were effectively settled with no amounts due to, or due from the counterparty.

 During the first quarter of 2019, the Company entered into three interest rate swap arrangements to hedge the variable interest rate risk exposure specific to the Company's First Lien US Dollar-denominated debt. The aggregate notional value for the three interest rate swap agreements is $600.0 million. As a result of these


-----

###### Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements

 arrangements, the Company collectively converted $600.0 million of its US Dollar-denominated debt from a floating three-month LIBOR interest rate to fixed rates of 3.26%, 3.12%, and 3.13%, respectively for the 36- month period from May 31, 2019 through May 31, 2022.

 These contracts have been designated and qualify as cash flow hedges. On both a retrospective and prospective basis, the Company measures hedge effectiveness by formally assessing, at least quarterly, the probable high correlation of the expected future cash flows of the hedged item and the derivative hedging instrument. The effective portion of the gain or loss on the derivative instrument is deferred as a component of other comprehensive loss or income until the settlement of the related business transaction at which time the accumulated gain or loss from the contracts will be reclassified into earnings. There was no ineffective portion of the gain or loss on the derivative instrument recognized during the years ended September 30, 2020, 2019 and 2018, respectively.

 For the years ended September 30, 2020, 2019, and 2018 the Company reclassified expense of $12.6 million, $1.7 million, and $3.3 million from Accumulated other comprehensive loss through Interest expense on the Consolidated Statements of Operations based on the paid and accrued interest recognized on the Company's interest rate swap liability.

 As of September 30, 2020, the Company expects losses of $18.6 million presented within Accumulated other comprehensive (loss) to be reclassified to net income or loss during the next 12 months.

 Deferred Purchase Price on Accounts Receivable Financing

 On March 26, 2018, the Company entered into an arrangement to sell accounts receivable under the terms of a RPA with ING. The RPA carried a maximum capacity of $120.0 million and was scheduled to expire on September 30, 2020. Refer to Note 5 for additional details.

 On March 20, 2020, the Company entered into an amended agreement with ING and a new agreement with MUFG Bank, Ltd (“MUFG”), through which ING will continue to service non-US markets for the maximum capacity of €110 million and further sell its interest in US markets to MUFG. The maximum RPA capacity carried by MUFG is $75 million to serve the US market. The total capacity of the RPA agreements among the Company, ING and MUFG is $204.1 million. The RPA agreement with MUFG and the amended RPA agreement with ING are scheduled to expire in March of 2022. Refer to Note 5, Sale of Trade Receivables for additional details.

 Initial consideration received from ING and MUFG through the Accounts Receivable Financing included a subordinated interest in transferred receivables collected, referred to as the Deferred Purchase Price. The DPP is carried at fair value and is remeasured weekly to reflect activity during the period (i.e. the Company's interest in subsequently-transferred receivables and collections on receivables previously sold to ING or MUFG) as well as changes in estimates of future interest rates and anticipated credit losses. The fair value of the DPP is predicated upon the underlying receivables which have been transferred to ING or MUFG. As the underlying receivables represent the Company's customers with the highest credit quality and are generally collectible within 90 days, the Company expects the fair value of the DPP to be equal to its face value.

 Receivables under the Accounts Receivable Financing are transferred to ING or MUFG daily, weekly, or monthly in accordance with the prevailing agreement for each jurisdiction. The consideration for the transfer of these receivables is incremental DPP to be settled at each settlement date, as defined in the RPAs.

 As the receivables transferred to ING and MUFG do not have an active market for equivalent or similar assets, the Company's fair value assessment is predicated upon its own history of collection surrounding the specific customers' receivables which have been transferred. Accordingly, such inputs qualify as Level 3 inputs. Due to the high credit quality and the relatively short-term nature of the underlying receivables, fluctuations in credit quality are expected to have an immaterial effect on the fair value of the DPP.

 As of September 30, 2020 and 2019, the DPP is carried at $164.5 million and $191.8 million, respectively. These amounts are included in Sold receivables on the Consolidated Balance Sheets.

###### Unconditional Purchase Obligations and Commitments

 In connection with the consummation of the Joint Venture with BASF on January 31, 2019, the Company entered into a number of "take or pay" contracts (the "Supply Agreements") through which BASF will make certain materials required to service acquired BASF legacy customers available to Solenis based upon a combination of legacy BASF volumes for these materials and available manufacturing capacity. The term of these agreements is either three (the "Medium Term"), or eight years (the "Long Term"). Upon maturity, each of the Medium Term agreements will automatically extend for 12 months on a revolving basis unless either party provides 24 months notice of their intention to exit the agreement. There is no penalty for either party to exit provided the 24 month notice period is met. Upon maturity, each of the Long Term agreements will expire immediately unless otherwise mutually agreed to by Solenis and BASF.

 Given the substantial capital and working capital requirements necessary to maintain available capacity and meet Solenis' purchasing requirements, the Company is required to remit minimum monthly payments (the "Fixed Manufacturing Costs") designed to cover BASF's plant overhead costs specific to the impacted production lines. The monthly payments are fixed and determinable, based on allocations of BASF's heritage costing structure relative to expected production and volumes and vary only based upon annual changes in inflation rates observable in the public domain.

 Fixed Manufacturing Costs are recognized as a component of Cost of sales on the Consolidated Statements of Operation. Total Fixed Manufacturing Costs incurred during the years ended September 30, 2020 and 2019, were $72.0 million and $49.0 million, respectively.

###### Environmental Remediation

 Due to the nature of Solenis' business, the Company is subject to various laws and regulations pertaining to the environment, manufacturing, sale, transportation and disposal of hazardous products. These laws pertain to, among other things, air and water, management of solid and hazardous wastes, transportation, and human health and safety. The total reserves for environmental remediation reflect estimates of the most likely costs that will be incurred over an extended period to remediate identified conditions for which the costs are reasonably estimable, without regard to any third-party recoveries.

 Environmental remediation reserves are subject to numerous inherent uncertainties that affect our ability to estimate its share of the costs. Such uncertainties involve the nature and extent of contamination at each site, the extent of required cleanup efforts under existing environmental regulations, widely varying costs of alternate cleanup methods, changes in environmental regulations, the potential effect of continuing improvements in remediation technology, and the number and financial strength of other potentially responsible parties at multi- party sites. 

 Under the terms of the initial carve-out from Ashland, the Company is indemnified for certain pre-existing environmental remediation costs. Certain of these indemnified costs are required to exceed a deductible of 2% of the purchase price paid in the acquisition in order for indemnification to be available.

 In connection with the JV, BASF transferred various production facilities to Solenis. During the diligence process related to the acquisition, Solenis performed diligence related to potential environmental or other continent liabilities. As no probable or estimable exposure existed at the acquisition date, Solenis is not indemnified with respect to any environmental or other contingent matters. As of both September 30, 2020 and 2019, the Company does not have material contingent obligations which are both probable and estimable related to these production facilities, transferred employees, or other real property acquired from BASF.

 As of both September 30, 2020 and 2019, the Company has recorded environmental remediation reserves of $1.8 million, related to two ongoing and probable environmental remediation proceedings. These reserves are included as part of other non-current liabilities on the Consolidated Balance Sheets. Given the limited time frame over


-----

###### Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements

 which remediation activities are expected to be performed, the Company has not discounted any projected future cash outflows in determining these reserves as of September 30, 2020.

 Of the $1.8 million reserved, $1.0 million relates to potential exposure surrounding groundwater and soil contamination associated with a plant in Araraquara, Brazil. The remaining $0.8 million relates to management's best estimate for potential exposure related to ground contamination at the Company's Milwaukee, Wisconsin plant as well as a reserve for a potential Environmental Protection Agency matter. The amount reserved for both matters represents management's best estimate of total expenses to be incurred, made with the assistance of a third-party specialist.

 Indemnification assets associated with environmental remediation claims are recorded on the Consolidated Balance Sheets as part of Other assets in the amounts of $1.0 million and $1.4 million as of September 30, 2020 and 2019, respectively.

 Other Legal Proceedings

 In addition to the matters described above, there are various claims, lawsuits and administrative proceedings that are pending or threatened. Such actions seek remedies or damages, some of which are for substantial amounts.

 The Company has accrued for legal reserves of $3.5 million and $1.9 million as of September 30, 2020 and 2019, respectively. While Solenis cannot predict with certainty the outcome of such actions, the Company believes that adequate reserves have been recorded and losses already recognized with respect to such actions.

 In addition to its uncertain tax positions which are referenced within Note 20, the Company has accrued for various contingent liabilities related to indirect taxes. As of September 30, 2020, the Company has accrued for potential exposure related to these positions of $5.7 million, of which Solenis is indemnified for $3.6 million by the former owners of Solenis' business combinations since inception. As of September 30, 2019, the Company had recorded liabilities specific to these positions of $10.4 million, and was indemnified for $8.5 million of these obligations. As of both September 30, 2020, and 2019, these obligations and the related indemnification assets are recorded as a component of Other non-current liabilities, and Other assets, respectively, on the Consolidated Balance Sheets.

 Insurance

 Solenis maintains deductibles for general liability, business interruption and property damage to owned, leased and rented property. These deductibles could be material to our earnings, but they are not material to our overall financial position. The Company carries substantial excess general liability, property and business interruption insurance above our deductibles. In addition, Solenis meets all statutory requirements for automobile liability and workers’ compensation.

 Note 16  Share-based Compensation

 Stock Incentive Plan

 Effective July 8, 2014, the Company's board of directors adopted the Solenis Holdings Top II B.V. Stock Incentive Plan pursuant to which the Company's board of directors shall select officers and key employees and directors to participate in the plan and grant stock options and offer opportunities to purchase shares. The plan allows for the issuance of up to 6,500,000 Class B shares under the plan (for all share-based compensation and share purchases). All stock options granted have a term not greater than ten years. Stock options vest and become exercisable, in whole or in part, with vesting conditions set by the Company's board of directors.

 The options are provided in two separate grants which have differing vesting conditions. Service Options, which reflect 75% of all options granted, vest in four equal annual installments, coinciding with the first anniversary date


-----

###### Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements

 of the grant date and each successive anniversary thereafter. Performance Options, which represent the remaining 25% of the options granted, vest upon the conclusion of each of the four fiscal years subsequent to the grant date based on the achievement of specified "EBITDA" (earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization; subject to management adjustments) targets during the fiscal year in which they vest. The extent of vesting is based on the Company's financial performance relative to EBITDA targets stipulated by the Board of Directors. The vesting of both Service and Performance Options are contingent upon continuous employment through the respective measurement dates.

 On January 31, 2019, the Solenis Holdings Top II B.V. Stock Incentive Plan was superseded by the Solenis UK International Limited Stock Incentive Plan ("the Plan") as part of the closing of the Joint Venture. All outstanding Service Options to purchase shares in Solenis Holdings Top II B.V. were converted to options to purchase ordinary shares in the Company. Service Options which were vested were exchanged for fully vested options. Unvested Service Options were exchanged for Service Options with identical vesting periods to the canceled awards. As of September 30, 2020, 1,650,105 shares or options were available for grant.

 In connection with the JV, all holders of Class A and B shares were provided with a return of capital conveyed in cash to facilitate the required equity holdings amongst the JV participants (CD&R, BASF and management shareholders). In addition, and to uphold the anti-dilutive provision of the Plan, the intrinsic value of all Class B options was kept constant through a reduction of option exercise prices equal to the per-share value of the return of capital conveyed to all Class A and B equity holders. In circumstances where this was not possible due to limitations under Section 409(a) of the Internal Revenue Code, the Company compensated option holders in cash totaling $4.4 million. This cash is considered to be a return of capital and presented as a reduction to Additional paid-in capital on the Consolidated Balance Sheets.

 The Company applied the guidance prescribed by ASC 718, Compensation - Stock Compensation, to determine the appropriate accounting treatment regarding the cancellation of the old awards and simultaneous grant of new awards. Based on the prescribed guidance, the Company determined that the two transactions, in combination, represent a modification of the original award. Subsequent accounting for modifications is predicated upon the fair value of the original award immediately before and the new award immediately after the modification. Management's analysis concluded that the fair value of the new award did not exceed the fair value of the old award on the modification date. Therefore, the Company will continue to ratably recognize the unrecognized stock-based compensation expense for the original awards based on the fair value of the awards as of the original grant date over the remaining vesting period.

 Compensation expense for the years ended September 30, 2020, 2019, and 2018 was $2.2 million, $2.6 million, and $4.0 million, respectively.

 In addition, as part of the closing of the Joint Venture, all unvested Performance Options to purchase shares in Solenis Holdings Top II B.V. were canceled and new Performance Options were granted to replace the canceled awards. The exchange of Service and Performance Options for new awards are collectively referred to as the "Modification".

###### Stock Options

 Stock incentive plan allows stock option grants for shares at a price based on the most recent valuation of the Company's ordinary shares at the time of the grant and may be subject to anti-dilution. Stock options under the plan become exercisable over four equal annual installments. Every option equals one share. Our policy is to recognize compensation expense on a straight-line basis over the requisite period for the entire award. Forfeitures are recognized as they occur.

 Share-based compensation expense is recognized as a component of Selling, general, and administrative expense. The Company records compensation expense related to all stock awards based on the grant date fair value of the awards. Compensation expense for Service Options is recognized over the requisite service period, while expense for Performance Options is recognized over the performance period based on successful achievement of performance-based conditions or targets.

 Restricted Stock Units

 In February 2020, certain members of the management team were granted a total of 1.1 million Restricted Stock Units (RSU) with a term of seven years and vesting contingent upon a combination of a liquidation event (Performance Obligation), the implied per-share equity value of the liquidation event at a pre-defined minimum threshold amount (Market Condition), and that a grantee continues to render service until the date of the liquidation event (Service Condition).

 Vesting of the RSU's range between 70% - 100%, where 70% is at minimum pre-defined exit price per share and 100% is at maximum pre-defined exit price per share.

 In the event of vesting, grantees shall receive cash proceeds within 75 days of the liquidity event. Although, at the discretion of the Board, the cash proceeds may be required for an equity contribution back to the Company. Grantees that leave the Company either voluntarily or involuntarily prior to vesting conditions are met will forfeit their respective grants.

 In accordance with ASC 718, Stock Compensation, vesting of these awards is contingent upon performance obligations and market conditions which are outside of management's control and such conditions cannot be assumed or estimated based on lack of history and potential outcomes. As the likelihood of achievement of the Performance condition cannot be assessed as "probable", no compensation expense will be recognized until the performance condition is achieved. As such, no expense was recognized with respect to these awards during the year ended September 30, 2020.

 Note 19  Related Parties

 As of September 30, 2020, voting control in Solenis is held collectively by CD&R which owns 49.5% of all outstanding shares, and management which owns 1.5% of the outstanding shares. Management has legally assigned their voting rights to CD&R, allowing CD&R to 51% control of outstanding voting rights. As a result of the JV, BASF owns 49% of the outstanding shares of Solenis.

 Relationship with CD&R

 On July 31, 2014, International, through its subsidiary, Solenis Switzerland Holdings GmbH, entered into a management and consulting agreement with CD&R pursuant to which CD&R provides, on a nonexclusive basis, management, consulting and advisory services to Solenis Switzerland Holdings GmbH and certain of its divisions and subsidiaries. Under the agreement, the Company is required to pay an annual advisory fee in the amount of $3.5 million plus 1% of the transaction value of any acquisitions, dispositions, or financing transactions incurred during the year for services provided (the “Advisory Fee”). Under the terms of the agreement, the Company is also required to reimburse CD&R for its out-of-pocket expenses.

 Advisory fees incurred for the years ended September 30, 2020, 2019, and 2018 were $3.6 million, $3.8 million and $3.7 million, respectively. These fees are included as a component of selling, general and administrative expense for all reporting periods presented.

 Transactions with CD&R or any of its affiliate companies are conducted on terms similar to those of third party transactions. For the year ended September 30, 2020, there was no purchase of goods and services from CD&R. For the years ended September 30, 2019 and 2018, Solenis purchased goods and services from CD&R affiliates of $3.6 million, and $2.9 million, respectively. Related to these purchases, the Company had no total payables due to affiliates of CD&R as of both September 30, 2020, and 2019, respectively.

 As of September 30, 2020 and 2019, a wholly-owned subsidiary of CD&R held $100.0 million of principal of the Company's Second Lien Credit Agreement. The terms of the Second Lien Credit Agreement are consistent with the unrelated lenders in the syndicate.

 Exclusive of these agreements, Solenis is not aware of any material transactions with CD&R or any of its affiliate companies which were not conducted on terms similar to those conducted with third-parties.

 Relationship with BASF

 On January 31, 2019 as part of the JV, Solenis entered into a management and consulting arrangement with BASF pursuant to which BASF provides, on a nonexclusive basis, management, consulting and advisory services to Solenis and certain of its divisions and subsidiaries. Under the agreement, Solenis is required to pay an annual

 advisory fee in the amount of $3.5 million. The advisory fees incurred during the year ended September 30, 2020 and 2019 were $3.5 million and $2.3 million, respectively, and are included as a component of Selling, general and administrative expense on the Consolidated Statements of Operations.

 As part of the JV, Solenis prepaid for an option to purchase an existing BASF manufacturing facility located in Nanjing, China. This option is exercisable 36 months from the JV close date with nominal consideration due upon exercise. Due to administrative delays, Solenis did not legally acquire the Nanjing Purchase Option at close.  As part of the closing of the Joint Venture, BASF and Solenis entered into various Supply agreements and Reverse supply agreements which provide finished goods and raw materials to each business to ensure continuity of operations. Accordingly, the JV provides that the price of the finished goods subject to Supply and Reverse Supply Agreements will be consistent with BASF's historical product costing. The difference between the estimated market price and cost is captured in the form of an asset and liability and amortized over the life of the agreement. ###### Note 20  Income Taxes

 Under ASC 740, the Company uses the asset and liability method of accounting for income taxes, under which deferred tax assets and liabilities are recognized for the future tax consequences of (i) temporary differences between the financial statement carrying amounts and the tax bases of existing assets and liabilities and (ii) operating loss and tax credit carryforwards. Deferred income tax assets and liabilities are based on enacted tax rates applicable to the future period when those temporary differences are expected to be recovered or settled. The effect of a change in tax rates on deferred tax assets and liabilities is recognized in income in the period the rate change is enacted. A valuation allowance is provided for deferred tax assets when it is more likely than not the deferred tax assets will not be realized. 

 Solenis is a limited company domiciled in the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland. The Company’s subsidiaries are subject to taxation in the U.S., U.K. and various other foreign jurisdictions, which are aggregated in the “Foreign” information captioned below.

 The Company recorded income tax expense of $6.8 million, $21.4 million and $8.6 million for the years ended September 30, 2020, 2019 and 2018, respectively.

 Unrecognized tax benefits

 U.S. GAAP prescribes a recognition threshold and measurement attribute for the accounting and financial statement disclosure of tax positions taken or expected to be taken in a tax return. The evaluation of a tax position is a two-step process. The first step requires Solenis to determine whether it is more likely than not that a tax position will be sustained upon examination based on the technical merits of the position. The second step requires Solenis to recognize in the financial statements each tax position that meets the more likely than not


-----

###### Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements

 criteria, measured at the amount of benefit that has a greater than 50% likelihood of being realized.  The Company recognized deferred tax assets in the periods ending September 30, 2018 and 2017 related to tax benefits attributable to intercompany mergers. While the Company intends to pursue the matter through available legal channels, the benefits do not meet the criteria for recognition resulting in an Unrecognized Tax Benefit and similarly has not recognized benefit for the 2018 transaction. As of September 30, 2020, the Company has recorded incremental penalties and interest as a result of the previously Unrecognized Tax Benefits from the 2017 and 2018 transactions.

 As of September 30, 2020, the Company has recognized a tax indemnification asset of $3.6 million to reflect an offsetting asset for acquired non income-tax liabilities for which Solenis is indemnified. Of this amount, $1.0 million relates to the AWT purchase from Ashland and $2.6 million relates to the 2015 acquisition of a Brazilian specialty chemicals manufacturer and distributor ("Quimatec"). As of September 30, 2020, all amounts related to the uncertain tax positions, interest, and penalties have been satisfied. Pursuant to the indemnification agreements, the Company is entitled to reimbursement in connection with any negative outcome related to these liabilities generated prior to the acquisition. As future changes to the indemnity receivable will impact Non- operating expense (income), net, the Company may experience volatility in earnings as a result of the tax indemnification from Ashland/Quimatec. For the liability estimated as of September 30, 2020, it is reasonably possible that there could be material changes to the amount of uncertain tax positions due to activities of the taxing authorities, settlement of audit issues, reassessment of existing uncertain tax positions, or the expiration of applicable statute of limitations; however, Solenis is not able to estimate the impact of these items at this time.

 U.S. Tax Reform

 On December 22, 2017, the U.S. government enacted comprehensive tax legislation commonly referred to as the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act (the “Tax Act”). The Tax Act included significant changes to the U.S. corporate income tax system including, among other things, lowering the U.S. statutory federal tax rate and implementing a territorial tax system. The U.S. statutory rate has been decreased to 21% for fiscal year 2019 and thereafter. A phased in tax rate of 24.5% was utilized for the year ended September 30, 2018 due to the Company’s fiscal year versus calendar year end. In fiscal year 2018, Solenis recorded the effect of this legislation through deferred taxes as a tax benefit of $4.5 million at September 30, 2018. Certain of the Tax Act’s new provisions, including Base Erosion Anti-Avoidance Tax (“BEAT”), Interest Expense Limitations and Foreign Derived Intangible Income (“FDII”) are effective beginning in fiscal year 2019. For fiscal year 2020, the Company has recorded no impact related to BEAT as the ratio of foreign payments to total deductions does not exceed the 3% base erosion percentage threshold. Additionally, no impact from FDII was recorded due to the lack of calculated deemed intangible income.

 COVID-19 Legislation

 During the year ended September 30, 2020, tax relief legislation was passed in a number of countries to combat the effects of the COVID-19 pandemic, including the United States’ Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security (CARES) Act, which was enacted on March 27, 2020. The Company evaluated the legislative provisions in the CARES Act and implemented a number of changes deemed applicable, including the temporary increase of the interest expense limitation from 30% to 50%, the temporary removal of the 80% limitation on net operating losses, and the temporary deferral of the Company's social security tax responsibilities. The Company has reflected the impact of these changes within its consolidated financial statements for the year ended September 30, 2020. 

 Note 21  Hyperinflationary Environment in Argentina

 On May 16, 2018, as documented in its meeting minutes, the International Practices Task Force categorized Argentina as a country with a highly-inflationary economy. Accounting Standards Codification 830, Foreign Currency Matters, requires entities domiciled in these jurisdictions to change their functional currency to the reporting currency of its parent entity on a prospective basis beginning in the quarter after this determination has been made.

 Solenis Argentina, S.A. ("Solenis Argentina") is a wholly-owned subsidiary of the Company; selling direct to end customers exclusively in Argentina. The Company does not have a plant in this specific subsidiary and, accordingly, the majority of its net assets are current to support local distribution activities. Revenues specific to Solenis Argentina totaled $12.5 million, $10.5 million, and $7.6 million for the years ended September 30, 2020, 2019, and 2018, respectively.


-----

###### Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements

 Transactions are predominately consummated in Argentinian Pesos (the "Peso") and, accordingly, the Peso is ordinarily the functional currency of this entity. However, in accordance with ASC 830, the Company changed the functional currency of this entity to the United States Dollar effective July 1, 2018. This change resulted in a remeasurement loss of $3.2 million, $3.1 million, and $1.4 million during the years ended September 30, 2020, 2019, and 2018, respectively, resulting from fluctuations in foreign currency exchange rates since July 1, 2018.

 The Company will continue to evaluate the inflationary environment in Argentina for any changes to this status. Until such time in which it is determined that the economy is no longer highly inflationary, the functional currency of Solenis Argentina will remain the United States Dollar.
