 Note 1  Business Background

 General Description of the Business

 Solenis UK International Limited ("Solenis" or "the Company") is domiciled in the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland (the "UK"). The Company was formed on August 31, 2018 for the specific purpose of consummating a Joint Venture (the "Joint Venture", "JV", or "JVFA") between BASF SE ("BASF") a German- based chemical manufacturer and distributor, and the Solenis business, which was 97% owned by Clayton, Dubilier & Rice, LLC ("CD&R") and 3% owned by management immediately prior to the JV.

 Prior to the formation of the Company, the Solenis business existed under the name Solenis International LLC (formerly a limited liability company known as CD&R Seahawk Bidco, LLC and a limited partnership known as Solenis International, L.P.) ("International"), a Delaware limited liability company. International was formed on February 14, 2014 and was domiciled in the Netherlands. International and certain other holding companies and partnerships (the "Holding Companies") were formed by affiliates of CD&R. The Holding Companies, collectively, were formed for the purpose of acquiring the business of Ashland Water Technologies ("AWT"), a business formerly owned by Ashland, Inc. ("Ashland"), including certain assets of AWT and all of the capital stock and equity interests of certain entities engaged in the AWT business from Ashland. International, through its wholly-owned subsidiaries, acquired AWT on July 31, 2014 for $1,734.8 million (the “Acquisition”). The Holding Companies have no business operations or assets other than cash, cash equivalents, certain related party loans between and among the Holding Companies and Solenis, and investments in the ownership interests described above. The Company’s global operations are conducted by wholly-owned subsidiaries.

 Immediately prior to the JV, CD&R, alongside members of the International management team, controlled 100% of the equity interests and voting rights in the Holding Companies and International. To consummate the JV, CD&R and members of the International management team sold their collective interests in International and the Holding Companies to Solenis in exchange for a 51% interest in the JV, represented by a 51% equity interest in Solenis UK International Limited, or Solenis. Historically, the combined and condensed consolidated financial statements of the Solenis business were presented at the level of International. International was the subsidiary of Solenis Holdings I Coöperatief U.A., a Dutch-domiciled holding company owned collectively by CD&R and members of the International management team. As both Solenis and Solenis Holdings I Coöperatief U.A. shared the same ultimate parent in CD&R, this transaction was accounted for as a business combination between entities under common control, as described under Accounting Standards Codification ("ASC") 805, Business Combinations. In accordance with this guidance, net assets acquired maintained their predecessor values and were not assessed for or recorded at fair value.

 On January 31, 2019, BASF conveyed $678 million to Solenis in consideration of a 49% interest in the JV, represented by a 49% equity interest in Solenis UK International Limited, or Solenis. The Company subsequently contributed the $678 million of proceeds to its subsidiaries. One such subsidiary, Solenis Holdings LLC, a US- domiciled limited liability company, obtained third party debt financing proceeds of $525 million, of which $213 million was either loaned or contributed to subsidiaries of the Company and Solenis Holdings LLC. In the aggregate, the subsidiaries of the Company entered into various local asset transfer agreements with BASF through which Solenis acquired the assets of the BASF Paper and Water Chemicals Business in exchange for $891.3 million, less working capital adjustments. Through the various transactions executed on January 31, 2019, BASF sold the assets of its former Paper and Water Chemicals Business to Solenis in consideration of $891.3 million, comprised of a 49% equity interest in the Company and $213 million in cash subject to working capital adjustments. The final agreed upon purchase price was $881.7 million, inclusive of working capital adjustments.

###### Notes to Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements [Unaudited]

 As of January 31, 2019, the Company was owned by CD&R (49.5%), BASF (49%) and members of the JV management team (1.5%).

 Basis of Presentation

 Solenis' Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements include all wholly owned subsidiaries of Solenis, including all Holding Companies. These financial statements have been prepared in accordance with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America (“GAAP”).

 Nature of Operations

 Solenis is a leading supplier of specialty chemicals and services to the pulp and paper, mining, food and beverage, power generation, refining, chemical processing, general manufacturing and municipal markets. It offers chemical and equipment technologies and services designed to help customers improve operational efficiencies, enhance product quality, protect plant assets and minimize environmental impact.

 The accompanying Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements reflect the assets, liabilities, revenues and expenses directly attributed to Solenis.

 To meet the diverse requirements of its customers, Solenis offers a range of services, including start-up and ongoing applications support, analytical and applications laboratories and customized program offerings.

 Solenis’ products include biocides, cleaners, coagulants and flocculants, converting additives, corrosion inhibitors, defoamers, deposit control agents, food and beverage processing aids, internal and surface size agents, membrane treatments, mining and mineral processing aids, monitoring and control systems, odor inhibitors and neutralizers, oxygen scavengers, polyacrylamides, pulp mill additives, retention, drainage and clarification aids, scale inhibitors, sludge dewatering polymers, surface treatments, tissue making additives, wet- and dry-strength additives, colorants, surface size, antiscalants for desalination, and wood adhesives.

 Solenis has 41 manufacturing facilities in 19 countries. Solenis markets and distributes its products and services directly and through third-party distributors in the Americas, Europe, the Middle East, Africa and Asia Pacific.

 Solenis’ business principally consists of three operating segments: Pulp & Paper, Industrial Water, and Reverse Supply Agreements. A brief description for each of these operating segments are as follows:

 Pulp & Paper – The Pulp & Paper ("P&P") business manufactures and sells a broad array of process chemistry for the pulp and paper industry including deposit and scale control agents, defoamers, biocides, retention aids and crepe and release additives. These products are designed to deliver benefits such as enhanced operational efficiencies, system cleanliness and superior performance in a wide variety of manufacturing operations globally. In addition, the Pulp & Paper business offers functional chemistry for packaging, tissue and towel, and printing and writing producers that impart specific properties such as wet or dry strength, colorants, surface size, liquid holdout and printing ability to the final paper or board. Products and technologies include internal and surface sizing agents and wet and dry strength additives.

 Industrial Water – The Industrial Water ("IWT") business offers specialized chemicals for the utility water treatment market including influent water, boiler water, cooling water and effluent water treatments. Products include scale and corrosion inhibitors, coagulants and flocculants, biocides, defoamers, anti-scaling for desalination, membrane treatments and sludge dewatering. In addition, the Industrial Water business offers process additives such as frothers and collection aids, dust control additives, sterilization treatments, corn oil


-----

###### Notes to Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements [Unaudited]

 extraction and scale and corrosion inhibitors for mining and mineral processing, food processing, oil refining, chemicals processing and general manufacturing markets.

 Reverse Supply Agreements - On January 31, 2019, as part of the JV, Solenis agreed to provide certain finished goods to BASF at below-market prices, consistent with BASF's historical cost and pricing structure. Such agreements are intended to allow BASF to uninterruptedly sustain the businesses that they've retained after the acquisition which were serviced significantly by BASF Paper & Water. These arrangements and related activities comprise the Company's Reverse Supply Agreements ("RSA") segment.

 Solenis also manufactures and supplies automated equipment, including performance-based feed and control systems, proprietary monitoring devices and remote system surveillance. The utility products, services and equipment offerings are designed to protect plant assets and optimize energy, water and operational costs at customers’ facilities.

 Solenis’ results are affected by domestic and international economic, political, legislative, regulatory and legal actions. Economic conditions, such as recessionary trends, inflation, foreign exchange rates, and interest rates, can have a significant effect on operations. While Solenis maintains reserves for anticipated liabilities and carries various levels of insurance, Solenis could be affected by civil, criminal, regulatory or administrative actions, claims or proceedings relating to environmental remediation or other matters.

 Note 2  Significant Accounting Policies

 Use of Estimates, Risks and Uncertainties

 The preparation of the Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements requires management to make estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amounts of assets, liabilities, revenues, expenses and the disclosures of contingent assets and liabilities. Significant items that are subject to such estimates and assumptions include impairment of long-lived assets, including goodwill and indefinite-lived intangible assets, computation of income tax provision, and calculation of reserves, including those for environmental remediation. Although management bases its estimates on historical experience and other relevant assumptions that are believed to be reasonable under the circumstances, actual results could differ significantly from these estimates.

 COVID-19

 The spread of the COVID-19 coronavirus, could negatively impact the Company. Any future wide-ranging health scares could potentially adversely affect Solenis' business, financial condition and results of operations. The duration and intensity of this and future disruptions is uncertain, including potential broader impacts like factory closures, reduced workforce, scarcity of raw materials and the potential disruption of transportation of goods. The Company may be indirectly impacted from the reduction of orders from customers as a result of reduced consumer spending. Given the uncertainty regarding these circumstances, the related financial impact cannot be reasonably estimated at this time.

 Principles of Consolidation and Combination

 Solenis' Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements include all wholly owned subsidiaries of Solenis, including all Holding Companies.

 Investments in companies in which Solenis, directly or indirectly, owns up to 50% of the voting stock and has the ability to exercise significant influence over operating and financial policies of the investee are accounted for


-----

###### Notes to Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements [Unaudited]

 using the equity method of accounting. As a result, Solenis’ share of the earnings or losses of such equity affiliates is included in the accompanying Condensed Consolidated Statement of Operations and Solenis' share of these companies’ shareholders’ equity is included in Investments in equity affiliates in the accompanying Condensed Consolidated Balance Sheet.

 All intercompany accounts and transactions have been eliminated in the preparation of the accompanying Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements.

 Foreign Currency Translation

 The Company's reporting currency is the U.S. dollar. Operations outside the United States are generally measured using the local currency as the functional currency. Assets and liabilities of these operations are translated into U.S. dollars at end-of-period exchange rates; income and expenses are translated using the average exchange rates for the reporting period. Resulting cumulative translation adjustments are recorded as a component of Shareholders’ deficit in the Condensed Consolidated Balance Sheet in Accumulated other comprehensive (loss).

 In circumstances where the economy in which one of the Company's subsidiaries operates is determined to be highly inflationary, the functional currency for the entity is changed to the U.S. dollar on a prospective basis. Refer to Note 20 for discussion surrounding the Company's operations in economies which have been determined to be highly inflationary.

 Cash, Cash Equivalents and Restricted Cash

 Cash and cash equivalents represent cash in banks and highly liquid short-term investments with original maturities of three months or less. Cash which has a legal restriction regarding its use or withdrawal is classified as Restricted cash and is classified as Other assets on the Condensed Consolidated Balance Sheet.

###### Accounts Receivable and Allowance for Doubtful Accounts

 Receivables are recognized net of an allowance for doubtful accounts receivable. The allowance for doubtful accounts receivable reflects the best estimate of losses inherent in the accounts receivable portfolio determined on the basis of historical experience, specific allowances for known troubled accounts and other available evidence. Accounts receivable are written down or off when a portion or all of such account receivable is determined to be uncollectible. Bad debt expense is recorded as a component of Selling, general and administration expense on the Condensed Consolidated Statement of Operations.

 Additionally, Solenis maintains various global credit insurance policies which serve to partially indemnify the Company from the risk of loss related to uncollectible trade receivables. The allowance for doubtful accounts receivable is recorded on a gross basis, independent of any considerations regarding potential indemnification


-----

###### Notes to Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements [Unaudited]

 assets resulting from successfully submitted claims under the Company's credit insurance policies. This indemnification asset is recorded as a component of Prepaid expenses and other assets on the Condensed Consolidated Balance Sheet. The related benefit available to the Company for successfully submitted claims is recorded as a contra-expense as a component of Selling, general and administrative expense on the Condensed Consolidated Statement of Operations.

 Inventories, net

 Inventories are valued at the lower of cost and net realizable value, with cost being determined on the weighted average cost method. Inventories deemed to have costs greater than their respective market values are reduced to net realizable value as a loss in the period recognized. Inventories on hand are continually assessed to identify excess or obsolete inventory based on anticipated demand and a provision is recorded for any estimated loss.

 Property, Plant and Equipment

 Property, plant and equipment are recorded at cost. Depreciation is calculated using the straight-line method over the asset's estimated useful life. Estimated useful lives by asset class are summarized below:

Buildings and building improvements 25 to 35 years
Machinery and equipment 3 to 25 years
Software 5 to 10 years

###### The carrying value of property, plant and equipment is periodically reviewed for recoverability when impairment indicators are present. Such indicators include, among other factors, operating losses, unused capacity, market value declines, and technological obsolescence.

 Recorded values of property, plant and equipment that are not expected to be recovered through undiscounted future net cash flows are written down to current fair value, which generally is determined from estimated discounted future net cash flows (assets held for use) or net realizable value (assets held for sale).

 Depreciation expense is presented as a component of Cost of sales or Selling, general and administrative expense on the Condensed Consolidated Statement of Operations, depending upon the use of the underlying asset. There were no impairment charges for Property, plant and equipment during the nine months ended June 30, 2021 or 2020.

 Revenue Recognition

 Revenues are recognized when persuasive evidence of an arrangement exists, products are shipped and title is transferred or services are provided to customers, the sales price is fixed or determinable, and collectibility is reasonably assured. Collateral is generally not required. Sales are reported net of tax assessed by qualifying governmental authorities. For consignment inventory, title and risk of loss are transferred when the products have been consumed or used in the customer’s production process.

 Solenis accrues for sales returns and other allowances based on historical experience. The Company includes the amounts billed to customers for shipping and handling fees in Net sales with costs incurred for the delivery of goods as Cost of sales within the Condensed Consolidated Statement of Operations. 


-----

###### Notes to Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements [Unaudited]

 Expense Recognition

 Cost of sales includes material and production costs, as well as the costs of inbound and outbound freight, purchasing and receiving, inspection, warehousing, internal transfers, and all other distribution network costs. Selling, general and administrative expense includes sales and marketing costs, advertising, customer support, environmental remediation and administrative costs.

 The Company does not sell product with warranties. Accordingly, there are no liabilities for product warranties.

 Advertising costs are expensed as incurred and are reported as a component of selling, general and administrative expenses. Advertising expenses were $0.4 million and $0.3 million for the three months ended June 30, 2021 and 2020, and were $1.0 million and $1.3 million for the nine months ended June 30, 2021 and 2020.

 Research and Development

 Research and development costs incurred during the normal course of business are expensed as incurred. In- process research development projects acquired in a business combination are recorded as intangible assets at their fair value as of the acquisition date. Subsequent costs related to acquire in-process research and development assets are expensed as incurred.

 Litigation

 The Company accrues for liabilities related to litigation matters when available information indicates that the liability is probable and the amount can be reasonably estimated. Legal costs such as outside counsel fees and expenses are charged to expense in the period incurred.

 Income Taxes

 Deferred tax assets and liabilities are recognized for the future tax consequences attributable to differences between the financial statement carrying amounts of assets and liabilities and their respective tax basis. Deferred tax assets are also recognized for operating losses and tax credit carry forwards. Valuation allowances are recorded to reduce deferred tax assets when it is more likely than not that a tax benefit will not be realized. Deferred tax assets and liabilities are measured using enacted tax rates applicable in the years in which they are expected to be recovered or settled. The effect on deferred tax assets and liabilities of a change in tax law is recognized in income in the period that includes the enactment date.

 Where the Company does not intend to indefinitely reinvest earnings of its foreign subsidiaries, the Company provides for income taxes and foreign withholding taxes, where applicable, on undistributed earnings.

 The Company recognizes the benefit of an income tax position only if it is “more likely than not” that the tax position will be sustained. The tax benefits recognized are measured based on the largest benefit that has a greater than 50% likelihood of being realized. Additionally, the Company accrues for estimated interest and penalties related to unrecognized tax benefits as a component of provision for income taxes. The current portion of unrecognized tax benefits is included within Accounts Payable and the long-term portion is included within Other non-current liabilities in the Condensed Consolidated Balance Sheet.

 Value Added Taxes ("VAT")

 Solenis is subject to VAT in the various jurisdictions in which it operates. The Company’s collective global VAT positions do not have a right of offset and are netted by jurisdiction for financial statement presentation purposes.

###### Notes to Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements [Unaudited]

 The Company provides for gross asset, and gross liability positions within Prepaid expenses and other assets, and within Accrued expenses, respectively, on the Condensed Consolidated Balance Sheet. As of June 30, 2021, and September 30, 2020, the Company had gross VAT assets of $43.4 million and $29.4 million, respectively, and gross VAT liability positions of $11.1 million and $26.4 million, respectively. Within the Condensed Consolidated Statement of Cash Flows, the Company presents the net change in its global VAT positions within Other assets and liabilities. For the the nine months ended June 30, 2021, and 2020, those net changes inclusive of currency translation adjustments were outflows of $29.2 million and inflows of $35.6 million.

 Accounting for Business Combinations

 The Company accounts for business combinations under the acquisition method of accounting. This method requires the recording of acquired assets, including separately identifiable intangible assets and assumed liabilities at the acquisition date fair values. As applicable, any excess purchase price over the fair value of the acquired net assets is recorded as Goodwill.

 The determination of the fair value of assets acquired and liabilities assumed, involves an assessment of the factors including, but not limited to the expected future cash flows associated with individual assets and liabilities and an appropriate discount rate at the closing date of an acquisition. When necessary, the Company consults with external advisers to help determine fair value. For non-observable market values, the Company determines fair value using acceptable valuation principles.

 Goodwill and Intangible Assets

 In accordance with ASC 350, impairment tests are performed for goodwill and in-process research and development assets annually as of July 1 and whenever events or circumstances make it more likely than not that impairment may have occurred. Goodwill is reviewed for impairment at the reporting unit level.

 The Company assigns goodwill to individual reporting units at the date of acquisition based on the reporting units that are expected to benefit from the synergies of the related business combination. This assessment is based solely on the pre-acquisition expectation of revenue and free cash flow by reporting unit.

 When conducting its annual impairment test, the Company first assesses qualitative factors to determine whether the existence of events and circumstances indicate that it is more likely than not that the asset is impaired. If, after assessing the totality of events and circumstances, it is not more likely than not that the fair value of a reporting unit (or asset, specific to any in-process research and development assets) is less than its carrying amount, then performing the quantitative impairment test is unnecessary.

 When determined necessary under the qualitative assessment, Goodwill is tested for impairment by comparing the carrying value of the reporting unit to its estimated fair value. The latter is determined using a combination of discounted cash flow models and valuations based on earnings multiples. Significant assumptions inherent in the valuation methodologies for goodwill are employed and include, but are not limited to, projected business results and future industry direction, long-term growth factors, the weighted-average cost of capital for a market participant.

 For the period ending June 30, 2021 there were no triggering events.

 Definite-lived intangible assets are amortized on a straight-line basis over their estimated useful lives. Estimated useful lives and asset classes are as follows:

Customer relationships 5 to 20 years
Trademarks and trade names 3 to 20 years
Proprietary process know how 8 to 15 years
Intellectual property 3 to 15 years
Supply and reverse supply agreements 3 to 8 years
Other intangibles 3 years

###### The reasonableness of the useful lives of these assets is regularly evaluated. Once these assets are fully amortized, they are removed from the Condensed Consolidated Balance Sheet.

 Impairment of Long-Lived Assets

 The carrying value of long-lived assets, including property, plant and equipment and definite-lived intangibles, to be held and used is evaluated when events or changes in circumstances indicate the carrying value may not be recoverable. The carrying value of a long-lived asset is considered impaired when the total projected undiscounted cash flows from the asset are less than its carrying value. In that event, a loss is recognized based on the amount by which the carrying value exceeds the fair value of the long-lived asset. The fair value methodology used is an estimate of fair market value and is based on prices of similar assets or other valuation methodologies including present value techniques.

 Commitments, Contingencies and Environmental Costs

 Liabilities for loss contingencies arising from claims, assessments, litigation, fines, penalties and other sources are recorded when it is probable that a liability has been incurred and the amount of the assessment and/or remediation can be reasonably estimated.

 Accruals for environmental remediation are recognized when it is probable, when a liability has been incurred and the amount of that liability can be reasonably estimated. Liabilities are recorded at estimated present values based on experience, assessments and current technology, without regard to any third-party recoveries (which are recorded as assets) and are regularly adjusted as environmental assessments and remediation efforts advance.

 Retirement Plans and Other Post-Retirement Benefits

 In connection with the acquisition of AWT, the Company assumed certain defined benefit and defined contribution plan obligations for current and former employees of non-U.S. subsidiaries. All defined contribution pension plan obligations for current and former employees in the United States, as well as certain defined benefit and contribution pension plan obligations of former employees of non-U.S. subsidiaries, were retained by Ashland.

 In connection with the JV, certain employees of the former BASF Paper and Water Chemicals business transferred to subsidiaries of Solenis on January 31, 2019 and employment agreements were entered into between the respective parties on that date. As applicable, certain defined benefit plan obligations related to the transferred employees were acquired by the Company in connection with the JV are primarily within continental Europe. While the majority of the transferred employees are employed by Solenis' subsidiaries in the United States ("US") or the United Kingdom ("UK"), no defined benefit plan obligations were transferred to Solenis for any US, or UK based employees. Employees in these jurisdictions participate only in employer-sponsored defined contribution plans.

 Defined benefit plans specify an amount of pension benefit that an employee will receive on retirement, usually dependent on factors such as age, years of service and compensation. The net obligation in respect of defined


-----

###### Notes to Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements [Unaudited]

 benefit plans is calculated separately for each plan by estimating the amount of the future benefits that employees have earned in return for their service in the current and prior periods. These benefits are then discounted to determine the present value of the obligations and are then adjusted for the impact of any unamortized prior service costs. The net obligation is then determined with reference to the fair value of the plan assets (if any). The discount rate used is the yield on bonds that are denominated in the currency in which the benefits will be paid and that have maturity dates approximating the terms of the obligations.

 Share-based Compensation

 The Company recognizes share-based compensation expense for all options and other arrangements within the scope of Accounting Standards Codification ("ASC") 718. Awards are classified as equity if such options are settled in shares and classified as liabilities if they are settled in cash. Share-based compensation expense for equity-classified awards is measured at the date of grant, based on the fair value of the award, and is recognized using the "straight-line attribution method" over the employee’s requisite service period. Awards classified as liabilities are measured for fair value at each reporting date, with any changes to fair value recognized currently in earnings based on the extent of the requisite service period elapsed. The fair value of awards classified as liabilities are presented as a component of Accrued expenses on the Condensed Consolidated Balance Sheet.

 Share-based awards with vesting conditions other than service are recognized over the performance period based on the probability that those conditions will be achieved.

 For additional information on the Company`s share-based compensation plan, see Note 15.

 Fair Value Measurements

 U.S. GAAP defines a fair value hierarchy that prioritizes the inputs to valuation techniques used to measure fair value. The hierarchy gives the highest priority to unadjusted quoted prices in active markets for identical assets or liabilities (Level 1 measurements) and the lowest priority to unobservable inputs (Level 3 measurements). A financial instrument’s level within the fair value hierarchy is based on the lowest level of any input that is significant to the fair value measurement.

 The following valuation techniques are used to measure fair value for assets and liabilities:

 Level 1—Quoted market prices in active markets for identical assets or liabilities;

 Level 2—Significant other observable inputs (e.g., quoted prices for similar items in active markets, quoted prices for identical or similar items in markets that are not active, inputs other than quoted prices that are observable such as interest rate and yield curves, and market-corroborated inputs);

 Level 3—Unobservable inputs for the assets or liabilities which are valued based on management’s estimates of assumptions that market participants would use in pricing the asset or liability; and

 Net Asset Value ("NAV") - The Company invests in funds which are not quoted on an active market. These funds are valued based on the underlying fair value of the funds investments less the funds liabilities or net asset value.

 Derivatives

 The Company is exposed to the effects of changes in interest rates, foreign currency, changes in commodity prices and credit risk. The Company utilizes interest rate swap agreements to hedge a portion of its exposure to fluctuating interest rates on its long term debt and net investment hedging to mitigate foreign exchange risk

 Sale of Accounts Receivable

 The Company accounts for sales of accounts receivables when control of receivables is surrendered. Whether control has been relinquished requires among other considerations, an evaluation of the relevant legal considerations and an assessment of the nature and extent of the Company's continuing involvement with the assets transferred. Assets obtained and liabilities incurred in connection with the transfers reported as sales are initially recognized in the Condensed Consolidated Balance Sheet at fair value.

 Accounts receivable sold are deemed transferred to the counterparty in accordance with the prevailing purchase agreement applicable to the relevant jurisdiction. In situations where cash is immediately received from the counterparty upon sale of the receivable, such cash is classified as cash received from operating activities. In situations where cash is not received immediately from the counterparty upon sale of the receivable, the transfer is deemed to represent a non-cash investing activity whereby the receivable is sold for a subordinated interest in future cash collections. Ultimate collections of cash on the subordinated interest in future cash collections are treated as cash flows from investing activities.

 Announced Accounting Standards

 In May 2014, the FASB issued accounting guidance outlining a single comprehensive five step model for entities to use in accounting for revenue arising from contracts with customers (ASC 606- Revenue from Contracts with Customers, i.e. the "new revenue standard"). The new revenue standard supersedes most current revenue recognition guidance, in an effort to converge the revenue recognition principles within U.S. GAAP. This new guidance also requires entities to disclose certain quantitative and qualitative information regarding the nature, amount, timing and uncertainty of qualifying revenue and cash flows arising from contracts with customers. Entities have the option of using a full retrospective or a modified retrospective approach to adopt the new guidance. In June 2020, the FASB issued ASU 2020-05, which results in a one-year deferral of the revised revenue recognition standard and requires private issues to adopt the standard beginning in the first annual reporting period after December 15, 2019 (for Solenis this period would begin October 1, 2020). As such, the Company will adopt the standard in the current fiscal year and will have disclosures prepared on a basis consistent with the required reporting and disaggregation available for the statements issued as of, and for the year ended September 30, 2021. The Company does not anticipate material changes to its previously issued financial statements or its revenue recognition procedures though the underlying analysis is on-going. 

 During February 2016, the FASB issued ASU 2016-02, "Leases". The initial guidance and the subsequent amendments and deferrals issued, require that companies recognize right of use assets and lease liabilities relative to at least all leasing arrangements with terms in excess of 12 months. The guidance is expected to eliminate the majority of off-balance sheet financing arrangements and provide clarity around actual contractual obligations of the business. This guidance is effective for all private entities for fiscal years beginning after December 15, 2021. As such, the Company is currently refining its analysis and will adopt the standard during the year ended September 30, 2021.

 In June 2016, the FASB issued ASU 2016-13, "Measurement of Credit Losses on Financial Instruments." The guidance requires immediate recognition of estimated credit losses that are expected to occur over the remaining life of many financial assets. This new guidance is effective for private companies for fiscal years beginning after


-----

###### Notes to Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements [Unaudited]

 December 15, 2020, but early adoption is permitted. Management is evaluating the impact this standard would have on the Company's financial condition, results of operations and cash flows; the most notable impact of this ASU will relate to the Company's processes around the assessment of the adequacy of the allowance for doubtful accounts on trade receivables.

 In August 2018, the FASB issued ASU 2018-15, "Intangibles - Goodwill and other Internal-Use-Software Customer's Accounting for Implementation Costs Incurred in a Cloud Computing Arrangement That Is a Service Contract." The guidance aligns the requirements for capitalizing implementation costs in a cloud computing arrangement service contract with the requirements for capitalizing implementation costs incurred for an internal use software license. Capitalized implementation costs should be amortized over the term of the service agreement on a straight line basis and should be assessed for impairment in a manner similar to long-lived assets. This new guidance is effective for private companies in fiscal years beginning after December 15, 2020. Early adoption is permitted. Management is currently evaluating the impact of adopting this standard.

 In October 2018, the FASB issued ASU 2018-16, "Derivatives and Hedging : Inclusion of the Secured Overnight Financing Rate (SOFR) Overnight Index Swap (OIS) Rate as a Benchmark Interest Rate for Hedge Accounting Purposes". Previously under Topic 815, the eligible benchmark interest rates in the United States were the interest rates on direct Treasury obligations of the U.S. government (UST), the LIBOR swap rate, the OIS Rate based on the Fed Funds Effective Rate, and the Securities Industry and Financial Markets Association (SIFMA) Municipal Swap Rate, which was introduced in ASU 2017-12, Derivatives and Hedging: Targeted Improvements to Accounting for Hedging Activities (“ASU 2017-12”). The amendments in ASU 2018-16 permit the use of the OIS rate based on SOFR as a benchmark interest rate for hedge accounting purposes under Topic 815. The guidance is effective at the same time as adoption of ASU 2017-12. Management is currently evaluating impact of adopting this standard.

 In October 2020, the FASB issued ASU 2020-08 "Codification improvements to Subtopic 310-20, Receivables- Nonrefundable Fees and Other Costs". The amendments in this Update clarify that an entity should reevaluate whether a callable debt security is within the scope of paragraph 310-20-35-33 for each reporting period. The amendments in this Update represent changes to clarify the Codification. The amendments make the Codification easier to understand and easier to apply by eliminating inconsistencies and providing clarifications. The amendments in this Update are effective for fiscal years beginning after December 15, 2021, and interim periods within fiscal years beginning after December 15, 2022. Early application is permitted for all other entities for fiscal years, and interim periods within those fiscal years, beginning after December 15, 2020. All entities should apply the amendments in this Update on a prospective basis as of the beginning of the period of adoption for existing or newly purchased callable debt securities. Management is currently evaluating impact of adopting this standard.

 In March 2021, the FASB issued ASU 2021-03, "Intangibles - Goodwill and Other (Topic 350) Accounting Alternative for Evaluating Triggering Events". Under the previous guidance in Subtopic 350-20, Intangibles— Goodwill and Other—Goodwill, an entity is required to monitor and evaluate goodwill impairment triggering events throughout the reporting period. The amendments in this Update provide private companies and not-for- profit entities with an accounting alternative to perform the goodwill impairment triggering event evaluation as required in Subtopic 350-20 as of the end of the reporting period, whether the reporting period is an interim or annual period. Management elected not use the accounting alternative to evaluate the triggering events. Refer to "Goodwill and Intangible Assets" within Note 2 for management's current evaluation standards.

###### Conversion of Nanjing Option to Long-Term Supply Agreement

 On April 30, 2021, Solenis Shanghai Chemicals Company Limited (a consolidated subsidiary of the Company, i.e. "Solenis Shanghai") and BASF Specialty Chemicals Nanjing Company Limited ("BASF Nanjing") agreed to convert the Company's $59.9 million deposit with BASF to a long-term supply agreement (the "LTSA"). The LTSA will provide Solenis Shanghai with an uninterrupted, eight year supply of finished goods required to serve former BASF customers acquired via Solenis' acquisition of the BASF Paper and Water business in January 2019. The $59.9 million deposit was originally conveyed via Solenis Holdings Top I B.V. (a consolidated Dutch subsidiary of Solenis) to BASF Nederland B.V. ("BASF NL") in January 2019, representing the estimated residual fair value of BASF Nanjing's manufacturing facility in Nanjing, China. The deposit was conveyed with the intention between the parties of transferring asset titles and operating permits from BASF to Solenis on, or prior to, January 31, 2022, upon which the existing three-year supply agreement between BASF Nanjing and Solenis Shanghai is scheduled to expire. The deposit was originally conveyed while the parties sought to perfect their intentions of transferring legal ownership on the basis that three years would be sufficient to achieve their original intentions. Despite the intent of both parties, the possibility of permit transfer appears to be remote and as such, the parties agreed to utilize the option consideration to create a new eight year supply agreement that will supersede the existing three year agreement. In consideration of the new LTSA, BASF NL returned the $59.9 million deposit to Solenis Holding Top I B.V. who in-turn provided funds to Solenis Shanghai such that funds could be conveyed locally to BASF Nanjing in China. In addition to $59.9 million of the initial deposit, Solenis Shanghai conveyed an incremental $5.0 million of Cash representing embedded realized foreign exchange losses from the initial transaction and local transfer taxes. In consideration of the Cash paid by Solenis Shanghai, the long-term supply agreement will become effective no later than October 31, 2021. Until the effective date, the total cash conveyed will be presented as "Acquisition-related deposits" on the Condensed Consolidated Balance

###### With respect to the intangible assets recognized during the year ended September 30, 2020, via the Company's acquisitions of Chemsystems' Pulp and Paper business and the outstanding shares of Poliquimicos, the fair value of intangible assets were estimated using an income approach, either the excess earnings method or the relief from royalty method. Under the excess earnings method, an intangible asset’s fair value is equal to the present value of the incremental after-tax cash flows attributable solely to the intangible asset over its remaining useful life. Under the relief from royalty method, fair value is measured by estimating future revenue associated with the intangible asset over its useful life and applying a royalty rate to the revenue estimate. These intangible assets collectively enable the Company to enhance its sales pipeline while manufacturing and developing new products to meet evolving business needs as well as competitively produce and sell existing products.

 Note 5  Sale of Trade Receivables

 On March 26, 2018, the Company sold certain accounts receivable under the terms of a Receivables Purchase Agreement ("RPA" or "Accounts Receivable Financing") with ING Luxembourg ("ING"). The RPA carried a maximum capacity of $120.0 million and was scheduled to expire on September 30, 2020.

 On March 20, 2020, the Company entered into an amended agreement with ING and a new agreement with MUFG Bank, Ltd (“MUFG”), through which ING will continue to service non-US markets with a maximum funding capacity of €110 million and further sell its interest in US markets to MUFG. The maximum funding capacity carried by MUFG to serve the US market is $75 million. As of June 30, 2021, the total capacity of the amended RPA agreements among the Company, ING and MUFG is $205.9 million. both of which are scheduled to expire in March 2022.

 Through the Accounts Receivable Financing facilities with both counterparties, the Company sells eligible short- term trade receivables on the initial transfer date to either ING or MUFG in exchange for consideration inclusive of cash conveyed to Solenis (referred to as the Initial Purchase Price, or "IPP") and a beneficial interest in the receivables collected by either ING or MUFG (referred to as the Deferred Purchase Price, or "DPP"). The Company continues to service the receivables sold in connection with the arrangement. The RPA requires Solenis to pledge its cash collection accounts for the underlying receivables to ING for the non-US market and to MUFG for US markets, whereby neither the receivables sold to ING or MUFG nor the future cash collections on the sold receivables are assets of Solenis post-transfer.

 Through maturity, ING and MUFG purchases new receivables from Solenis on a daily, weekly, or monthly basis, depending on the jurisdiction, in exchange for incremental DPP. These amounts are settled monthly against sold receivables which were previously collected.

 The DPP is carried at fair value, which is remeasured weekly to take into account activity during the period (the Company's interest in the newly-transferred receivables and collections on previously transferred receivables attributable to the DPP), as well as changes in estimates of future interest rates and anticipated credit losses. Refer to Note 11 for additional discussion surrounding the fair value of the DPP.

###### On July 31, 2014, International and Solenis Holdings 3 LLC, then a subsidiary of International, entered into a First Lien Credit Agreement ("First Lien Credit Agreement due 2021"), comprised of a $630.0 million loan ("First Lien Dollar Loan due 2021"), a €230.0 million loan ("First Lien Euro Loan due 2021"), and a $200.0 million Revolving Credit Facility ("Revolving Credit Facility due 2019"). On that same day, International and Solenis Holdings 3 LLC entered into a Second Lien Credit Agreement comprising a $470.0 million loan (the "Second Lien Credit Agreement due 2022"). Subsequent to these transactions, the Company entered into two additional term loans under the First Lien Credit Agreement due 2021: one for €85 million during the second quarter of 2015 and one for €100 million during the third quarter of 2016. These agreements are collectively referred to as the "Old Debt".

 On June 26, 2018, Solenis Holdings LLC, a wholly-owned subsidiary of the Company, entered into the First Lien Credit Agreement (the "First Lien Credit Agreement") which includes a $200 million Revolving Credit Facility (the "Revolving Credit Facility"), and a Second Lien Credit Agreement through which the company borrowed aggregate principal amount of $1.8 billion, with original maturity dates of December 2023, and June 2024 for the First Lien Credit Agreement, and Second lien Credit Agreement, respectively. The First and Second Lien Credit Agreements were consummated to provide net proceeds which facilitated the Joint Venture between Solenis and BASF and allow for an extension of the terms of each of the credit agreements and the Revolving Credit Facility. These agreements are collectively referred to as the "New Debt". The proceeds from each of these borrowings were used in combination with one another to repay the remaining principal balance on the Company's Old Debt.  As part of the closing of the Joint Venture on January 31, 2019, the Company borrowed an incremental $170 million and €330 million under the First Lien Credit Agreement, and increased the borrowing capacity of the Revolving Credit Facility from $200 million to $375 million, at which time the Company borrowed an incremental $124 million on the Revolving Credit Facility. The closing of the Joint Venture also extended the maturity date of all term loans under the First Lien Credit Agreement (except for the Revolving Credit Facility) by


-----

###### Notes to Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements [Unaudited]

 18 months, from December 26, 2023 to June 26, 2025, and extended the maturity date of the Second Lien Credit Agreement by 24 months, from June 25, 2024 to June 26, 2026.

 For both the June 26, 2018 refinancing and the incremental borrowing on January 31, 2019 the Company applied the guidance prescribed by Accounting Standards Codification ("ASC") 470-50, Modifications and Extinguishments, to determine the appropriate accounting treatment regarding unamortized deferred financing costs and original issue discounts related to the original borrowing. All deferred financing costs and original issue discount associated with portions of the debt determined to be modified were allocated to the First Lien Credit Agreement due 2025 and Second Lien Credit Agreement due 2026 to be amortized over the life of the associated agreements.

 On February 5, 2020, the Company entered into an agreement to supplement its First Lien Credit Agreement which resulted in incremental gross proceeds of $150 million and €100 million. The Company used the proceeds to pay down outstanding borrowings on its Revolving Credit facility by the same amount as the incremental proceeds. An incremental debt discount of $1.3 million and incremental deferred financing costs of $1.6 million were capitalized consistent with the guidance prescribed above within ASC 470-50, Modifications and Extinguishments. All other terms of the First Lien Credit Agreement remained consistent, including but not limited to, the outstanding indebtedness thereunder being due June 26, 2025.

 On March 1, 2021, the Company and its syndicate of lenders agreed to reduce the fixed component of Solenis' debt service costs by 0.25% with respect to the First Lien Euro Loan while replacing the variable rate floor of 0.5% with zero (the "Repricing"). As the Euro London Interbank Offered Rate ("EURIBOR") remains negative as of June 30, 2021, this agreement reduced the Company's debt service costs on it's First Lien Euro Loan by 0.75%. The transaction is accounted for as a modification. As such, the Company capitalized incremental deferred financing costs of $1.0 million related to lender fees paid in connection with the transaction.

 First Lien Credit Agreement

 Obligations under the First Lien Credit Agreement are guaranteed by the Company's wholly-owned UK subsidiaries, subject to certain exceptions (collectively, the "Subsidiary Guarantors"), and, solely by recourse to the equity of the Company, by Solenis UK Industries Limited, a wholly-owned subsidiary of the Company, and Solenis Holdings Sub II B.V. (collectively, the "Holdings Guarantors"). The First Lien Credit Agreement is collateralized by substantially all of the assets of the Company and the Subsidiary Guarantors, subject to certain exceptions, as well as the equity of the Company held by the Holdings Guarantors. Principal is paid on the last day of each quarter in an amount equal to $2.8 million and €2.0 million for the First Lien Dollar Loan and First Lien Euro Loan, respectively.

 Interest rates on all term loans under the First Lien Credit Agreement are variable. The First Lien Dollar Loan carries an interest rate of 4%, plus the greater of the USD London Interbank Offered Rate ("LIBOR") or 0%. Beginning on March 1, 2021 in connection with the Repricing, The First Lien Euro Loan carries an interest rate of 4.00% plus the greater of the EURIBOR or 0%. Interest elections are made on the last day of the second month of every quarter and are effective for three months.

 Term loans under the First Lien Credit Agreement mature on June 26, 2025. The Company is permitted to prepay all term loans under the First Lien Credit Agreement at any time. Through June 30, 2021, the Company has not made any voluntary prepayments on the First Lien Loans in normal course.

 The First Lien Loans are subject to mandatory prepayments equal to 50% of the Company's Excess Cash Flow, as defined in the First Lien Credit Agreement, subject to certain conditions, beginning in the fiscal year ended September 30, 2019. During the three months ended December 31, 2020, the Company made a mandatory


-----

###### Notes to Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements [Unaudited]

 principal prepayment of $12.4 million based on the calculation of 50% of the Company's Excess Cash Flow during the year ended September 30, 2020. There were no mandatory prepayments due under the First Lien Credit Agreement as of either June 30, 2021 or June 30, 2020.

 The obligations under the First Lien Credit Agreement are effectively senior to all of the Company's Second Lien Debt and unsecured debt, in each case to the extent of the value of the collateral securing such obligations.

 In addition, if, at the end of any quarter, borrowings under the Revolving Credit Facility exceed 35% of the aggregate amount available, or $363.7 million, the First Lien Credit Agreement requires the Company to maintain a condensed consolidated First Lien Leverage Ratio, as defined in the First Lien Credit Agreement, of 7.30 to 1. The First Lien Credit Agreement also includes customary negative and affirmative covenants including, among others, limitations on the Company's ability to: (i) incur additional debt; (ii) create liens; (iii) make certain investments, loans and advances; (iv) sell assets; (v) pay dividends or make distributions or other restricted payments; (vi) engage in mergers or consolidations; or (vii) change the nature of our business. As of June 30, 2021, the Company is in compliance with all positive and negative and affirmative covenants under the First Lien Credit Agreement.

 The Revolving Credit Facility allows maximum borrowings of $375.0 million and matures on June 26, 2023. The interest rate on the Revolving Credit Facility is, at the election of the Borrower, ABR plus 2.5% per annum or LIBOR plus 3.5% per annum. As of June 30, 2021, the company had no revolver borrowings outstanding on the Revolving Credit Facility.

 The Company has $363.7 million of borrowings available under the Revolving Credit Facility due 2023 as of June 30, 2021. This amount consisted of $375.0 million less undrawn standby letters of credit of $11.3 million.

 Second Lien Credit Agreement

 The Second Lien Credit Agreement carries the same guaranty and security package as the First Lien Credit Agreement. No principal payments are due in connection with the Second Lien Credit Agreement until maturity. The Second Lien Credit Agreement matures on June 26, 2026.

 The Company is permitted to prepay the Second Lien Credit Agreement at any time. Prepayments made prior to June 26, 2020 would have incurred a 2% penalty of the principal balance prepaid. Prepayments made after June 26, 2020 but prior to June 26, 2021 would have incurred a 1% penalty on the principal balance prepaid. Prepayments made after June 26, 2021 are free of penalty. The prepayment penalty is assessed regardless of whether or not the prepayment was mandatory or voluntary.

 The interest rate on the Second Lien Credit Agreement is 8.5% plus the greater of LIBOR or 0%. Interest elections are made on the last day of the second month of every quarter and are effective for three months. The Second Lien Credit Agreement is junior in priority to the First Lien Credit Agreement and senior to all other unsecured debt.

 The Second Lien Credit Agreement includes customary negative and affirmative covenants including, among others, limitations on the Company's ability to: (i) incur additional debt; (ii) create liens; (iii) make certain investments, loans and advances; (iv) sell assets; (v) pay dividends or make distributions or other restricted payments; (vi) engage in mergers or consolidations; or (vii) change the nature of our business.

 Derivatives and Hedging Activities

 In order to reduce the Company's exposure to fluctuations in the cash flows associated with changes in interest rates, Solenis may create offsetting positions through the use of derivative financial instruments. The Company does not enter into derivative financial instruments for trading or speculative purposes.

 In November 2014, the Solenis entered into three interest rate swap arrangements to hedge interest rate exposure related to a portion of the Company's long-term debt. As a result of these arrangements, the Company effectively


-----

###### Notes to Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements [Unaudited]

 converted $440.0 million of its US Dollar denominated debt from a floating interest rate to a fixed LIBOR rate of 2.59% for a 2.5 year period from November 30, 2016 through May 30, 2019.

 On June 26, 2018, a wholly-owned subsidiary of the Company entered into the First and Second Lien Credit Agreements, the proceeds from which were used to pay off outstanding principal amounts on the First Lien Dollar Loan due 2021. More information regarding this refinancing event can be found in Note 10. Despite the payoff of the First Lien Dollar Loan due 2021, (i) the Company still bore interest rate risk exposure through its wholly- owned subsidiary; (ii) the First Lien Dollar Loan due 2023 still carried an outstanding principal balance in excess of the $440.0 million notional amount in the interest rate and; (iii) interest payments under the First Lien Dollar Loan due 2023 carried a variable interest rate tied to LIBOR. As such, the Company determined that the hedge continued to be effective after the refinancing and, therefore, Solenis continued to apply cash flow hedge accounting through the maturity date of the swaps. As of May 30, 2019, these swaps were effectively settled with no amounts due to, or due from the counterparty.

 During the first quarter of 2019, the Company entered into three interest rate swap arrangements to hedge the variable interest rate risk exposure specific to the Company's First Lien US Dollar-denominated debt. The aggregate notional value for the three interest rate swap agreements is $600.0 million. As a result of these arrangements, the Company collectively converted $600.0 million of its US Dollar-denominated debt from a floating three-month LIBOR interest rate to fixed rates of 3.26%, 3.12%, and 3.13%, respectively for the 36- month period from May 31, 2019 through May 31, 2022.

 These contracts have been designated and qualify as cash flow hedges. On both a retrospective and prospective basis, the Company measures hedge effectiveness by formally assessing, at least quarterly, the probable high correlation of the expected future cash flows of the hedged item and the derivative hedging instrument. The effective portion of the gain or loss on the derivative instrument is deferred as a component of other comprehensive loss or income until the settlement of the related business transaction at which time the accumulated gain or loss from the contracts will be reclassified into earnings. There was no ineffective portion of the gain or loss on the derivative instrument recognized during the three and nine months ended June 30, 2021 or 2020, respectively.

 For the nine months ended June 30, 2021 and 2020, the Company reclassified expense of $13.1 million and $5.9 million, respectively from Accumulated other comprehensive loss through Interest expense on the Condensed Consolidated Statement of Operations based on the paid and accrued interest recognized on the Company's interest rate swap liability.

 As of June 30, 2021, the Company expects losses of $18.2 million presented within Accumulated other comprehensive (loss) to be reclassified to net income or loss during the next 12 months.

###### While Solenis partially mitigates the market driven interest rate risk on its term debt through the use of interest rate swaps, the Company has historically experienced significant foreign exchange risk on its First Lien Euro Loans. As of June 30, 2021, the Company has First Lien Euro Loans of $927.0 million (EUR 779.3 million). To


-----

###### Notes to Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements [Unaudited]

 mitigate the foreign exchange risk associated with these loans on a go-forward basis, management determined to pursue solutions without incurring the cost or underlying risks associated with derivative financial instruments.

 Effective April 1, 2021, the Company determined to utilize an intercompany Euro denominated note between two downstream consolidated subsidiaries to act as a hedging instrument in response to the foreign exchange risk associated with the Company's consolidated EUR net asset exposure (i.e. the "hedged item"). The intercompany note will act as a "Net Investment Hedge" through which changes in the USD equivalent of the intercompany note will be recognized in Other Comprehensive Income rather than through the Condensed Consolidated Statement of Operations as is common for foreign currency denominated monetary instruments. The use of an intercompany note is permissible under ASC 815-20, Derivatives, only to the extent that the intercompany note reflects the consolidated foreign exchange risk of the consolidated company, and the entity party to the third-party debt instrument is the counterparty to the intercompany note designated as a hedging instrument. As of April 1, 2021 and through June 30, 2021, Solenis meets both of these criteria required to assume a net investment hedge.

 Each month, Solenis redesignates a specific amount of Euro denominated intercompany notes as a hedging instrument to mitigate foreign exchange risk associated with its Euro net assets. The company's designation is limited to the lowest value in the subset of data points among: 1) The total Euro value of the intercompany note outstanding, 2) The total Euro value of Solenis' consolidated First Lien Euro Loans, and 3) The total Euro value of Solenis' net assets in consolidated subsidiaries that utilize a Euro functional currency. As of June 30, 2021, the Company has designated EUR 772.6 million of its intercompany Euro notes as a hedging instrument to mitigate the foreign currency risk associated with the Company's 772.6 million of consolidated Euro net assets (relative to total First Lien Euro Loans of EUR 779.3 million). During the three months ended June 30, 2021, Solenis recognized Other Comprehensive Loss of $14.4 million as a result of its net investment hedge, effectively representing deferrals of foreign exchange gains and losses associated with the Company's First Lien Euro Loans. No reclassification of Other Comprehensive Losses specific to the net investment hedge are expected to be reclassified to the Condensed Consolidated Statement of Operations during the next 12 months.

###### Deferred Purchase Price on Accounts Receivable Financing

 On March 26, 2018, the Company entered into an arrangement to sell accounts receivable under the terms of a RPA with ING. The RPA carried a maximum capacity of $120.0 million and was scheduled to expire on September 30, 2020. Refer to Note 5 for additional details.


-----

###### Notes to Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements [Unaudited]

 On March 20, 2020, the Company entered into an amended agreement with ING and a new agreement with MUFG Bank, Ltd (“MUFG”), through which ING will continue to service non-US markets for the maximum capacity of €110 million and further sell its interest in US markets to MUFG. The maximum RPA capacity carried by MUFG is $75 million to serve the US market. The total capacity of the RPA agreements among the Company, ING and MUFG is $205.9 million. The RPA agreement with MUFG and the amended RPA agreement with ING are scheduled to expire in March of 2022. Refer to Note 5, Sale of Trade Receivables for additional details.

 Initial consideration received from ING and MUFG through the Accounts Receivable Financing included a subordinated interest in transferred receivables collected, referred to as the Deferred Purchase Price. The DPP is carried at fair value and is remeasured weekly to reflect activity during the period (i.e. the Company's interest in subsequently-transferred receivables and collections on receivables previously sold to ING or MUFG) as well as changes in estimates of future interest rates and anticipated credit losses. The fair value of the DPP is predicated upon the underlying receivables which have been transferred to ING or MUFG. As the underlying receivables represent the Company's customers with the highest credit quality and are generally collectible within 90 days, the Company expects the fair value of the DPP to be equal to its face value.

 Receivables under the Accounts Receivable Financing are transferred to ING or MUFG daily, weekly, or monthly in accordance with the prevailing agreement for each jurisdiction. The consideration for the transfer of these receivables is incremental DPP to be settled at each settlement date, as defined in the RPAs.

 As the receivables transferred to ING and MUFG do not have an active market for equivalent or similar assets, the Company's fair value assessment is predicated upon its own history of collection surrounding the specific customers' receivables which have been transferred. Accordingly, such inputs qualify as Level 3 inputs. Due to the high credit quality and the relatively short-term nature of the underlying receivables, fluctuations in credit quality are expected to have an immaterial effect on the fair value of the DPP.

 As of June 30, 2021 and September 30, 2020, the DPP is carried at $185.9 million and $164.5 million, respectively. These amounts are included in Sold receivables on the Condensed Consolidated Balance Sheet.

 Note 12  Commitments, Contingencies and Litigation

 Unconditional Purchase Obligations and Commitments

 In connection with the consummation of the Joint Venture with BASF on January 31, 2019, the Company entered into a number of "take or pay" contracts (the "Supply Agreements") through which BASF will make certain materials required to service acquired BASF legacy customers available to Solenis based upon a combination of legacy BASF volumes for these materials and available manufacturing capacity. The term of these agreements is either three (the "Medium Term"), or eight years (the "Long Term"). Upon maturity, each of the Medium Term agreements will automatically extend for 12 months on a revolving basis unless either party provides 24 months notice of their intention to exit the agreement. There is no penalty for either party to exit provided the 24 month notice period is met. Upon maturity, each of the Long Term agreements will expire immediately unless otherwise mutually agreed to by Solenis and BASF.

 Given the substantial capital and working capital requirements necessary to maintain available capacity and meet Solenis' purchasing requirements, the Company is required to remit minimum monthly payments (the "Fixed Manufacturing Costs") designed to cover BASF's plant overhead costs specific to the impacted production lines. The monthly payments are fixed and determinable, based on allocations of BASF's heritage costing structure relative to expected production and volumes and vary only based upon annual changes in inflation rates observable in the public domain.

 Environmental Remediation

 Due to the nature of Solenis' business, the Company is subject to various laws and regulations pertaining to the environment, manufacturing, sale, transportation and disposal of hazardous products. These laws pertain to, among other things, air and water, management of solid and hazardous wastes, transportation, and human health and safety. The total reserves for environmental remediation reflect estimates of the most likely costs that will be incurred over an extended period to remediate identified conditions for which the costs are reasonably estimable, without regard to any third-party recoveries.

 Environmental remediation reserves are subject to numerous inherent uncertainties that affect our ability to estimate its share of the costs. Such uncertainties involve the nature and extent of contamination at each site, the extent of required cleanup efforts under existing environmental regulations, widely varying costs of alternate cleanup methods, changes in environmental regulations, the potential effect of continuing improvements in remediation technology, and the number and financial strength of other potentially responsible parties at multi- party sites. 

 Under the terms of the initial carve-out from Ashland, the Company is indemnified for certain pre-existing environmental remediation costs. Certain of these indemnified costs are required to exceed a deductible of 2% of the purchase price paid in the acquisition in order for indemnification to be available.

 In connection with the JV, BASF transferred various production facilities to Solenis. During the diligence process related to the acquisition, Solenis performed diligence related to potential environmental or other continent liabilities. As no probable or estimable exposure existed at the acquisition date, Solenis is not indemnified with respect to any environmental or other contingent matters. As of both June 30, 2021 and September 30, 2020, the Company does not have material contingent obligations which are both probable and estimable related to these production facilities, transferred employees, or other real property acquired from BASF.

 As of both June 30, 2021 and September 30, 2020, the Company has recorded environmental remediation reserves of $1.8 million, related to two ongoing and probable environmental remediation proceedings. These reserves are


-----

###### Notes to Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements [Unaudited]

 included as part of other non-current liabilities on the Condensed Consolidated Balance Sheet. Given the limited time frame over which remediation activities are expected to be performed, the Company has not discounted any projected future cash outflows in determining these reserves as of June 30, 2021.

 Of the $1.8 million reserved, $1.0 million relates to potential exposure surrounding groundwater and soil contamination associated with a plant in Araraquara, Brazil. The remaining $0.8 million relates to management's best estimate for potential exposure related to ground contamination at the Company's Milwaukee, Wisconsin plant as well as a reserve for a potential Environmental Protection Agency matter. The amount reserved for both matters represents management's best estimate of total expenses to be incurred, made with the assistance of a third-party specialist.

 Indemnification assets associated with environmental remediation claims are recorded on the Condensed Consolidated Balance Sheet as part of Other assets in the amount of $1.1 million as of both June 30, 2021 and September 30, 2020, respectively.

 Other Legal Proceedings

 In addition to the matters described above, there are various claims, lawsuits and administrative proceedings that are pending or threatened. Such actions seek remedies or damages, some of which are for substantial amounts.

 The Company has accrued for legal reserves of $3.3 million as of both June 30, 2021 and September 30, 2020, respectively. While Solenis cannot predict with certainty the outcome of such actions, the Company believes that adequate reserves have been recorded and losses already recognized with respect to such actions.

 In addition to its uncertain tax positions, the Company has accrued for various contingent liabilities related to indirect taxes. As of June 30, 2021 and September 30, 2020, the Company has accrued for potential exposure related to these positions of $5.7 million, of which Solenis is indemnified for $3.6 million by the former owners of Solenis' business combinations since inception. As of both June 30, 2021, and September 30, 2020, these obligations and the related indemnification assets are recorded as a component of Other non-current liabilities, and Other assets, respectively, on the Condensed Consolidated Balance Sheet.

 Insurance

 Solenis maintains deductibles for general liability, business interruption and property damage to owned, leased and rented property. These deductibles could be material to our earnings, but they are not material to our overall financial position. The Company carries substantial excess general liability, property and business interruption insurance above our deductibles. In addition, Solenis meets all statutory requirements for automobile liability and workers’ compensation.

 On July 31, 2014, CD&R contributed $405.0 million of cash to the Holding Companies in exchange for 40,500,000 of Class A shares of Common stock in Solenis Holdings Top II B.V. No additional Class A shares were purchased or sold prior to the closing of the Joint Venture.

 Between July 31, 2014 and the closing of the Joint Venture, members of Management purchased Class B shares of Common stock in Solenis Holdings Top II B.V. As of the date of the Joint Venture, 1,261,829 Class B shares were outstanding.

 On December 27, 2017, Solenis I Coopertief U.A. issued a return of capital in kind to CD&R totaling $400.0 million. The return of capital was issued in the form of a note payable. On April 4, 2018, the Board of Directors of Solenis Holdings I Coopertief U.A. passed a resolution to recapitalize $405.1 million representing the initial note payable and related interest accrued. On May 1, 2018 Solenis Holdings Top I B.V. issued a return on capital of $400.0 million in the form of a note payable maturing on April 30, 2020 to CD&R. 

 On January 31, 2019, CD&R exchanged their 40,500,000 shares of Class A Common stock in exchange for 35,624,716 Ordinary shares of Solenis UK International Limited. Additionally, CD&R received $303.0 million in cash which represented a partial repayment of the $400.0 million on the note payable due from Solenis Holding Top I B.V. The $303.0 million in cash paid constitutes $293.4 million in partial repayment of principal and $9.6 million of accrued interest. CD&R exchanged the remaining balance of $106.6 million principal outstanding on the note payable for 6,137,113 Ordinary shares in Solenis. This transaction was financed using proceeds from the Incremental Borrowings.

 On January 31, 2019, Management exchanged their 1,261,829 shares of Class B Common stock in exchange for 1,261,829 Ordinary shares of Solenis and $9.4 million of cash. In order to avoid a dilutive adjustment in accordance with the provision of the Plan, management shareholders received a $4.4 million incremental return of capital during the year ended September 30, 2019.

 On January 31, 2019, as part of consideration transferred to acquire BASF Paper & Water, Solenis issued 40,113,302 Ordinary shares and $203.8 million in cash to BASF. The fair value of the Ordinary shares conveyed, based upon the total equity value of the combined business, exclusive of expected synergies, was $677.8 million.
