 Note 15  Share-based Compensation

 Stock Incentive Plan

 Effective July 8, 2014, the Company's board of directors adopted the Solenis Holdings Top II B.V. Stock Incentive Plan pursuant to which the Company's board of directors shall select officers and key employees and directors to participate in the plan and grant stock options and offer opportunities to purchase shares. The plan allows for the issuance of up to 6,500,000 Class B shares under the plan (for all share-based compensation and share purchases). All stock options granted have a term not greater than ten years. Stock options vest and become exercisable, in whole or in part, with vesting conditions set by the Company's board of directors.


-----

###### Notes to Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements [Unaudited]

 The options are provided in two separate grants which have differing vesting conditions. Service Options, which reflect 75% of all options granted, vest in four equal annual installments, coinciding with the first anniversary date of the grant date and each successive anniversary thereafter. Performance Options, which represent the remaining 25% of the options granted, vest upon the conclusion of each of the four fiscal years subsequent to the grant date based on the achievement of specified "EBITDA" (earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization; subject to management adjustments) targets during the fiscal year in which they vest. The extent of vesting is based on the Company's financial performance relative to EBITDA targets stipulated by the Board of Directors. The vesting of both Service and Performance Options are contingent upon continuous employment through the respective measurement dates.

 On January 31, 2019, the Solenis Holdings Top II B.V. Stock Incentive Plan was superseded by the Solenis UK International Limited Stock Incentive Plan ("the Plan") as part of the closing of the Joint Venture. All outstanding Service Options to purchase shares in Solenis Holdings Top II B.V. were converted to options to purchase ordinary shares in the Company. Service Options which were vested were exchanged for fully vested options. Unvested Service Options were exchanged for Service Options with identical vesting periods to the canceled awards. As of June 30, 2021, 171,783 shares or options were available for grant.

 In connection with the JV, all holders of Class A and B shares were provided with a return of capital conveyed in cash to facilitate the required equity holdings amongst the JV participants (CD&R, BASF and management shareholders). In addition, and to uphold the anti-dilutive provision of the Plan, the intrinsic value of all Class B options was kept constant through a reduction of option exercise prices equal to the per-share value of the return of capital conveyed to all Class A and B equity holders. In circumstances where this was not possible due to limitations under Section 409(a) of the Internal Revenue Code, the Company compensated option holders in cash totaling $4.4 million. This cash is considered to be a return of capital and presented as a reduction to Additional paid-in capital on the Condensed Consolidated Balance Sheet.

 The Company applied the guidance prescribed by ASC 718, Compensation - Stock Compensation, to determine the appropriate accounting treatment regarding the cancellation of the old awards and simultaneous grant of new awards. Based on the prescribed guidance, the Company determined that the two transactions, in combination, represent a modification of the original award. Subsequent accounting for modifications is predicated upon the fair value of the original award immediately before and the new award immediately after the modification. Management's analysis concluded that the fair value of the new award did not exceed the fair value of the old award on the modification date. Therefore, the Company will continue to ratably recognize the unrecognized stock-based compensation expense for the original awards based on the fair value of the awards as of the original grant date over the remaining vesting period.

 Compensation expense for the nine months ended June 30, 2021 and 2020 was $1.7 million, and $1.4 million.

 In addition, as part of the closing of the Joint Venture, all unvested Performance Options to purchase shares in Solenis Holdings Top II B.V. were canceled and new Performance Options were granted to replace the canceled awards. The exchange of Service and Performance Options for new awards are collectively referred to as the "Modification".

 Stock Options

 Stock incentive plan allows stock option grants for shares at a price based on the most recent valuation of the Company's ordinary shares at the time of the grant and may be subject to anti-dilution. Stock options under the plan become exercisable over four equal annual installments. Every option equals one share. Our policy is to


-----

 recognize compensation expense on a straight-line basis over the requisite period for the entire award. Forfeitures are recognized as they occur.

 Share-based compensation expense is recognized as a component of Selling, general, and administrative expense. The Company records compensation expense related to all stock awards based on the grant date fair value of the awards. Compensation expense for Service Options is recognized over the requisite service period, while expense for Performance Options is recognized over the performance period based on successful achievement of performance-based conditions or targets.

 Stock Appreciation Rights

 Certain employees were granted Stock Appreciation Rights ("SARs"), representing stock awards to be settled in cash. The Company recognized these as liability-classified awards in accordance with ASC 718. Consistent with our equity based awards, the Company has SARs which vest in accordance with service ("Service SARs") and performance ("Performance SARs") conditions. SAR based compensation is included as a part of Selling, general, and administrative expenses.

 Like the Service Options, Service SARs originally issued as part of the Plan which participated in the appreciation of the price of Class B Shares were converted to rights to participate in share price appreciation of the Company's Ordinary shares. Vested SARs were converted to vested SARs and unvested SARs were converted to SARs with identical vesting and other contractual conditions. Strike prices were revised in accordance with the Plan's anti- dilution provision.

 Like the Performance Options, all Performance SARs were canceled as of the Modification date. 1,600 Performance SARs have been granted during the nine months ended June 30, 2021.

 Stock appreciation rights issued under the plan are remeasured to fair value at each reporting date using Black- Scholes inputs applicable at the reporting date. Differences in fair value between reporting dates are recognized in earnings as part of Selling, general, and administrative expense to the extent that awards have vested or are expected to vest. 

 As of June 30, 2021, and September 30, 2020, the fair value of SARs outstanding were $0.6 million and $0.2 million, respectively. The fair value of SARs outstanding are included as part of Accrued expenses on the Condensed Consolidated Balance Sheet as of June 30, 2021, and September 30, 2020. All outstanding SARs were exercisable as of June 30, 2021, and September 30, 2020.

 Restricted Stock Units

 In February 2020, certain members of the management team were granted a total of 1.1 million Restricted Stock Units (RSU) with a term of seven years and vesting contingent upon a combination of a liquidation event (Performance Obligation), the implied per-share equity value of the liquidation event at a pre-defined minimum threshold amount (Market Condition), and that a grantee continues to render service until the date of the liquidation event (Service Condition).

 Vesting of the RSU's range between 70% - 100%, where 70% is at minimum pre-defined exit price per share and 100% is at maximum pre-defined exit price per share.

 In the event of vesting, grantees shall receive cash proceeds within 75 days of the liquidity event. Although, at the discretion of the Board, the cash proceeds may be required for an equity contribution back to the Company. Grantees that leave the Company either voluntarily or involuntarily prior to vesting conditions are met will forfeit their respective grants.

 In March 2021, certain members of the management team were granted a total of 0.5 million RSU's with a term of seven years and vesting contingent upon the Company achieving certain EBITDA targets.

 In accordance with ASC 718, Stock Compensation, vesting of these awards is contingent upon performance obligations and market conditions which are outside of management's control and such conditions cannot be assumed or estimated based on lack of history and potential outcomes. As the likelihood of achievement of the Performance condition cannot be assessed as "probable", no compensation expense will be recognized until the performance condition is achieved. As such, no expense was recognized with respect to these awards during the nine months ended June 30, 2021.

 Since January 31, 2019, and as of June 30, 2021, voting control in Solenis is held collectively by CD&R which owns 49.5% of all outstanding shares, and management which owns 1.5% of the outstanding shares. Management

 has legally assigned their voting rights to CD&R, allowing CD&R to 51% control of outstanding voting rights. As a result of the JV, BASF owns 49% of the outstanding shares of Solenis.

 Relationship with CD&R

 On July 31, 2014, International, through its subsidiary, Solenis Switzerland Holdings GmbH, entered into a management and consulting agreement with CD&R pursuant to which CD&R provides, on a nonexclusive basis, management, consulting and advisory services to Solenis Switzerland Holdings GmbH and certain of its divisions and subsidiaries. Under the agreement, the Company is required to pay an annual advisory fee in the amount of $3.5 million plus 1% of the transaction value of any acquisitions, dispositions, or financing transactions incurred during the year for services provided (the “Advisory Fee”). Under the terms of the agreement, the Company is also required to reimburse CD&R for its out-of-pocket expenses.

 Advisory fees incurred during the three months ended June 30, 2021 and 2020 were both $0.9 million. These fees are included as a component of Selling, general and administrative expense for all reporting periods presented. Advisory fees incurred during the nine months ended June 30, 2021 and 2020 were both $2.7 million. These fees are included as a component of Selling, general and administrative expense for all reporting periods presented.

 Transactions with CD&R or any of its affiliate companies are conducted on terms similar to those of third party transactions. For the three months ended and the nine months ended June 30, 2021 and 2020, there was no purchase of goods and services from CD&R or its affiliates or sales of goods and services to CD&R or its affiliates. The Company had no total payables due to or receivables due from affiliates of CD&R as of both June 30, 2021, and September 30, 2020, respectively.

 As of June 30, 2021 and September 30, 2020, a wholly-owned subsidiary of CD&R held $100.0 million of principal of the Company's Second Lien Credit Agreement. The terms of the Second Lien Credit Agreement are consistent with the unrelated lenders in the syndicate.

 Exclusive of these agreements, Solenis is not aware of any material transactions with CD&R or any of its affiliate companies which were not conducted on terms similar to those conducted with third-parties.

 Relationship with BASF

 On January 31, 2019 as part of the JV, Solenis entered into a management and consulting arrangement with BASF pursuant to which BASF provides, on a nonexclusive basis, management, consulting and advisory services to Solenis and certain of its divisions and subsidiaries. Under the agreement, Solenis is required to pay an annual advisory fee in the amount of $3.5 million. The advisory fees incurred during the three months ended were both $0.9 million, and during the nine months ended June 30, 2021 and 2020 were both $2.7 million, respectively, and are included as a component of Selling, general and administrative expense on the Condensed Consolidated Statement of Operations.

 As part of the JV, Solenis prepaid for an option to purchase an existing BASF manufacturing facility located in Nanjing, China. This option was exercisable 36 months from the JV close date with nominal consideration due upon exercise. However, the Company conveyed $59.9 million through an interest-free loan between Solenis Holdings Top I B.V., a wholly-owned subsidiary of Solenis, and BASF NL.  long-term supply agreement during the three months ended June 30, 2021.  Note 20  Hyperinflationary Environment in Argentina

 On May 16, 2018, the International Practices Task Force categorized Argentina as a country with a highly- inflationary economy. Accounting Standards Codification 830, Foreign Currency Matters, requires entities domiciled in these jurisdictions to change their functional currency to the reporting currency of its parent entity on a prospective basis beginning in the quarter after this determination has been made.

 Solenis Argentina, S.A. ("Solenis Argentina") is a wholly-owned subsidiary of the Company; selling direct to end customers exclusively in Argentina. The Company does not have a plant in this specific subsidiary and, accordingly, the majority of its net assets are current to support local distribution activities. ###### Notes to Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements [Unaudited]

 Consolidation (and Derecognition), management determined the loss of control requires the deconsolidation of the subsidiary and a write-off of the previously consolidated net assets. Upon deconsolidation, the Company recorded a loss of $18.0 million during the three months ended June 30, 2021, reflected within Non-operating (expense) income on the Condensed Consolidated Statement of Operations. In consideration of the liquidation efforts, the Company recorded the residual fair value of its non-controlling interest of $2.5 million, equal to the value of cash on hand and other net working capital items controlled by the administrator which were previously reflected on the balance sheet of Solenis Trinidad in consolidation. The fair value of the non-controlling interest is reflected within Other Current Assets on the Condensed Consolidated Balance Sheet as of June 30, 2021. Management anticipates the liquidation procedures will be completed by December 31, 2021.

 Resulting from the liquidation, Management reviewed the criteria for the presentation of results within discontinued operations as reflected within ASC 205-20- Discontinued Operations, noting that Solenis Trinidad represents less than 1% of the Company's total assets and annualized revenues and accordingly, the liquidation does not represent a "strategic shift" required to present items within discontinued operations. Accordingly, the results of Solenis Trinidad are reflected in the Company's condensed consolidated financial statements for all periods prior to January 4, 2021.

 Note 22  Subsequent Events

 On July 3, 2021, the Company and it's beneficial owners (CD&R Seahawk Holdings, L.P. and BASF Nederland B.V., on behalf of CD&R, BASF, and Management equity holders) executed the Securities Purchase Agreement (the "SPA") with Olympus Water Holdings IV, L.P. (a Cayman Islands exempted limited partnership on behalf of Platinum Equity, a global Private Equity firm based in the United States) to sell 100% of the equity in Solenis for an enterprise value of $5.25 billion. Residual proceeds available to current equity holders are expected to be conveyed net of considerations for indebtedness and working capital adjustments. The transaction is expected to close on or around October 1, 2021.

 Subsequent events have been evaluated through September 6, 2021, which is the date the financial statements were available to be issued.

**Note 1: Business and Summary of Significant Accounting Principles**

**_Organization and Description of the Business_**

Innovative Water Care Global Corporation (“IWC” or “we” or “our” or the “Company”), doing business as Sigura, is
one of the world’s leading suppliers of sanitizers and other treatment chemicals for pools, spas and industrial water
applications. We maintain six production facilities throughout North America, South America, Europe, and Africa and
sales locations in all major regions globally. We have three manufacturing facilities that primarily produce calcium
hypoclorite for water treatment and three packaging plants that produce finished products for sale to customers.

**_Acquisition by Platinum Equity Capital Partners IV, L.P._**

On February 28, 2019, IWC, through its indirect majority parent, Platinum Equity Capital Partners IV, L.P. (hereafter
“Platinum Equity”) completed the acquisition of the water treatment business (“Water Care”) from Lonza Group AG
(“Lonza”) for $622.9 million, (hereafter the “Transaction”). The acquisition by IWC was accounted for in accordance
with Accounting Standards Codification (“ASC”) 805, Business Combinations (ASC 805) and we have elected to adopt
push-down accounting in the accompanying financial statements under ASU 2014-17 and ASC 805-50-3010. Accordingly, in the accompanying December 31, 2019 consolidated balance sheet, the consideration transferred in
connection with the acquisition has been “pushed down” to the assets acquired and liabilities assumed and recorded at
fair value in accordance with ASC 805. Due to the impact of the acquisition and push down accounting, the Company’s
consolidated and combined financial statements and certain note presentations for the year ended December 31, 2019,
are presented in two distinct periods to indicate the application of a different basis of accounting between the periods
presented: (1) the period up to and including the acquisition date (January 1, 2019 through February 28, 2019, labeled
“Predecessor”) and (2) the period after that date (March 1, 2019 through December 31, 2019, labeled “Successor”). As
a result of the foregoing, the accompanying consolidated and combined financial statements are not comparable and are
separated by a black line.

See also Note 2 – Acquisition by Platinum Equity for further information.

**_Basis of Presentation and Consolidation Policy_**

The consolidated and combined financial statements have been prepared in accordance with accounting principles
generally accepted in the United States (“GAAP”) and include the accounts of the Company and its wholly owned
subsidiaries. All significant intercompany balances and transactions have been eliminated.

Prior to the acquisition by IWC, the Water Care business did not exist as a separate reporting group. Therefore, the
period January 1, 2019 to February 28, 2019 included within these financial statements and notes to the financial
statements represent the historical combined and “carve-out” activity of the Water Care business during the Predecessor
period in which it was owned by Lonza. Prior to the acquisition, certain corporate, and general and administrative
expenses of Lonza were allocated to the Water Care business primarily on the basis of the proportion of net sales of the
Water Care business versus non-Water Care. In the opinion of management, such an allocation is reasonable. However,
such expenses are not indicative of, nor is it practical or meaningful for management to estimate for the historical period
presented, the actual level of expenses that might have been incurred had the Water Care business been operating as an
independent company. General corporate overhead primarily includes information technology, finance and accounting,
human resources, regulatory and legal.


-----

**_Use of Estimates and Assumptions_**

The preparation of our consolidated and combined financial statements requires management to make estimates and
assumptions that affect the reported amounts of assets and liabilities at the date of the financial statements and the
reported amounts of net sales and expenses during the reporting periods. Actual results could differ from these estimates,
and changes in these estimates are recorded when known. Significant management judgment is required in determining
the accounting for, among other things, pension and postretirement benefits, purchase price allocations, useful lives for
depreciation and amortization, future cash flows associated with impairment testing for tangible and intangible longlived assets, goodwill, income taxes, contingencies, inventory obsolescence and market reserves and the valuation of
share-based compensation.

Subsequent to December 31, 2019, the COVID-19 pandemic has created significant public health concerns as well as
economic disruption, uncertainty, and volatility. If the pandemic persists or worsens, the Company’s operations could
be negatively affected, and there could be an adverse impact on the estimates and assumptions used to prepare our
consolidated and combined financial statements. It is reasonably possible such changes in estimates and assumptions
could be significant.

**_Subsequent Events_**

We evaluated events subsequent to December 31, 2020 through March 25, 2021, the date the consolidated and
combined financial statements were available to be issued.

**_Revenue Recognition_**

In May 2014, the Financial Accounting Standards Board (“FASB”) issued Accounting Standards Update (“ASU”) 201409, Revenue from Contracts with Customers (ASU 2014-09), which amends ASC 605 Revenue Recognition and creates
a new topic, ASC 606 Revenue from Contracts with Customers (ASC 606). Subsequent to the issuance of ASU 201409, ASC 606 was amended by various updates that amend and clarify the impact and implementation of the
aforementioned update. We adopted these updates on January 1, 2019, using the modified retrospective transition
method. The cumulative effect of applying the updates did not have a material impact on our consolidated and combined
financial statements.

The Company derives revenue from the sale of sanitizers and other treatment chemicals for pools, spas and other
industrial water applications. We recognize sales revenue at a point in time following the transfer of title of the product
to the customer, which typically occurs upon shipment or delivery depending on the terms of the underlying contracts.
Sales are reported net of allowable discounts and estimated returns. Reserves for cash discounts, trade allowances and
sales returns are estimated using historical experience. We account for transportation activities related to contracts with
customers as costs to fulfill our promise to transfer the associated products. Accordingly, we record transportation costs
as a component of cost of goods sold. The Company excludes tax amounts assessed by governmental authorities that are
both (i) imposed on and concurrent with a specific revenue-producing transaction and (ii) collected from customers from
our measurement of transaction prices. Accordingly, such tax amounts are not included as a component of net sales or
cost of goods sold. We consider each transaction/shipment as a separate performance obligation. We recognize revenue
when the title transfers to the customer. As such, the remaining performance obligations at period end are not considered
significant.

The Company does not typically include extended payment terms or significant financing components in our contracts
with customers. Certain product sales contracts may include cash-based incentives (volume rebates or credits), which
are accounted for as variable consideration. We estimate these amounts based on the expected forecast quantities to be
provided to customers and reduce revenues recognized accordingly. Incidental items that are immaterial in the context
of the contract are recognized as expense in the period incurred. We generally expense sales commissions when incurred
because the amortization period is one year or less.

See Note 4 — Revenue from Contracts with Customers for further information.


-----

**_Marketing and Distribution Expenses_**

Marketing and distribution expenses on the consolidated and combined statements of comprehensive loss include selling,
distribution, marketing and advertising expenses; salaries, travel and office expenses of administrative associates and
contractors; and software license fees.

Marketing and distribution costs are expensed as incurred and totaled $58.0, $62.7 and $12.5 million in 2020, 2019
Successor and Predecessor periods, respectively.

**_Research and Development Expenses_**

Research and development costs are expensed as incurred. Research and development expenses on the consolidated and
combined statements of comprehensive loss were $4.4, $4.3 and $0.9 million in 2020, 2019 Successor and Predecessor
periods, respectively.

**_Restructuring Activities_**

Restructuring charges, net include employee severance and benefit costs. We apply the provisions of ASC 420, Exit or
_Disposal Cost Obligations (ASC 420) or ASC 712, Compensation— Nonretirement Postemployment Benefits, based on_
the facts and circumstances related to our restructuring activities. Severance costs accounted for under ASC 420 are
recognized when management with the proper level of authority has committed to a restructuring plan and communicated
those actions to employees. At each reporting date, we evaluate the accruals for restructuring costs to ensure the accruals
are still appropriate. Restructuring expenses were $2.3, $2.4 and $0.1 million in 2020, 2019 Successor and Predecessor
periods, respectively. The 2020 and 2019 period expenses were primarily attributed to the termination of certain
positions. The expense is included in Transaction and restructuring expenses on the consolidated and combined
statements of comprehensive loss. We had $2.3 million remaining liabilities as part of the restructuring activities as of
December 31, 2020 and no significant remaining liabilities as part of the restructuring activities as of December 31,
2019.

**_Cash and Cash Equivalents_**

Cash and cash equivalents include investments that are highly liquid and have maturities of three months or less when
purchased. The carrying values of cash and cash equivalents approximate their fair value due to the short-term nature of
these instruments. We maintain amounts on deposit with various financial institutions, which may at times, exceed
federally insured limits. However, management periodically evaluates the creditworthiness of those institutions, and no
losses on such deposits have been recognized.

**_Accounts Receivable_**

We record accounts receivable at net realizable value. This value includes an allowance for estimated uncollectible
accounts to reflect losses anticipated on accounts receivable balances. The allowance is based on historical write-offs,
an analysis of past due accounts based on the contractual terms of the receivables, and the economic status of customers,
if known. We believe that the allowance is sufficient to cover uncollectible amounts; however, there can be no assurance
that unanticipated future business conditions of customers will not have a negative impact on our results of operations.
We generally do not require collateral for our accounts receivable.

Additions to the allowance for doubtful accounts are made by means of the provision for doubtful accounts. We writeoff uncollectible accounts receivable against the allowance for doubtful accounts after exhausting collection efforts.

**_Inventories_**

Inventories, which primarily include materials, direct labor, utilities and related manufacturing overhead, are stated at
the lower of cost or market. The cost of inventories is calculated using the weighted average cost basis.


-----

**_Property, Plant, and Equipment and Depreciation_**

We record purchases of land, buildings, capitalized software, leasehold improvements and machinery and equipment at
cost. We report depreciation of property, plant and equipment in Cost of goods sold, Marketing and distribution expenses
and Administration and general expenses on the consolidated and combined statements of comprehensive loss based on
the nature of the underlying assets. We record depreciation primarily related to the production of inventory within Cost
of goods sold. We record depreciation related to marketing, distribution and administrative functions within Marketing
and distribution expenses and Administration and general expenses.

Depreciation is determined on a straight-line basis using estimated useful lives of plant and equipment. Machinery and
equipment is typically depreciated over two to sixteen years, and buildings are being depreciated up to thirty years. We
amortize leasehold improvements over the lease term or the useful life of the improvement, whichever is shorter.

We retain fully depreciated assets in property and accumulated depreciation accounts until we remove them from service.
In case of sale, retirement or disposal, the asset cost and related accumulated depreciation balances are removed from
the respective accounts and the resulting net amount, after consideration of any proceeds, is included in Loss on sale of
property, plant and equipment on the consolidated and combined statements of cash flows and reported as Other
expenses, net on the consolidated and combined statements of comprehensive loss. Maintenance and repairs of property
and equipment are expensed as incurred. We capitalize replacements and improvements that increase the estimated
useful life of an asset.

See Note 7—Property, Plant and Equipment for further information.

**_Leases_**

We lease certain of our vehicles, buildings, warehouses, factories, and office facilities under noncancelable operating
lease agreements. Certain of these operating lease agreements contain rent escalation clauses. We expense rent on a
straight-line basis over the life of our leases, which commences on the date we have the right to control leased property.

See Note 7—Property, Plant and Equipment for further information.

**_Goodwill and Intangible Assets_**

Goodwill is tested for impairment annually, unless changes in circumstances indicate that an impairment may have
occurred sooner. Our annual testing date for impairment is the first day of the fourth fiscal quarter.

We are required to test goodwill on a reporting unit basis. A reporting unit is the operating segment unless, for businesses
within that operating segment, discrete financial information is prepared and regularly reviewed by management, in
which case such a component business is the reporting unit. We evaluated and concluded that each of the regional
components within our operating segment represent a single reporting unit. Goodwill impairment is present if a reporting
unit’s carrying value exceeds its fair value. We primarily determine the fair value of our reporting units using an income
approach and supplement this with observable valuation multiples for comparable companies, as appropriate. The
income approach, which is based on a discounted cash flow analysis, calculates the fair value of a reporting unit by
estimating after-tax cash flows discounted using the Company’s consolidated weighted average cost of capital. The cash
flows used in the analysis are based on financial forecasts developed internally by management and require significant
judgment. The significant unobservable inputs used in the fair value measurement of the reporting units are revenue
growth rate, cost of sales, and other operating expense growth rates. These assumptions are sensitive to future changes
in the business profitability, changes in our business strategy and external market conditions, among other factors.

As a result of our assessment, during 2019, we recorded a $106.6 million non-cash impairment charge to write off the
carrying value of our goodwill, which impairment is reflected in Goodwill impairment and related charges on the
consolidated and combined statements of comprehensive loss. This impairment charge does not impact our operations,
compliance with our debt covenants or our cash flows.


-----

Definite-lived intangible assets consist of customer relationships, trademarks, and technology and are amortized on a
straight-line basis over the estimated economic life of the respective intangible asset, ranging from six and a half to
fifteen and a half years. Amortization expense is recorded as a component of Administration and general expenses on
the consolidated and combined statements of comprehensive loss.

If impairment indicators related to definite-lived intangible assets are present, we estimate the undiscounted cash flows
expected to be generated over the remaining useful lives of the related asset group based on current projections. If the
projected net undiscounted cash flows are less than the carrying value of the related asset group, we then measure
impairment based on a discounted cash flow model and record an impairment charge as the excess of carrying value
over estimated fair value.

See Note 8—Goodwill and Intangibles Assets for further information.

**_Capitalization of Software Costs_**

We capitalize certain purchases of software and software development costs in connection with major projects of
software development for internal use. These expenditures totaled approximately $0.7 million in both 2020 and 2019
Successor period and are included in Other non-current assets on the consolidated balance sheets and are amortized
using the straight-line method over the estimated useful life not to exceed five years. Costs associated with business
process redesign, end-user training, system start-up and ongoing software maintenance are expensed as incurred.

**_Foreign Currency Translation and Other Expense (Income), Net_**

Other non-operating (income) expenses, net on the consolidated and combined statements of comprehensive loss
includes gains or losses on foreign currency transactions and other non-operating items. The functional currency for our
foreign operations is their local currency. Gains or losses relating to foreign currency transactions consisted of income
of $0.2 million for 2020 and was expense of $1.1 million for the 2019 Successor period and was not significant for the
2019 Predecessor period.

The income statements of foreign entities are translated into U.S. dollars at average exchange rates prevailing during the
periods presented. The balance sheets of these entities are translated at period-end exchange rates. The gains or losses
resulting from foreign currency translation are included in Other comprehensive loss and are excluded from Net loss.

**_Defined-benefit Plans (pension plans)_**

Our net obligation in respect of defined-benefit plans is calculated separately for each plan by estimating the amount of
future benefit that employees have earned in the current and prior periods, discounting that amount and deducting the
fair value of any plan assets. The calculation of defined-benefit obligations is performed annually by a qualified external
actuary using the projected unit credit method. When the calculation results in a potential asset, the recognized asset is
limited to the present value of economic benefits available in the form of any future refunds from the plan or reductions
in future contributions to the plan. To calculate the present value of economic benefits, consideration is given to any
applicable minimum funding requirements. Remeasurements of the defined-benefit liability, which comprise actuarial
gains and losses and the return on plan assets (excluding interest) and the effect of the asset ceiling (if any, excluding
interest), are recognized immediately in Other comprehensive loss.

We determine the net interest expense on the net defined-benefit liabilities for the period by applying the discount rate
used to measure the defined-benefit obligation at the beginning of the annual period to the net defined-benefit liability,
taking into account any changes in the net defined-benefit liability during the period as a result of contributions and
benefit payments. Net interest expense and other expenses related to defined-benefit plans are recognized in the
consolidated statements of comprehensive loss.

See Note 12—Employee Benefit Plans for further information.

**_Fair Value Disclosures_**

Our financial instruments consist primarily of cash and cash equivalents, trade receivables, trade payables, and debt. The
net book values of cash and cash equivalents, trade receivables, and trade payables are representative of their respective
fair values due to their short-term nature. We estimate that the carrying value of all of our outstanding debt obligations
approximates fair value based on the variable nature of our effective interest rate associated with the indebtedness, which
is a Level 2 estimate based on a market approach.

**_Future Adoption of Accounting Pronouncements_**

_Leases. In February 2016, the FASB issued ASU No. 2016-02, Leases. This new guidance establishes a right-of-use_
(“ROU”) model that requires a lessee to record a ROU asset and a lease liability on the balance sheet for all leases with
terms longer than 12 months. Leases will be classified as either financing or operating, with such classification affecting
the pattern of expense recognition in the statements of comprehensive loss. Disclosure of key information about leasing
arrangements will also be required. This new guidance is effective for fiscal years beginning after December 15, 2021
for private companies. In July 2018, the FASB issued ASU 2018-11, Leases: Targeted Improvements, as an amendment
to ASU 2016-02, Leases, which provides entities with an additional transition method to recognize a cumulative-effect
adjustment to the opening balance of retained earnings in the period of adoption. We will adopt the accounting standard
using a modified retrospective transition approach on January 1, 2022, which applies the provisions of the new guidance
at the effective date without adjusting the comparative periods presented, and will elect the package of practical
expedients, short-term practical expedient and the expedient to not separate lease components from non-lease
components. While the adoption of this new guidance will not have a significant impact on our results of operations, the
adoption will require us to record a ROU asset and a corresponding lease liability upon adoption.

As of December 31, 2020, no other amendments to the ASC had been issued and not adopted by the Company that will
have or are reasonably likely to have a material effect on its financial position, results of operations or cash flows.

**Note 4: Revenue from Contracts with Customers**

The majority of our annual revenues are recognized upon delivery and customer acceptance, paid for on account having
terms generally between 30 and 120 days, with most paying within 90 days. We believe that, based on experience with
similar transactions, the quality delivered will generally be accepted. Therefore, revenue is generally recognized when
title is transferred upon delivery of the products. Revenue is measured at the fair value of the consideration received or
receivable. Amounts disclosed as revenue are net of returns, trade allowances, and rebates.

We derive revenue from the sale of sanitizers and other treatment chemicals for pools, spas and water parks (revenue
stream “Residential Water Products”). Furthermore, we generate revenue in the treatment of water for drinking,

**2019 Credit Facilities**

On February 28, 2019, we entered into a $125 million asset-based revolving credit facility due February 28, 2024, a
$360 million first lien term loan credit facility due February 28, 2026, and a $100 million second lien term loan credit
facility due February 28, 2027 (the “2019 Credit Facilities” or “Term Loans”) with Bank of America, as Administrative
Agent and Collateral Agent. The revolving credit facility permits the issuance of letters of credit and swingline loans.

The 2019 Credit Facilities are guaranteed by the Company and certain of our domestic subsidiaries (the “Guarantors”).
Pursuant to the 2019 Credit Facilities, the Guarantors guarantee to the Lenders, among other things, all of the obligations
of the Company and each Guarantor under the 2019 Credit Facilities. Borrowings under the 2019 Credit Facilities are
secured by substantially all of the Company’s and each Guarantor’s owned real and personal property.

Interest rates are variable and are based on, at the option of the borrowers, LIBOR or base rate for United States dollar
loans, and CDOR or Canadian prime for Canadian dollar loans. In addition to paying interest on borrowings under the
2019 Credit Facilities, the borrowers are required to pay a commitment fee on the unused portion of the revolver as well
an agency fee to Bank of America. Under the terms of the 2019 Credit Facilities, accrued interest on each loan is payable
in arrears on the applicable interest payment date for each loan. Principal repayments on the Term Loan are to be paid
quarterly beginning June 30, 2019 in such amounts as set forth in the 2019 Credit Facilities. The revolving credit facility
is subject to a borrowing base and is available to fund capital expenditures, investments, acquisitions, distribution
payments, working capital and other corporate purposes. We will be required to make prepayments when and to the
extent the aggregate amount of outstanding loans and letters of credit under the asset-based revolving credit facility
exceeds the lesser of the aggregate amount of commitments in respect of the asset-based revolving credit facility or the
borrowing base.

The 2019 Credit Facilities contains customary covenants and default provisions and are subject to restrictions with
respect to indebtedness and guarantees, liens, consolidations and mergers, change of control, sales of certain assets, lines
of business and distributions. On any date when Global Availability, as defined, is less than the greater of (a) 10.0% of
the Line Cap, as defined, or (b) $7.5 million, the revolving credit facility also requires us to have a Consolidated Fixed
Charge Coverage Ratio of at least 1 to 1. The default provisions under the 2019 Credit Facilities include, among other
things, defaults for nonpayment, breach of representations and warranties, insolvency, nonperformance of covenants,
cross-defaults and guarantor defaults. The occurrence of an event of default under the 2019 Credit Facilities could result
in all loans and other obligations becoming immediately due and payable and the revolving credit facility being
terminated. We are in compliance with all applicable covenants as of December 31, 2020.

The all-in interest rates in effect as of December 31, 2020, for the revolving credit facility, the first lien term loan, and
the second lien term loan were 3.8%, 6.0%, and 10.0%, respectively.

We account for income taxes using the asset and liability approach. This approach requires recognition of deferred tax
liabilities and assets for the expected future tax consequences of events that have been included in the financial
statements or tax returns. Using the enacted tax rates in effect for the year in which the differences are expected to
reverse, deferred tax liabilities and assets are determined based on the differences between the financial reporting and
the tax basis of an asset or liability. Management has established valuation allowances when it determines that it is
more likely than not that some portion, or all, of the deferred tax assets will not be realized based on available
evidence.

We are subject to U.S. federal income tax as well as income tax in multiple state and non-U.S. jurisdictions. With
respect to federal and state income tax, tax returns for all years are subject to future examination by local tax
authorities. With respect to material non-U.S. jurisdictions in which we operate, we have open tax years ranging from
2 to 15 years. The Company is under an indemnification agreement with the seller for open tax years preceding the
acquisition in 2019. We don't anticipate any material changes to our unrecognized tax benefits balance within the next
twelve months.

As of December 31, 2020, we concluded that any temporary differences related to any excess in the amount of
financial reporting basis over the tax basis of our investment in our foreign subsidiaries are immaterial. Therefore, we
accrued no deferred tax liabilities related to temporary differences for our investment in foreign subsidiaries as of
December 31, 2020. We also considered the effects of a hypothetical distribution on a legal entity basis using a
bottoms-up approach, including the effect of any withholding taxes and determined the potential effects.
Consequently, we accrued foreign withholding taxes of approximately $0.2 million which would be payable upon
remittance of all previously unremitted earnings as of December 31, 2020.

Deferred tax assets were partially offset by valuation allowances of $51.0 million at both December 31, 2020 and
2019. Our assumptions, judgments and estimates relative to the value of our deferred tax assets also take into account
predictions of the amount and the categories of future taxable income, carry-back and carry-forward periods and tax
strategies which could impact the realization of a deferred tax asset. As of December 31, 2020, we could not sustain a
conclusion that it was more likely than not that we would realize most of our deferred tax assets resulting from recent
losses as well as other factors. Consequently, we maintain a valuation allowance against those deferred tax assets. The


-----

majority of deferred tax assets which are not subject to a valuation allowance are located outside of the United States.
We have maintained a valuation allowance as a result of weighing all positive and negative evidence, including the
Company's history of losses in recent years and the difficulty of forecasting future taxable income. We intend to
maintain a valuation allowance until sufficient positive evidence exists to support its reversal.

Our U.S. federal net operating losses will not expire by statute. Domestic state net operating loss carryforwards expire
between tax years 2024 and 2039. Unless utilized, certain non-U.S. net operating losses will expire in tax years 2029
through 2039, others may be carried forward indefinitely.

We believe that an ownership change, as defined under Internal Revenue Code section 382, did not occur during the
2019 tax year with respect to the U.S. entities. We have not analyzed the potential implications of an ownership
change related to our foreign entities. If certain substantial changes in the entity's ownership occur, there would be an
annual limitation on the amount of the carryforwards that can be utilized. As discussed above, we maintain a valuation
allowance against deferred tax assets, including net operating losses and credit carryforwards, which are not
considered more likely than not to be realized.

As of December 31, 2020, we had no gross tax-effected unrecognized tax benefits (including interest and penalties),
which, if recognized, would affect our effective tax rate. There were no interest and penalties recognized in our
operating results. There are no significant increases in the amount of unrecognized tax benefits anticipated within the
next twelve months.

We recognize potential accrued interest and penalties related to unrecognized tax benefits, if any, in income tax
expense.

**_CARES Act_**

On March 27, 2020, the President of the Unites States signed into law the Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic
Security Act ("CARES Act"). There were several income tax provisions included in the CARES Act, as well as other
non-tax matters incorporated into law as a result of the enactment of the CARES Act.

Overall, the income tax provisions of the CARES Act are not expected to have a material impact on our financial
statements.

**_Consolidated Appropriations Act_**

On December 27, 2020, the President of the United States signed into law the Consolidated Appropriations Act 2021.
There were several income tax provisions included in this bill which include forgiveness of PPP loans, deferred
payroll taxes, extensions of certain tax provisions, employee retentions credits, and other provisions.

Overall, the income tax provisions of the Consolidated Appropriations Act 2021 are not expected to have a material
impact on our financial statements.

**Note 11: Commitments and Contingencies**

**_Litigation_**

We are subject to various legal claims arising in the normal course of business. Based on information currently available,
it is the opinion of management that the ultimate resolution of pending and threatened legal proceedings will not have a
material adverse effect on our results of operations, financial position, or cash flows. However, in the event of unexpected
future developments, it is possible that the ultimate resolution of such matters, if unfavorable, could have a material
adverse effect on our results of operations, financial position, or cash flows.

We establish accruals for legal claims when the costs associated with the claims become probable and can be reasonably
estimated. The actual costs of resolving legal claims may be substantially higher or lower than the amounts accrued for
such claims. In many cases, we are unable to make a meaningful estimate of actual costs or a range of reasonably possible
losses that could possibly be higher or lower than the amounts accrued.

**_Environmental Matters_**

We are subject to environmental laws and regulations related to the use, storage, handling, generation, transportation,
emission, discharge, disposal and remediation of, and exposure to, hazardous and non-hazardous substances and wastes
in all countries which we do business. We monitor the costs associated with these laws and regulations and do not have
a material liability related to environmental matters.

We maintain multiple non-qualified deferred compensation plans for the benefit of eligible employees. The plans are

**Note 1: Business and Summary of Significant Accounting Principles**

**_Organization and Description of the Business_**

Innovative Water Care Global Corporation (“IWC” or “we” or “our” or the “Company”), doing business as Sigura, is one
of the world’s leading suppliers of sanitizers and other treatment chemicals for pools, spas and industrial water
applications. We maintain six production facilities throughout North America, South America, Europe, and Africa and
sales locations in all major regions globally. We have three manufacturing facilities that primarily produce calcium
hypoclorite for water treatment and three packaging plants that produce finished products for sale to customers.

**_Basis of Presentation and Consolidation Policy_**

The consolidated financial statements have been prepared in accordance with accounting principles generally accepted in
the United States (“GAAP”) and include the accounts of the Company and its wholly owned subsidiaries. All significant
intercompany balances and transactions have been eliminated. In the opinion of management, all adjustments (consisting
of normal recurring accruals) considered necessary for a fair presentation have been included. Operating results for the
six months ended June 30, 2021 are not necessarily indicative of the results that may be expected for the year ending
December 31, 2021.

**_Use of Estimates and Assumptions_**

The preparation of our consolidated financial statements requires management to make estimates and assumptions that
affect the reported amounts of assets and liabilities at the date of the financial statements and the reported amounts of net
sales and expenses during the reporting periods. Actual results could differ from these estimates, and changes in these
estimates are recorded when known. Significant management judgment is required in determining the accounting for,
among other things, pension and postretirement benefits, useful lives for depreciation and amortization, future cash flows
associated with impairment testing for tangible and intangible long-lived assets, goodwill, income taxes, contingencies,
inventory obsolescence and market reserves and the valuation of share-based compensation.

Subsequent to December 31, 2019, the COVID-19 pandemic has created significant public health concerns as well as
economic disruption, uncertainty, and volatility. If the pandemic persists or worsens, the Company’s operations could be
negatively affected, and there could be an adverse impact on the estimates and assumptions used to prepare our
consolidated financial statements. It is reasonably possible such changes in estimates and assumptions could be significant.

**_Revenue Recognition_**

The Company derives revenue from the sale of sanitizers and other treatment chemicals for pools, spas and other industrial
water applications. We recognize sales at a point in time following the transfer of title of the product to the customer,
which typically occurs upon shipment or delivery depending on the terms of the underlying contracts. Sales are reported
net of allowable discounts and estimated returns. Reserves for cash discounts, trade allowances and sales returns are
estimated using historical experience. We account for transportation activities related to contracts with customers as costs
to fulfill our promise to transfer the associated products. Accordingly, we record transportation costs as a component of
cost of goods sold. The Company excludes tax amounts assessed by governmental authorities that are both (i) imposed on
and concurrent with a specific revenue-producing transaction and (ii) collected from customers from our measurement of
transaction prices. Accordingly, such tax amounts are not included as a component of net sales or cost of goods sold. We
consider each transaction/shipment as a separate performance obligation. We recognize revenue when the title transfers


-----

to the customer. As such, the remaining performance obligations at period end are not considered significant.

The Company does not typically include extended payment terms or significant financing components in its contracts with
customers. Certain product sales contracts may include cash-based incentives (volume rebates or credits), which are
accounted for as variable consideration. We estimate these amounts based on the expected forecasted quantities to be
provided to customers and reduce sales recognized accordingly. Incidental items that are immaterial in the context of the
contract are recognized as expense in the period incurred. We generally expense sales commissions when incurred because
the amortization period is one year or less.

See Note 2 — Sales from Contracts with Customers for further information.

**_Marketing and Distribution Expenses_**

Marketing and distribution expenses on the consolidated statements of comprehensive income (loss) include selling,
distribution, marketing and advertising expenses; salaries, travel and office expenses of sales associates and contractors;
and software license fees.

Marketing and distribution costs are expensed as incurred and totaled $23.9 and $27.1 million for the six months ended
June 30, 2021 and 2020, respectively.

**_Research and Development Expenses_**

Research and development costs are expensed as incurred. Research and development expenses on the consolidated
statements of comprehensive income (loss) were $1.6 and $1.8 million for the six months ended June 30, 2021 and 2020,
respectively.

**_Restructuring Activities_**

Restructuring charges, net include employee severance and benefit costs. We apply the provisions of ASC 420, Exit or
_Disposal Cost Obligations (ASC 420) or ASC 712, Compensation— Nonretirement Postemployment Benefits, based on_
the facts and circumstances related to our restructuring activities. Severance costs accounted for under ASC 420 are
recognized when management with the proper level of authority has committed to a restructuring plan and communicated
those actions to employees. At each reporting date, we evaluate the accruals for restructuring costs to ensure the accruals
are still appropriate. We had $0 and $2.3 million accrued for restructuring activities as of June 30, 2021 and December
31, 2020, respectively. There were no significant restructuring expenses recorded during the six months ended June 30,
2021 and 2020.

**_Cash and Cash Equivalents_**

Cash and cash equivalents include investments that are highly liquid and have maturities of three months or less when
purchased. The carrying values of cash and cash equivalents approximate their fair value due to the short-term nature of
these instruments. We maintain amounts on deposit with various financial institutions, which may at times, exceed
federally insured limits. However, management periodically evaluates the creditworthiness of those institutions, and no
losses on such deposits have been recognized.

**_Accounts Receivable_**

We record accounts receivable at net realizable value. This value includes an allowance for estimated uncollectible
accounts to reflect losses anticipated on accounts receivable balances. The allowance is based on historical write-offs, an
analysis of past due accounts based on the contractual terms of the receivables, and the economic status of customers, if
known. We believe that the allowance is sufficient to cover uncollectible amounts; however, there can be no assurance
that unanticipated future business conditions of customers will not have a negative impact on our results of operations.
We generally do not require collateral for our accounts receivable.

Additions to the allowance for doubtful accounts are made by means of the provision for doubtful accounts. We write-off
uncollectible accounts receivable against the allowance for doubtful accounts after exhausting collection efforts.


-----

**_Inventories_**

Inventories, which primarily include materials, direct labor, utilities and related manufacturing overhead, are stated at the
lower of cost or market. The cost of inventories is calculated using the weighted average cost basis.

**_Property, Plant, and Equipment and Depreciation_**

We record purchases of land, buildings, capitalized software, leasehold improvements and machinery and equipment at
cost. We report depreciation of property, plant and equipment in Cost of goods sold, Marketing and distribution expenses
and Administration and general expenses on the consolidated statements of comprehensive income (loss) based on the
nature of the underlying assets. We record depreciation primarily related to the production of inventory within Cost of
goods sold. We record depreciation related to marketing, distribution and administrative functions within Marketing and
distribution expenses and Administration and general expenses.

Depreciation is determined on a straight-line basis using estimated useful lives of plant and equipment. Machinery and
equipment is typically depreciated over two to sixteen years, and buildings are being depreciated up to thirty years. We
amortize leasehold improvements over the lease term or the useful life of the improvement, whichever is shorter.

We retain fully depreciated assets in property and accumulated depreciation accounts until we remove them from service.
In case of sale, retirement or disposal, the asset cost and related accumulated depreciation balances are removed from the
respective accounts and the resulting net amount, after consideration of any proceeds, is included in Loss on sale of
property, plant and equipment on the consolidated statements of cash flows and reported as Other expenses, net on the
consolidated statements of comprehensive income (loss). Maintenance and repairs of property and equipment are expensed
as incurred. We capitalize replacements and improvements that increase the estimated useful life of an asset.

**_Leases_**

We lease certain of our vehicles, buildings, warehouses, factories, and office facilities under noncancelable operating lease
agreements. Certain of these operating lease agreements contain rent escalation clauses. We expense rent on a straightline basis over the life of our leases, which commences on the date we have the right to control leased property.

**_Intangible Assets_**

Definite-lived intangible assets consist of customer relationships, trademarks, and technology and are amortized on a
straight-line basis over the estimated economic life of the respective intangible asset, ranging from six and a half to fifteen
and a half years. Amortization expense is recorded as a component of Administration and general expenses on the
consolidated statements of comprehensive income (loss).

If impairment indicators related to definite-lived intangible assets are present, we estimate the undiscounted cash flows
expected to be generated over the remaining useful lives of the related asset group based on current projections. If the
projected net undiscounted cash flows are less than the carrying value of the related asset group, we then measure
impairment based on a discounted cash flow model and record an impairment charge as the excess of carrying value over
estimated fair value.

See Note 5—Intangibles Assets for further information.

**_Capitalization of Software Costs_**

We capitalize certain purchases of software and software development costs in connection with major projects of software
development for internal use. These expenditures totaled $0.1 million and $0.0 million for the six months ended June 30,
2021 and 2020, respectively and are included in Other non-current assets on the consolidated balance sheets and are
amortized using the straight-line method over the estimated useful life not to exceed five years. Costs associated with
business process redesign, end-user training, system start-up and ongoing software maintenance are expensed as incurred.


-----

**_Foreign Currency Translation and Other Expense (Income), Net_**

Other non-operating (income) expense, net on the consolidated statements of comprehensive income (loss) includes gains
or losses on foreign currency transactions and other non-operating items. The functional currency for our foreign
operations is their local currency. Gains or losses relating to foreign currency transactions consisted of income of $0.3
million and $7.3 million for the six months ended June 30, 2021 and 2020, respectively.

The income statements of foreign entities are translated into U.S. dollars at average exchange rates prevailing during the
periods presented. The balance sheets of these entities are translated at period-end exchange rates. The gains or losses
resulting from foreign currency translation are included in Other comprehensive income (loss) and are excluded from Net
income (loss).

**_Defined-benefit Plans (pension plans)_**

Our net obligation in respect of defined-benefit plans is calculated separately for each plan by estimating the amount of
future benefit that employees have earned in the current and prior periods, discounting that amount and deducting the fair
value of any plan assets. The calculation of defined-benefit obligations is performed annually by a qualified external
actuary using the projected unit credit method. When the calculation results in a potential asset, the recognized asset is
limited to the present value of economic benefits available in the form of any future refunds from the plan or reductions
in future contributions to the plan. To calculate the present value of economic benefits, consideration is given to any
applicable minimum funding requirements. Remeasurements of the defined-benefit liability, which comprise actuarial
gains and losses and the return on plan assets (excluding interest) and the effect of the asset ceiling (if any, excluding
interest), are recognized immediately in Other comprehensive income (loss).

We determine the net interest expense on the net defined-benefit liabilities for the period by applying the discount rate
used to measure the defined-benefit obligation at the beginning of the annual period to the net defined-benefit liability,
taking into account any changes in the net defined-benefit liability during the period as a result of contributions and benefit
payments. Net interest expense and other expenses related to defined-benefit plans are recognized in the consolidated
statements of comprehensive income (loss).

**_Fair Value Disclosures_**

Our financial instruments consist primarily of cash and cash equivalents, trade receivables, trade payables, and debt. The
net book values of cash and cash equivalents, trade receivables, and trade payables are representative of their respective
fair values due to their short-term nature. We estimate that the carrying value of all of our outstanding debt obligations
approximates fair value based on the variable nature of our effective interest rate associated with the indebtedness, which
is a Level 2 estimate based on a market approach.

**_Future Adoption of Accounting Pronouncements_**

In February 2016, the FASB issued ASU No. 2016-02, Leases. This new guidance establishes a right-of-use (“ROU”)
model that requires a lessee to record a ROU asset and a lease liability on the balance sheet for all leases with terms longer
than 12 months. Leases will be classified as either financing or operating, with such classification affecting the pattern of
expense recognition in the consolidated statements of comprehensive income (loss). Disclosure of key information about
leasing arrangements will also be required. This new guidance is effective for fiscal years beginning after December 15,
2021 for private companies. In July 2018, the FASB issued ASU 2018-11, _Leases: Targeted Improvements, as an_
amendment to ASU 2016-02, _Leases, which provides entities with an additional transition method to recognize a_
cumulative-effect adjustment to the opening balance of retained earnings in the period of adoption. We will adopt the
accounting standard using a modified retrospective transition approach on January 1, 2022, which applies the provisions
of the new guidance at the effective date without adjusting the comparative periods presented, and will elect the package
of practical expedients, short-term practical expedient and the expedient to not separate lease components from non-lease
components. While the adoption of this new guidance will not have a significant impact on our results of operations, the
adoption will require us to record a ROU asset and a corresponding lease liability upon adoption.

As of June 30, 2021, no other amendments to the ASC had been issued and not adopted by the Company that will have or
are reasonably likely to have a material effect on its financial position, results of operations or cash flows.

**Note 2: Sales from Contracts with Customers**

The majority of our sales are recognized upon delivery and customer acceptance, paid for on account having terms
generally between 30 and 120 days, with most paying within 90 days. We believe that, based on experience with similar
transactions, the quality delivered will generally be accepted. Therefore, revenue is generally recognized when title is
transferred upon delivery of the products. Revenue is measured at the fair value of the consideration received or receivable.
Amounts disclosed as revenue are net of returns, trade allowances, and rebates.

We derive revenue from the sale of sanitizers and other treatment chemicals for pools, spas and water parks (revenue
stream “Residential Water Products”). Furthermore, we generate revenue in the treatment of water for drinking,

**2019 Credit Facilities**

On February 28, 2019, we entered into a $125 million asset-based revolving credit facility due February 28, 2024, a $360
million first lien term loan credit facility due February 28, 2026, and a $100 million second lien term loan credit facility
due February 28, 2027 (the “2019 Credit Facilities” or “Term Loans”) with Bank of America, as Administrative Agent
and Collateral Agent. The revolving credit facility permits the issuance of letters of credit and swingline loans.

The 2019 Credit Facilities are guaranteed by the Company and certain of our domestic subsidiaries (the “Guarantors”).
Pursuant to the 2019 Credit Facilities, the Guarantors guarantee to the Lenders, among other things, all of the obligations
of the Company and each Guarantor under the 2019 Credit Facilities. Borrowings under the 2019 Credit Facilities are
secured by substantially all of the Company’s and each Guarantor’s owned real and personal property.

Interest rates are variable and are based on, at the option of the borrowers, LIBOR or base rate for United States dollar
loans, and CDOR or Canadian prime for Canadian dollar loans. In addition to paying interest on borrowings under the
2019 Credit Facilities, the borrowers are required to pay a commitment fee on the unused portion of the revolver as well
an agency fee to Bank of America. Under the terms of the 2019 Credit Facilities, accrued interest on each loan is payable
in arrears on the applicable interest payment date for each loan. Principal repayments on the Term Loan are to be paid
quarterly beginning June 30, 2019 in such amounts as set forth in the 2019 Credit Facilities. The revolving credit facility
is subject to a borrowing base and is available to fund capital expenditures, investments, acquisitions, distribution
payments, working capital and other corporate purposes. We will be required to make prepayments when and to the extent
the aggregate amount of outstanding loans and letters of credit under the asset-based revolving credit facility exceeds the
lesser of the aggregate amount of commitments in respect of the asset-based revolving credit facility or the borrowing
base.

The 2019 Credit Facilities contains customary covenants and default provisions and are subject to restrictions with respect
to indebtedness and guarantees, liens, consolidations and mergers, change of control, sales of certain assets, lines of
business and distributions. On any date when Global Availability, as defined, is less than the greater of (a) 10.0% of the
Line Cap, as defined, or (b) $7.5 million, the revolving credit facility also requires us to have a Consolidated Fixed Charge
Coverage Ratio of at least 1 to 1. The default provisions under the 2019 Credit Facilities include, among other things,
defaults for nonpayment, breach of representations and warranties, insolvency, nonperformance of covenants, crossdefaults and guarantor defaults. The occurrence of an event of default under the 2019 Credit Facilities could result in all
loans and other obligations becoming immediately due and payable and the revolving credit facility being terminated. We
are in compliance with all applicable covenants as of June 30, 2021.

The all-in interest rates in effect as of June 30, 2021, for the revolving credit facility, the first lien term loan, and the
second lien term loan were 3.8%, 6.0%, and 10.0%, respectively.

**_Interest Expense, Net_**

Interest expense, net, is composed primarily of interest expense on our variable rate debt instruments, partially offset by
interest income on cash and cash equivalents. We made interest payments of $18.2 and $16.3 million during the six months
ended June 30, 2021 and 2020, respectively.

**Note 7: Income Taxes**

Our effective tax rate differs from the statutory U.S. federal rate due to recurring items, such as state income taxes and
rate differences between U.S. and non-U.S. jurisdictions, as well as discrete items that may occur in any given year but
are not consistent from year to year including valuation allowances.

As of December 31, 2020, we had no gross tax-effected unrecognized tax benefits (including interest and penalties),
which, if recognized, would affect our effective tax rate. There were no interest and penalties recognized in our
operating results. There are no significant increases in the amount of unrecognized tax benefits anticipated within the
next twelve months.

We recognize potential accrued interest and penalties related to unrecognized tax benefits, if any, in income tax expense.


-----

**Note 8: Commitments and Contingencies**

**_Litigation_**

We are subject to various legal claims arising in the normal course of business. Based on information currently available,
it is the opinion of management that the ultimate resolution of pending and threatened legal proceedings will not have a
material adverse effect on our results of operations, financial position, or cash flows. However, in the event of unexpected
future developments, it is possible that the ultimate resolution of such matters, if unfavorable, could have a material
adverse effect on our results of operations, financial position, or cash flows.

We establish accruals for legal claims when the costs associated with the claims become probable and can be reasonably
estimated. The actual costs of resolving legal claims may be substantially higher or lower than the amounts accrued for
such claims. In many cases, we are unable to make a meaningful estimate of actual costs or a range of reasonably possible
losses that could possibly be higher or lower than the amounts accrued.

**_Environmental Matters_**

We are subject to environmental laws and regulations related to the use, storage, handling, generation, transportation,
emission, discharge, disposal and remediation of, and exposure to, hazardous and non-hazardous substances and wastes
in all countries which we do business. We monitor the costs associated with these laws and regulations and do not have a
material liability related to environmental matters.

**Note 10: Related Party Transactions**

During 2020, $23.9 million of our debt was purchased by a related party. Of our $451.9 million outstanding long-term
debt, a related party owns $23.9 million as of June 30, 2021. We paid $1.0 and $0.1 million of interest expense to this
related party during the six months ended June 30, 2021 and 2020, respectively.

We paid Platinum Equity Advisors, LLC, (“Advisors”) an affiliate of Platinum Equity, approximately $2.5 million in the
six months ended June 30, 2021 and 2020 for ongoing management services, and such amounts are classified as
Administrative and general expenses in the consolidated statements of comprehensive income (loss).

**Note 11: Equity-based Compensation**

In the 2019, IWC Holding Corporation, a subsidiary of Platinum Equity and our indirect parent company, adopted the
IWC Holding Corporation 2019 Participation Plan (the “Plan”) for the benefit of certain of our key employees.
Performance units granted under the Plan vest only upon a Qualifying Sale Event, as defined. Accordingly, no performance
units have vested, and no compensation expense has been recognized. Vesting will occur, and the compensation expense
will be recognized, when it is probable the performance condition will be met.

**Note 12: Subsequent Events**

We evaluated events subsequent to June 30, 2021 through September 3, 2021, the date the unaudited interim consolidated
financial statements were available to be issued. On July 6, 2021, Platinum Equity entered into a definitive agreement to
acquire Solenis, a leading global producer of specialty chemicals used in water-intensive industries, from Clayton, Dubilier
& Rice and BASF. As part of this transaction, Solenis is expected to merge with IWC. The acquisition of Solenis and
merger with IWC are expected to be completed before the end of 2021, subject to regulatory approval and customary
closing conditions.
